headline: Cummins Engine Amends 'Pill' Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Cummins Engine Company, fighting off the latest potential takeover threat, said it had amended its ''poison pill'' defense. Under the plan, directors of the diesel-engine maker may grant shareholders the right to buy new shares for $1 each if someone acquires 15 percent of the company's stock.

headline: Tourism Plan In France Fails
abstract: LEAD: Efforts to form Europe's third-largest tourism company broke down today, as officials of the companies involved -Club Med Inc. and the air-charter group, Nouvelles Frontieres S.A. - backed away from a preliminary agreement reached in April. Under the accord, Club

headline: 2 BIG POWERS BACK WORLD COURT ROLE
abstract: LEAD: In a move to strengthen international law, the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to accept the binding arbitration of the International Court of Justice in disputes over seven treaties dealing with terrorism and drug trafficking, American diplomats and other officials say.

headline: United Planning Flights to Europe
abstract: LEAD: United Airlines, which has profited from its acquisition of routes across the Pacific, announced yesterday that it would begin flying to Europe next spring, pending government approval.

headline: Polish Communists Condemn 1939 Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party Politburo today condemned the Nazi-Soviet pact that carved up Poland as invalid and a violation of international law.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: S.E.C. Move On 'Baskets'
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Friday that it would ask the full United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit to review a recent decision by a panel of the court that ordered a halt to trading on two stock exchanges of hybrid financial instruments known as stock baskets.

headline: Gallo Curbing Skid Row Sales
abstract: LEAD: The E.&J. Gallo Winery, the world's largest wine maker, said this week that it had stopped selling its high-alcohol Thunderbird and Night Train brands to retailers in skid rows throughout the country. The skid rows were not identified. Thunderbird and Night

headline: Hungarian Fund Aid
abstract: LEAD: The International Finance Corporation, an arm of the World Bank, has said it is helping set up the first fund for foreign portfolio investment in Hungary. International Finance said on Tuesday that it would put up $7.5 million, or 15 percent of the shares in the First Hungary Fund, which is to total $50 million and to last 10 years.

headline: Deputies Order Papandreou To Stand Trial in Wiretapping
abstract: LEAD: Former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was ordered by Parliament today to stand trial on criminal charges of ordering illegal telephone wiretapping during his eight years in power.

headline: Midlantic Offers $100 Million Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Midlantic Corporation, a New Jersey bank holding company, has offered $100 million worth of 12-year subordinated capital notes. The 9.20 percent notes, which mature on Aug. 1, 2001, were priced at $100, or par, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 9 1/8 percent Treasury notes at the time of pricing.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman Is Appointed At Revitalized Gemcraft
abstract: LEAD: When Thomas A. Falik, a Houston lawyer, decided last winter to go into business for himself instead of working on other people's deals, Gemcraft Inc. a bankrupt home builder that had been taken over by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, caught his eye.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Japanese in Deal for 10% of Tiffany
abstract: LEAD: Tiffany & Company, the jewelry maker whose fine products in robin's-egg-blue packages are status symbols around the world, said yesterday that Mitsukoshi Ltd., one of Japan's leading department stores, would buy about 10 percent of its shares.

headline: Court Rejects 3 Bids to Curb Punitive Damages Court Rejects 3 Bids to Curb Awards Against Companies
abstract: LEAD: The Supreme Court today rejected three appeals in cases involving punitive-damage awards in personal-injury lawsuits against companies.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: LEAD:  Economy

headline: Greenstone Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: Greenstone Rabasca Roberts in Melville, L.I., announced the acquisition of Sommer Inc., a small business-to-business ad agency in Englewood, N.J. Ronald Greenstone, Greenstone Rabasca's president, said the acquisition would bring the agency's billings to about $50 million in 1989. Earlier this year, the agency bought Weston Ganoff Marini in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: Stock Surge in Thailand
abstract: LEAD: Thailand's stock market, fueled by optimism over the country's surging economy, has reached record highs. The index of the Securities Exchange of Thailand today passed the previous record of 670. Most analysts see further advances over the next month.

headline: 4 Cuban Officers Sentenced To Die for Drug Trafficking
abstract: LEAD: A Cuban military court today condemned a highly decorated former army general, the general's aide and two other former officers to death by firing squad for drug trafficking in the country's worst scandal since Fidel Castro seized power 30 years ago.

headline: Shamir Faces a Fight in His Party Over His Plan for Arab Elections
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is facing what is likely to be a brutal political battle that could endanger not only Israel's plan for Palestinian elections but also Mr. Shamir's standing as the nation's leader.

headline: Hurricane Imperils Eastern Caribbean; Warnings Are Issued
abstract: LEAD: Residents of the eastern Caribbean boarded up homes and stockpiled supplies today as a hurricane churned toward the popular resort islands with winds of up to 140 miles per hour.

headline: Ralston Purina Unit Being Sold
abstract: LEAD: Beatrice Foods Inc., a unit of the Onyx Corporation, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Bremner Inc. from the Ralston Purina Company. Terms were not disclosed. Bremner, based in Louisville, Ky., makes cookie and cracker products for sale under private-label trademarks. The company has annual sales of $75 million and employs about 450 people.

headline: Partnerships Join In Allegheny Bid
abstract: LEAD: A New York investment group comprising Steinhardt Partners and Japonica Partners has offered to acquire Allegheny International Inc. for $700 million in cash, debt and equity securities. The offer is part of a reorganization plan for the consumer products company, which filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in February 1988.

headline: Bankers Trust Preferred Stock
abstract: LEAD: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation is offering $250 million of fixed- and adjustable-rate preferred stock through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Proceeds from the sale will be used to make an equity investment in its wholly owned subsidiary, the BT Securities Corporation.

headline: Dow Drops 3.61 Points, To 2,680.28
abstract: LEAD: A late spurt of program selling depressed stocks yesterday in continued moderate trading.

headline: 10-Year Notes Get Poor Response
abstract: LEAD: A disappointing auction of 10-year notes sent prices of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds lower yesterday, and dealers questioned whether interest rates would have to move still higher to generate demand for the $9.75 billion worth of 30-year bonds to be sold today.

headline: Sea Containers May Be a Buyer
abstract: LEAD: Sea Containers Ltd. said it had held talks about buying an unidentified company that is ''complementary to certain of Sea Containers's current operations.'' In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sea Containers said there was no assurance that an agreement would be reached.

headline: Rising Worry on 'Partner' Benefits
abstract: LEAD: Employers have begun to worry about the potential costs of health benefits sought by employees for people they live with outside marriage.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 7.1% Increase Projected In TV Advertising Sales
abstract: LEAD: Emboldened by predictions of a robust economy, the Television Bureau of Advertising projected yesterday that revenue from television advertising would increase 7.1 percent in 1990. The bureau said the sharpest growth, an estimated 15 percent, would be in revenue from sales on syndicated programs.

headline: Swings Seen In Treasury Issue Prices
abstract: LEAD: The fixed-income securities market is bracing for a week of volatile price moves in what is normally its slowest period of the year.

headline: Vereeniging Journal; Where the Boers Bargained, the Die-Hards Rally
abstract: LEAD: In 1902, the peace talks that ended the Boer War were played out in this town on the rolling grasslands of the southern Transvaal.

headline: Patents; Diet Pills Said to Curb Fat and Cholesterol
abstract: LEAD: Jackie R. See and William E. Shell, two cardiologists who founded See/ Shell Biotechnology Inc. in Los Angeles, won a patent this week for what they call ''Fat Magnets'': diet pills that prevent the body from absorbing some of the fat and cholesterol in food.

headline: Aquino Is Resolute on Marcos-Burial Ban
abstract: LEAD: Rejecting new appeals from newspaper editorials and many politicians, President Corazon C. Aquino reiterated today that the family of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos would not be permitted to bring his body to the Philippines for burial.

headline: Bucharest Journal; To Rumanians, It Just Feels Like the Third World
abstract: LEAD: The ''personality cult,'' in Soviet standard usage, was a euphemism for Stalin's excesses. In Rumania, the cult of Nicolae Ceausescu has developed its own rituals: adulation, sacrifice and relentless pursuit of heretics.

headline: Brazil Skips Loan Payment
abstract: LEAD: Brazil, the third world's biggest debtor, skipped an important interest payment Monday, joining a growing list of Latin American countries in arrears on debt.

headline: Progress Seen on Plan For Eastern Revamping
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Airlines is making progress in putting together a plan to reorganize under the protection of Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, although two major issues with its unsecured creditors are still unresolved, it was disclosed at a court hearing yesterday.

headline: Careers; Environment Experts in Short Supply
abstract: LEAD: SOLVING environmental problems for companies has become a fast-growing career field, says Vance M. Bakeman, who is vice president of engineering and environmental affairs for W. R. Grace & Company's largest unit, the Grace Specialty Chemicals Company.

headline: 3d Finisher Gains in Bolivia Runoff Deal
abstract: LEAD: The three-month impasse over who is to become President of Bolivia was broken today when a former military ruler, Hugo Banzer Suarez, threw his support in the runoff in Congress to Jaime Paz Zamora.

headline: In Defense Of Ads That Win Awards
abstract: LEAD: NOT for Allan Beaver the awards-bashing that has become fashionable among those who believe in a distinction between creative advertising and sales.

headline: Gorbachev Is Said to Back Baltic Autonomy
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today with Communist Party and Government leaders from the three Baltic republics, and expressed support for greater autonomy for the area, according to the Estonian party leader.

headline: S.E.C. Official To Davis Polk
abstract: LEAD: Gary G. Lynch, director of the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will join the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell as a partner this summer, the firm announced yesterday.

headline: U.S. DRAFTS PLANS TO CURB ADMISSION OF SOVIET JEWS
abstract: LEAD: The State Department and other Federal agencies have drafted plans that would make large numbers of Soviet Jews ineligible for admission to the United States as refugees. A likely effect of the plan would be to channel many of them to Israel, whose Government has long sought such a move.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Worthington Foods Inc. to Partners & Shevack for its Morningstar Farms line of cholesterol-free products, with a budget of $2 million to $5 million.

headline: Market Place; Looking for Value In Airline Assets
abstract: LEAD: AMERICAN AIRLINES, considered by Wall Street to be a prime takeover target, has substantial assets that could generate huge amounts of cash to finance a bid. But the airline is also headed by an executive who could mount a strong defense.

headline: BALTIC COMMUNISTS PRESS MIDDLE ROAD ON INDEPENDENCE
abstract: LEAD: Facing a crisis with Moscow over the growing nationalist movements in the Baltic republics, Communist Party leaders in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania issued statements today that straddled the line between the Kremlin's demand for restraint and local cries for more radical change.

headline: Young Officers in Attack On Soviet Defense Chief
abstract: LEAD: Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov was confirmed in his post by the increasingly restive Soviet legislature today, but only after facing unusually bold opposition led by a group of younger military officers.

headline: Corona Awarded Gold Mine
abstract: LEAD: The Supreme Court of Canada has awarded the country's richest gold mine to the Corona Corporation, ending an eight-year legal battle and freeing the mine's new owners to explore for gold.

headline: Labor Party Considers Pulling Out Of Governing Coalition in Israel
abstract: LEAD: The Labor Party is considering whether to leave its governing coalition with Likud, bringing down the Israeli Government, and analysts on both sides of the question are giving the proposition an even chance.

headline: Navy Contract Is Won by G.E.
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Company said it had been selected by the Navy to provide all the F404-GE-400 turbofan engines for fiscal year 1990 with options to supply the needs for FA-18 aircraft production for the six fiscal years beginning in 1991. The contract could be worth as much as $2 billion, the company said.

headline: Oswiecim Journal; A Place Where the Past Overwhelms the Present
abstract: LEAD: This is a quiet place, population 60,000, wedged into gentle hills between the meandering Vistula and Sola Rivers, actually large streams. But now it is at the center of a dispute over the presence of a convent of Carmelite nuns just outside the walls of the Auschwitz death camp. Jewish groups say the convent should be moved from the site, which they consider the central symbol of the Nazi genocide carried out against European

headline: Populist Regains His Power In Belize General Elections
abstract: LEAD: The populist leader George Price, who led Belize to independence from Britain eight years ago, has regained power in general elections, according to results announced today.

headline: Colombia Journal; A Battle Grande for a Lucrative Span
abstract: LEAD: The Rio Grande flows tranquilly past this sleepy hamlet. But in nearby cities on both sides of the United States-Mexican border, a proposal to build an eight-lane bridge across the river here has created an intense struggle over who will share in the lucrative and fast-growing overland trade between the two countries.

headline: China Is Said to Execute Some in Secret
abstract: LEAD: Amnesty International accused the Chinese Government today of ordering the secret execution of dissidents, and a United Nations human-rights panel debated a move to censure China for its suppression of the democracy movement.

headline: Takeover Bid Rejected By Dunkin' Donuts
abstract: LEAD: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. said today that it had rejected a $45-a-share takeover offer from the DD Acquisition Corporation as inadequate and would explore other alternatives, including the acquisition of the doughnut chain by a third party.

headline: Toppling a Tower of Compromise
abstract: LEAD: Three years almost to the day after Congress approved the Tax Reform Act of 1986, that monumental legislation, the product of dozens of carefully drawn political and economic trade-offs, seems likely to be torn apart by lawmakers in votes this week.

headline: Snags Seen in Europe Unity
abstract: LEAD: The failure of European governments to act quickly is undermining the creation of a European Community with no trade barriers by 1992, a report by the European Commission said today.

headline: IN MOSCOW, TONE IS A STUDIED CALM
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union reacted with deliberate equanimity today to Poland's movement toward a government led by non-Communists, declaring that developments there were strictly an internal affair.

headline: Income Declines by 44% at Bethlehem Steel
abstract: LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday reported a 44 percent drop in earnings in the second quarter, a result of $50 million in charges for restructuring and reducing operations in one division, as well as higher costs.

headline: Panhandle Issue Totals $300 Million
abstract: LEAD: The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company yesterday offered $300 million of senior subordinated reset debentures due in 2001 through Kidder, Peabody & Company.

headline: LABOR LEADERSHIP MOVES TO DISSOLVE COALITION IN ISRAEL
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of the Israeli Labor Party recommended today that Labor leave the coalition with the Likud party, an action that would dissolve the Government.

headline: Savings Unit Outflow Dips
abstract: LEAD: Withdrawals exceeded deposits at the nation's savings institutions by $183 million in July, a nine-month low, the Government said today.

headline: Quinoco is Sold
abstract: LEAD: The Angeles Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Quinoco oil and gas businesses to Saxon Oil Development Partners for $26.5 million. Among the businesses are Quinoco Oil and Gas Inc. and Quinoco Energy Inc. Saxon, based in Dallas, is an oil and gas master limited partnership.

headline: Campeau Said To Lose Control Of Retail Giant
abstract: LEAD: Robert Campeau, the Canadian developer who amassed one of the world's biggest retail empires by borrowing heavily to buy such stores as Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, was forced yesterday to yield control to get yet another loan to keep the operation solvent, executives in Toronto and New York said.

TREAS. BILLS   7.84   7.87   7.06        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.86   7.85   7.53        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.17   8.15   9.19        30-YR.

headline: Greek Bank in U.S. Is Sued
abstract: LEAD: An attorney for depositors in a Greek bank that was raided by Federal authorities last month has filed a lawsuit accusing the bank of taking hundreds of millions of dollars from its depositors.

headline: Quaker Fabric Agrees to Takeover
abstract: LEAD: The Quaker Fabric Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by Unione Manifatture S.p.A. of Italy for $11.35 a share in cash, or a total of about $20.5 million in cash. Quaker said the amount to be paid may not be reduced by more than $1,650, or about 92 cents a share, for certain environmental matters.

headline: JARUZELSKI, MOVED BY 'NEEDS AND ASPIRATIONS' OF POLAND, NAMES WALESA AIDE PREMIER
abstract: LEAD: The Communist President, Wojciech Jaruzelski, today designated a senior Solidarity official, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, to be the first non-Communist Prime Minister of Poland since the early postwar years.

headline: Honecker Has Operation
abstract: LEAD: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, has undergone surgery to remove gallstones and is recovering in the hospital, the East German press agency A.D.N. reported today. It said that Mr. Honecker, who will be 77 years old on Friday, had the operation last week.

headline: Ex-Head of Tropicana At Church & Dwight
abstract: LEAD: The Church & Dwight Company, the maker of Arm & Hammer brand products, has named Spencer J. Volk, former head of Tropicana Products Inc., to be president and chief operating officer.

headline: Chairmen of Banks Discuss Mexican Debt
abstract: LEAD: The chairmen of the banks that are negotiating with Mexico on a debt reduction and restructuring package met in New York yesterday to try to agree on the final elements of a plan, bankers said.

headline: A Struggle to Compete in a Shrinking Market
abstract: LEAD: For distillers, the 1980's have proved to be a prolonged hangover.

headline: KENYA, IN GESTURE, BURNS IVORY TUSKS
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel arap Moi ignited 12 tons of elephant tusks today in a gesture to persuade the world to halt the ivory trade.

headline: Mexican Mine Closing Stirs Deep Emotions
abstract: LEAD: By closing the nation's largest mine, considered the birthplace of the Mexican labor movement, the Government has spurred nationwide criticism and has set off a strike by several thousand mine workers.

headline: U.N. Begins Literacy Year With Celebration
abstract: LEAD: Aiming to help make literacy a global priority in the next decade, the General Assembly started International Literacy Year today with a celebration featuring Barbara Bush, two puppets and a group of singing schoolchildren.

headline: Quayle Plans 2d Asian Trip
abstract: LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle will travel next month to South Korea, Japan and the Philippines, his office announced today. The trip, Sept. 19 to 28, will include meetings with Presidents Roh Tae Woo of South Korea and Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines.

headline: Crowds Jam Calcutta To Mark 300th Year
abstract: LEAD: Some 200,000 people jammed central Calcutta today as the former capital of the British Raj began its 300th birthday party.

headline: Great Western Expanding in Florida
abstract: LEAD: The Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif., said today that it had agreed to acquire 63 branches from Centrust Bank of Miami, giving it the largest branch network of any savings and loan in Florida.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''The people that got burned are the banks and the smaller guys, who were a little more desperate and shipped clothes with their fingers crossed.''  Howard Bloom, president of Chetta B,  a dress maker, on the bankruptcy filings  by Bonwit and B. Altman.

headline: Old Newspapers Hit a Logjam
abstract: LEAD: Hour after hour, around the clock, bundles of old newspapers rumble along a conveyor until they drop into a large vat at the Garden State Paper Company's recycling mill here along the Passaic River. In a few hours they will emerge as rolls of blank newsprint, ready to be used again.

headline: Kompong Speu Journal; The Princess and 'the Peacock': A Cambodia Tale
abstract: LEAD: ''I'm a museum piece in this country,'' said Lyda Sisowath, doing a sort of pirouette as she ministered to a war widow, offering mosquito netting and incense for the Buddha.

headline: Hewlett Will License Microprocessor Design
abstract: LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company, in a change of strategy intended to match a rival, Sun Microsystems Inc., has decided to license its microprocessor design to other companies, company officials said today.

headline: An Odd Deal: Main Client Buys Tarlow
abstract: LEAD: AFTER 18 months of explosive growth - during which the agency rose from nothing to $90 million in billings and was designated as Adweek's 1989 ''Agency of the Year'' for the Eastern United States - Tarlow Advertising was acquired on Friday by its largest client, the Revlon Group.

headline: A FRONT-RUNNER EMERGES IN JAPAN
abstract: LEAD: After nine days of maneuvering among faction leaders and elders in the governing Liberal Democratic Party, a former Minister of Education emerged today as the clear front-runner in the scramble to become the next Prime Minister.

headline: A.T.&T. Wins Round in 'Dumping' Fight
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company cleared a major hurdle yesterday in its efforts to convince the Government that equipment manufacturers in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan are selling small-business telephone systems in the United States at unfairly low prices.

headline: Typesetting Gets a Digital Facelift
abstract: LEAD: Until recently, only publishers with access to expensive laser printers could participate in the digital typsetting revolution, one of the most fundamental changes in the five-century history of typography. Now digital typography is about to become part of the basic software controlling personal computers and work stations, allowing millions of users to generate and display typefaces on their computer screens and on inexpensive printers.

headline: A New Razor For Gillette
abstract: LEAD: The Gillette Company, bruised in recent takeover battles, plans to introduce a new razor next week that the company is touting as a ''revolutionary new shaving system.''

headline: Exchange Expels Firm
abstract: LEAD: The commodity trading firm Capcom Financial Services Ltd. has been expelled from the Chicago Board of Trade in response to its indictment on charges involving a multimillion-dollar scheme to launder drug profits, the Board of Trade said Thursday. London-based Capcom, which had been a member since 1985, agreed to the expulsion and to never reapply for membership.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Airbus Industrie said Braniff Inc., had ordered 50 of its single-aisle Airbus A320 aircraft and had taken options on 50 more. The sale price was not disclosed.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Rapid Rail
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Israelis Cut Jail Terms of 3 Who Beat an Arab to Death
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army today cut short by three months the jail terms of three soldiers convicted in the fatal beating of a Palestinian in custody.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Iranian Parliament Delays Showdown Over Hard-Liner
abstract: LEAD: Iran's Parliament delayed a showdown today over the rejection of a leading anti-Western minister from the new President's Cabinet, but the hard-liners won a skirmish by voting down a motion to impeach a another minister.

headline: CHINA PARTY PLANS PARLEY ON ECONOMY
abstract: LEAD: The Central Committee of the Communist Party will meet next month to ratify a detailed policy of economic retrenchment that will last through 1991, Chinese officials and foreign diplomats say.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Spain's Leader Weighing Plans for Elections
abstract: LEAD: Encouraged by his party's strong showing in recent elections for the European Parliament, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez is debating whether to call general elections before June 1990, when they are due.

headline: Deal for H.M.S.S.
abstract: LEAD: SecoAmerica Inc., a diversified services company that is the American arm of the Secom Company Ltd. of Japan, signed a definitive agreement to acquire H.M.S.S. for $50 a share, or $250 million, and said it would commence a tender offer later this week for the home health-care services company. H.M.S.S.

headline: Soviet Official Acknowledges Stalin-Hitler Protocol Existed
abstract: LEAD: A senior Kremlin official has conceded for the first time that the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany divided Eastern Europe between themselves in secret protocols to a 1939 nonaggression pact.

headline: Castro Begins to Talk of a Decline in Crucial Aid From Soviets
abstract: LEAD: As a result of radical changes under way in the Soviet bloc, Fidel Castro is beginning to speak of a decline in economic aid that has been crucial to Cuba's survival.

headline: Knight-Ridder Officers Shifted
abstract: LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc. announced today that Alvah Chapman, 68 years old, would step down as chairman, effective Oct. 1, and would be replaced by James K. Batten. 53, the chief executive.

headline: BRITISH EXAMINING SECURITY AT BASES
abstract: LEAD: British defense officials said today that they had ordered a general review of security at military installations after an Irish Republican Army bomb attack that killed 10 members of the Royal Marines Band Friday.

headline: Ex-Goldman Trader Enters a Guilty Plea
abstract: LEAD: Robert A. Freeman, once a senior trader at one of Wall Street's most powerful investment houses, pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to charges that he illegally traded on insider information.

headline: TV Station for Pulitzer
abstract: LEAD: The Pulitzer Publishing Company has agreed to buy WDSU-TV, the NBC affiliate in New Orleans, for $46.8 million from the Cosmos Broadcasting Corporation, Pulitzer announced Monday.

headline: Utility Executive Ready To Roll Up His Sleeves
abstract: LEAD: On election night in November, a power failure blacked out The Idaho Statesman newspaper office in Boise, which had been serving as the headquarters for reporting the state's computerized election returns. Joseph W. Marshall, then the Idaho Power Company's executive vice president, went to the scene to help workers restore electricity.

headline: Migrant Job Program Baffles Mexico
abstract: LEAD: A new United States immigration program, aimed at preventing potential labor shortages in American agriculture over the next four years, is causing confusion and controversy throughout Mexico, which is expected to supply most of the workers for the plan.

headline: ITALY ADDRESSES POLITICAL IMPASSE
abstract: LEAD: Giulio Andreotti, Italy's most durable politician of the postwar era, has been called on once again to try to form a government and finally end a political impasse that has left the country without effective leadership for nearly two months.

headline: House Panel Starts Work on 'Bare-Bones' Tax Bill
abstract: LEAD: The House Ways and Means Committee began deliberations on a tax bill today, working from a ''bare-bones'' proposal by its chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski. The plan would raise only the $5.3 billion needed to meet this year's budget target.

headline: 9 Are Killed on Second Day Of Bombardments in Beirut
abstract: LEAD: Nine people were killed as much of Beirut came under intense shelling tonight by Syrian and Christian forces, the second straight night of bombardment, the police said.

headline: Dunkin' Donuts In Several Pacts
abstract: LEAD: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. said it had signed confidentiality agreements with several parties interested in pursuing the possible acquisition of the doughnut-store chain. The parties to be given confidential corporate data include the DD Acquisition Corporation, which has been conducting a hostile tender offer for Dunkin' Donuts.

headline: Cummins Engine Amends 'Pill' Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Cummins Engine Company, fighting off the latest potential takeover threat, said it had amended its ''poison pill'' defense. Under the plan, directors of the diesel-engine maker may grant shareholders the right to buy new shares for $1 each if someone acquires 15 percent of the company's stock.

abstract: LEAD: Efforts to form Europe's third-largest tourism company broke down today, as officials of the companies involved -Club Med Inc. and the air-charter group, Nouvelles Frontieres S.A. - backed away from a preliminary agreement reached in April. Under the accord, Club

abstract: LEAD: In a move to strengthen international law, the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to accept the binding arbitration of the International Court of Justice in disputes over seven treaties dealing with terrorism and drug trafficking, American diplomats and other officials say.

headline: United Planning Flights to Europe
abstract: LEAD: United Airlines, which has profited from its acquisition of routes across the Pacific, announced yesterday that it would begin flying to Europe next spring, pending government approval.

headline: Polish Communists Condemn 1939 Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party Politburo today condemned the Nazi-Soviet pact that carved up Poland as invalid and a violation of international law.

abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Friday that it would ask the full United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit to review a recent decision by a panel of the court that ordered a halt to trading on two stock exchanges of hybrid financial instruments known as stock baskets.

abstract: LEAD: The International Finance Corporation, an arm of the World Bank, has said it is helping set up the first fund for foreign portfolio investment in Hungary. International Finance said on Tuesday that it would put up $7.5 million, or 15 percent of the shares in the First Hungary Fund, which is to total $50 million and to last 10 years.

headline: Deputies Order Papandreou To Stand Trial in Wiretapping
abstract: LEAD: Former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was ordered by Parliament today to stand trial on criminal charges of ordering illegal telephone wiretapping during his eight years in power.

headline: Swedish Bank Raided
abstract: LEAD: The police last week raided the head office of Sweden's largest bank, Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken, to seize material in a tax evasion inquiry against its chief executive, Jacob Palmstierna.

headline: August Soybean Contracts Seen as Possible Problem
abstract: LEAD: Concern deepened here today that the Chicago Board of Trade, having averted a crisis in trading of its July soybean contracts, would soon face a crisis in its August soybean contracts.

headline: Hungarian Serenade: Wooing Voters and the West
abstract: LEAD: The Communist leadership is casting about for ways out of Hungary's deep political and economic predicaments that will appeal to two critical quarters: the West and the Hungarian electorate.

headline: Real Estate; A Movie House Boom In Manhattan
abstract: LEAD: HOPING to cash in on what so far has been one of the best box office summers in movie history, the developers of a large new theater under construction on 23d Street east of Eighth Avenue are rushing to finish the project.

headline: The Post Drops Real Estate
abstract: LEAD: The weekly real estate section of The New York Post, established with much fanfare in 1987, has been canceled.

headline: Medellin Banks Bombed; Justice Chief Said to Be Near Quitting
abstract: LEAD: Nine bank offices, seven of them Government-owned, were dynamited today, presumably by drug traffickers, as indications grew that the Minister of Justice was resigning in the face of death threats.

headline: Treasury Issues Mixed in Active Trading
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities finished narrowly mixed yesterday, although trading was active as many market participants squared their books before going on vacation. Dealers said retail buying of Treasury coupon issues was evident even before the Government announced a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index for July in midmorning, a figure that was in line with expectations.

headline: Russians in Estonia Pledge To Continue Strike Over Law
abstract: LEAD: Striking Russian workers in the Soviet Baltic republic of Estonia pledged today to continue their protest against a new local voting law.

headline: Grim Vigil, Then Reprieve for Hostage Family
abstract: LEAD: The American relatives of Joseph James Cicippio waited two hours after the deadline for his execution had passed today before learning that his Lebanese captors had given him a 48-hour reprieve.

headline: Sugar Moves Up Sharply On Rumor of Indian Buying
abstract: LEAD: Sugar futures prices rose sharply yesterday amid rumors that India had made a long-expected purchase of refined white sugar on the world market to offset partly its projected shortfall of nearly a million metric tons.

headline: For VW, the Future Is Its Past
abstract: LEAD: In introducing a racy car called the Corrado last week, Volkswagen A.G. provided a reminder that it faces a long, difficult road back from the fringes of the American car market.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Brent Walker P.L.C. said its $:170 million purchase of the wine and spirits division of Lonrho P.L.C., London, had been approved by Britain's Department of Trade and Industry.

headline: Manager at First Boston Leaving to Join Wespar
abstract: LEAD: The First Boston Corporation continues to suffer more personnel defections. The latest is Kelly A. Dunne, manager of $1.5 billion in high-yield investments at First Boston asset management, who is leaving to join Wespar Financial Corporation in Century City, Calif.

abstract: LEAD:  THE ECONOMY       $       Gross National Product     II Q'89    I Q'89    Year Ago       Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions     $4,123.9    $4,106.8    $4,010.7        Real G.N.P. headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Romanoff International Inc., to the Bloom Agency, with a budget of $1 million.

headline: UAL Stock Up Again; Board Meets Today
abstract: LEAD: The shares of the UAL Corporation, parent company of United Airlines, jumped again yesterday - rising $8.50, to close at $219.25 - in advance of a meeting today at which UAL directors will consider a takeover offer from Marvin Davis.

headline: Europe Vows No Bias Against U.S. Chips
abstract: LEAD: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today that the European Community had assured her that it would not discriminate against American manufacturers in setting rules of origin for computer memory chips.

headline: Glemp Is Reticent on the Auschwitz Convent
abstract: LEAD: A day after the Vatican threw its authority behind the relocation of a Roman Catholic convent from the site of the Auschwitz death camp, there was no formal response from Jozef Cardinal Glemp of Warsaw.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Companies  Eastman Kodak said it would eliminate 4,500 jobs, about 3 percent of its work force, and sell some businesses. The company also said it would cut management salaries by up to 40 percent. The announcement came three weeks after Kodak reported a sharp drop in second-quarter earnings.

headline: Opponents in Ethiopian War Meet With Carter in Atlanta for Talks
abstract: LEAD: Representatives of the Ethiopian Government and a rebel group seeking independence from Ethiopia met here today to begin talks aimed at ending their 28-year war, which has taken a million lives.

headline: Baker Heads for Japan (Scandal on His Mind)
abstract: LEAD: The first order of business for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on his weeklong Pacific tour will be finding a way to avoid being pulled into the scandal swirling around Japan's beleaguered Prime Minister, Sousuke Uno.

headline: Stocks Fall Broadly as Dow Drops 22.42
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices plunged across a broad front yesterday on the heels of a steep decline in the dollar and in bond prices.

headline: Las Vegas Papers Seek Approval for a Merger
abstract: LEAD: The Las Vegas Sun, for nearly four decades the embodiment of a maverick newspaper, is trying to assure a half-century more of journalistic life by applying with its bitter rival, The Las Vegas Review-Journal, for an unusual joint operating arrangement.

headline: In Seoul, a Hot Debate on Dealing With the North
abstract: LEAD: While its Communist neighbor prepares for its highly publicized World Festival of Youth and Students, which starts this weekend, South Korea has become embroiled in a long-running debate over the timing and nature of contacts with Pyongyang.

headline: Pilots Said To Plan Bid For United
abstract: LEAD: The pilots union at United Airlines plans to make an offer to buy the carrier that could be worth $6.5 billion, a Wall Street executive and an investor with major holdings in the airline said yesterday.

headline: Hydrogen Pushed as Motor Fuel
abstract: LEAD: Recent advances in the efficiency of cells that convert solar energy to electricity are increasing the possibility of using hydrogen as a practical, low-polluting motor vehicle fuel, according to a new study by two Princeton University physicists that was released here today.

headline: 7 Feared Dead in Cuba Crash
abstract: LEAD: A Cuban Air Force training plane crashed into the sea several miles northwest of Havana and seven men aboard are believed dead, the Juventud Rebelde youth newspaper reported today.

headline: In Soviet Asia Backwater, Infancy's a Rite of Survival
abstract: LEAD: This is the dying season here, the time of year when the flowering birth rates in Soviet Central Asia are tempered by the number of babies who die before reaching their first birthdays.

headline: Squibb to Invest In Research Center
abstract: LEAD: The Squibb Corporation said it would invest $50 million in long-term research in cellular and molecular biology and genetics at the University Louis Pasteur in Strasbourg, France. The drug company, based in Princeton, N.J., will build a research center at Illkirch-Graffenstaden, near Strasbourg, where it will support 50 of the 400 scientists directed by Prof.

headline: Michelin to Acquire Uniroyal Goodrich
abstract: LEAD: In a deal that will create the world's largest tire company, the Michelin Group of France agreed yesterday to acquire the Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company in a transaction valued at $1.5 billion.

headline: McDonald's Hopes Pizza Will Be the Next McHit
abstract: LEAD: After several years trying to develop a pizza-making operation fast and good enough to satisfy its customers, the McDonald's Corporation has begun to test-market a product.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Levine Picked By Ethan Allen
abstract: LEAD: After a two-year hiatus without an agency, Ethan Allen Inc. yesterday selected Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver to handle its $10 million advertising account. The account had been at Hill, Holliday, Connors & Cosmopulos, Boston, until two years ago, when the home-furnishing company dropped the agency and began assigning its business on a project basis.

headline: Mortgage Rates Drop
abstract: LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.07 percent, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That rate was down from 10.19 percent a week earlier. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.92 percent this week, compared with 9 percent the previous week, Freddie Mac said.

headline: New Twist In Bidding For Utility
abstract: LEAD: The maneuvering to end the 20-month bankruptcy of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire took an unanticipated and complex twist yesterday, as the bidding for the beleaguered electric system moved in opposite directions.

headline: Treasury Securities Rise Again
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher again yesterday, regaining more ground lost in the big selloff on Friday and Monday.

headline: Chip-Making Machines Sent To East Bloc, Japanese Say
abstract: LEAD: Investigators disclosed today that some of Japan's most sophisticated equipment for making computer chips was illegally diverted to East Germany by a company that is also suspected of sending nuclear material to the Soviet bloc.

headline: AZT Maker Expected to Reap Big Gain
abstract: LEAD: Favorable medical findings announced on Thursday will help AZT become one of the world's biggest-selling drugs, sharply improving the fortunes of Wellcome P.L.C., the British company that owns its manufacturer, drug industry analysts said yesterday.

headline: Borden to Cut 7,000 Jobs And 65 Plants
abstract: LEAD: After a three-and-a-half-year buying binge in which it spent $1.7 billion and more than doubled the number of its plants, Borden Inc. reversed course yesterday. The nation's No. 1 dairy company said it will close or sell 65 of its 265 plants in the next two or three years and cut worldwide employment by 7,000 people, bringing its payroll down to 39,000.

headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; Rhinebeck Town Houses Circle Ponds
abstract: LEAD: The Rhinebeck area of northern Dutchess County in New York State, rich in history and scenery, is a 90-minute train ride or a 95-mile drive from Manhattan. And across the Hudson River, in Kingston, is the International Business Machines Corporation's Data Systems division with 6,200 employees.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Dominick F. Rossi Jr., executive vice president and director of national operations at N. W. Ayer, has been appointed to the additional post of president of the agency's Middle Western division.

headline: Comex to Test Hand-Held Computers to Record Trades
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Exchange Inc. announced yesterday that it would begin floor-testing hand-held computers that are intended to prevent trading abuses of the sort that led to the Federal investigation earlier this year of commodities traders in New York and Chicago.

headline: Princess Anne and Husband Agree to Separate
abstract: LEAD: Princess Anne and her husband, Mark Phillips, have agreed to separate after nearly 16 years of marriage, Buckingham Palace said today.

headline: Magazine Publishers Look Abroad
abstract: LEAD: SEVERAL American magazine publishers whose concerns have been largely domestic have begun to look with increasing interest at foreign lands, especially Europe.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Bio-Response Inc., Hayward, Calif., a bioprocessing company, said it had filed for creditor protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code after failing to reach an arrangement with debenture holders.

headline: GATT Delay on China Bid
abstract: LEAD: GATT has postponed a meeting to consider a bid by China to join the 96-nation trade forum ''because of difficulties in having meaningful discussions in present circumstances,'' a spokesman for the group said today.

headline: London Journal; Battling for England's Green and Pleasant Land
abstract: LEAD: In the tiny, cluttered headquarters of Britain's Green Party, where workers seem to do three things at once, the walls are decorated with posters that read: ''The earth can't vote. You can. Vote Green.''

headline: 7 Insurers Told To Justify Rates
abstract: LEAD: California's Insurance Commissioner on Tuesday ordered seven of the state's largest insurance companies to show why they should not be forced to cut their rates by 20 percent. The commissioner, Roxani

headline: Time Warner Payout
abstract: LEAD: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would begin paying cash for the 100 million shares it accepted from Warner shareholders under the Time offer that expired on July 24. Time, which is paying $70 a share for Warner, said that about 175 million shares out of 198 million were tendered. Time itself owns an additional 17 million shares of Warner.

headline: Extradition by Swiss
abstract: LEAD: A Lebanese businessman was extradited to West Germany Wednesday to face charges of fraud in an oil trading scandal, the Swiss justice ministry said. West German authorities accuse the businessman, Khalil J. Ghattas, of heading an illegal scheme that cost the trading house Kloeckner & Company $303 million.

headline: Buffett to Add To Coke Stake
abstract: LEAD: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire Omaha investor, said today that he planned to seek permission from Federal antitrust officials to raise his stake in the Coca-Cola Company to 15 percent, from 6.75 percent.

headline: About Real Estate; Town Houses to Go Up On a Weehawken Pier
abstract: LEAD: A concrete pier in Weehawken, N.J., that is almost as long as the Empire State Building is high is being developed into a complex of five-story town houses by the Coastal Group of Colts Neck, N.J.

headline: Dunkin' Donuts Talks With Bidder
abstract: LEAD: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. said it was talking with the DD Acquisition Corporation about providing the hostile bidder with confidential data and arranging a meeting. The disclosure came a day after the Randolph, Mass., doughnut chain rejected DD Acquisition's sweetened $45-a-share takeover offer as inadequate.

headline: Market Place; Value Questions In Warner Deal
abstract: LEAD: WITH the ''junk bond'' market reeling, shareholders of Warner Communications Inc. are suffering.

headline: Import Fall Narrows Trade Gap
abstract: LEAD: A decline in imports that could signal economic softness helped the nation's trade deficit fall to $7.58 billion in July, its lowest level in four and a half years, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: Drexel Sued On '85 Buyout
abstract: LEAD: Three former heirs to the Pacific Lumber Company have filed a lawsuit against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York, charging fraud in the financing of a hostile buyout of the company.

headline: 3 Top Officers Are Quitting Suzuki Unit
abstract: LEAD: Plagued by poor sales of its cars and continuing doubts among drivers about the safety of its Samurai sport-utility vehicle, the American Suzuki Motor Corporation announced a management shake-up today. Four top executives are being transferred or have resigned.

headline: Stimulating The Growth Of Livestock
abstract: LEAD: Researchers at Genentech Inc., the biotechnology company in South San Francisco, Calif., have patented what officials describe as a biological skeleton key that unlocks the growth mechanisms in livestock without using hormones.

headline: Mysterious Waves May Speed Fiber Optics
abstract: LEAD: A seemingly unnatural phenomenon, a wave that rolls along almost endlessly without losing its shape, may provide the key to increasing the speed of fiber-optic communications almost a hundredfold.

headline: The Power Of the Sound Of Speech
abstract: LEAD: IN a dark and smoky chamber two floors above 10th Avenue and 56th Street, Tony Schwartz roosts behind a music stand, a solo performer in New York's oddest cabaret act. A master of political advertising, Mr. Schwartz ignores the grand piano to his right, playing instead a small tape recorder as he sings the body electronic.

headline: Market Place; Branching Out From Auto Parts
abstract: LEAD: Among the host of companies looking to cash in on the renewed emphasis on environmental issues, the SPX Corporation is in a fairly unusual situation.

headline: Savimbi Says He Is Halting Angolan Peace Talks
abstract: LEAD: The Angolan guerrilla leader, Jonas Savimbi, said tonight that he was suspending negotiations to end his country's long civil war because the two sides remain too far apart to have meaningful talks.

headline: Vehicle Sales Jumped By 22% in Late August
abstract: LEAD: Responding to aggressive discounting of vehicles left at the end of the model year, American automobile buyers lifted the sales of domestically built cars by more than 22 percent in late August.

headline: Argentine Wavers on Army Pardons
abstract: LEAD: Under pressure from families of victims, human rights groups and political parties, President Carlos Saul Menem appears to be backing away from plans to grant a broad pardon for political killings, torture and other crimes committed during the last military Government.

headline: Prices Paid To Farmers Drop 1.4%
abstract: LEAD: Prices that farmers were paid for raw products dropped 1.4 percent from July to August, putting the monthly average just where it was a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: SEES SHIITE PLOT
abstract: LEAD: The Egyptian authorities say they have arrested 41 people believed to be members of what they call a clandestine Shiite Muslim movement whose members trained in Iran and Syria to attack American and Israeli targets and overthrow the pro-Western Government of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Patents; Gout Drug May Help To Curb Cockroaches
abstract: LEAD: Physicians have long prescribed allopurinol for people who suffer from gout. Now three entomologists think it may be a formidable weapon against cockroaches.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: CSC Industries, Warren, Ohio, named W. Lawrence Weeks president and chief executive, replacing John G. Roberts, who retired but will remain a director.

headline: 10-Part Financing By Fannie Mae
abstract: LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association is selling $300 million of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter.

headline: Stance on Debt By Venezuela
abstract: LEAD: Venezuela will insist on a 50 percent cut in its foreign debt in negotiations with creditors, its Minister of Coordination and Planning, Miguel Rodriguez, told the state news agency Venpres.

headline: Turmoil in Colombia
abstract: LEAD: Nine Colombian bank offices were bombed, and the nation's Justice Minister reportedly resigned after receiving death threats. Page A10.

headline: Soviet Arms Official Criticizes West's Plans
abstract: LEAD: As the Vienna negotiations on reducing conventional arms in Europe began their summer break, the chief Soviet negotiator today criticized the Western proposals.

headline: ORDERS FOR DURABLES DOWN 1.9% IN JULY
abstract: LEAD: Orders to American factories for durable goods tumbled 1.9 percent in July to the lowest level in nine months, the Government said today. The report provides further evidence that the economy is weakening.

headline: 'Help Wanted' Signs Sprout in West as East Germans Continue to Arrive
abstract: LEAD: As East Germans continued to stream into this border town, the local paper published a special supplement listing more than 4,000 jobs, many including the offer of an apartment or room.

headline: Health-Care Cures
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: GTE Unit Prices Mortgage Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The General Telephone Company of the South, a unit of the GTE Corporation, yesterday priced $100 million in 9 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2029 through competitive bidding.

headline: Fruehauf Sets Sale of Some Units
abstract: LEAD: The Fruehauf Corporation said it had completed the sale of its trailer, maritime and Cemco businesses to the Terex Trailer Corporation.

headline: Williams Revises Primerica Merger
abstract: LEAD: The Primerica Corporation and the A. L. Williams Corporation said a special committee of Williams's independent directors had approved the revised terms of the proposed merger of the two companies. Under the revision, 82-hundredths of a Primerica share will be exchanged for each Williams share. The previous exchange ratio was 80-hundredths of a share.

headline: 'Junk' Market Nervous As Selling Continues
abstract: LEAD: In an attempt to ease the fear and uncertainty that has gripped the ''junk bond'' market in recent days, Goldman, Sachs & Company yesterday told its institutional customers that the investment firm stood ready to provide trading liquidity and buy junk bonds ''across the board.''

headline: Experts See Nuclear Energy as Cure for Global Warming
abstract: LEAD: The cure for the greenhouse effect, the warming of the atmosphere that is believed to be caused by the burning of fossil fuels, is a huge shift to nuclear-generated power, speaker after speaker told delegates at a World Energy Conference meeting this week.

headline: Bush Rejects Coffee Appeal
abstract: LEAD: President Bush is refusing a request by President Virgilio Barco of Colombia to reinstate a one-year Colombian coffee export program that has been beneficial to Colombian farmers, the White House says.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  PREPARATORY COMMISSION FOR THE INTERNATIONAL SEABED AUTHORITY AND THE INTERNATIONAL TRIBUNAL FOR THE LAW OF THE SEA - 3 P.M.

headline: Dow Advances 8.34 to End at 2,687.97
abstract: LEAD: Stocks advanced yesterday in continued subdued trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average tacking on 8.34 points to close at 2,687.97.

headline: Democratic Effort on Tax Plan
abstract: LEAD: House Democratic leaders, fearful that a measure reducing capital gains taxes may have enough Democratic votes for passage in the Ways and Means Committee and later on the House floor, scrambled today to fashion an alternative that would keep their colleagues in line.

headline: Time Stock Slides to $141
abstract: LEAD: Time Inc.'s stock fell $4.25 yesterday, to $141, after sliding $4.75 Friday when a Delaware Chancery Court cleared Time to buy Warner Communications Inc. despite a bid for Time from Paramount Communications. Warner rose $1.125, to $65.375, on volume of more than 3.5 million shares while Paramount fell $1.25, to $56.25, as 885,000 shares were traded.

headline: Acura Is Tops For Third Year
abstract: LEAD: The buyers of Acura automobiles are the most satisfied with their cars and their dealers, according to a survey released today by J. D. Power & Associates, a research firm.

headline: Offering by Bank Of Nova Scotia
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of Nova Scotia priced $200 million of subordinated notes yesterday through competitive bidding by a group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: New Potential UAL Suitors Emerge and Stock Climbs
abstract: LEAD: The prospects of a bidding war for the UAL Corporation heated up yesterday as two new potential suitors appeared.

headline: Stalinist Rumania Closes In on Itself
abstract: LEAD: While Hungary and Poland move toward a multiparty system and all of Eastern Europe ponders its future, Rumania steadily closes in on itself in pursuit of the Stalinist visions of its leader, Nicolae Ceausescu.

headline: 2 Commodity Brokers Sued
abstract: LEAD: Two investors in commodity futures options, accusing two brokerages of fraudulent sales ploys, filed class-action suits today for $800 million in losses and damages.

headline: Tijuana Journal; U.S. Athletes Advised: Get Your Steroids Here!
abstract: LEAD: As tourists cross the border from San Diego, they are likely to be given fliers urging the aspiring Olympian or All-America athlete to stop by the nearest pharmacy and choose from what is advertised as ''Steroids: Largest Selection Anywhere, at Wholesale Prices!''

headline: Vitro's Strategy In Anchor Offer
abstract: LEAD: The battle for the Anchor Glass Container Corporation has just begun, and despite the company's resistance, many analysts say Vitro S.A., a giant Mexican glass manufacturer, stands a good chance of success with its $20-a-share tender offer for Anchor.

headline: U.S. Is Sending Military Specialists to Train the Colombians
abstract: LEAD: Detailing a more ambitious role for United States servicemen being sent to Colombia, the Pentagon said today that it would dispatch 50 to 100 military personnel to train Colombians to operate and maintain the $65 million worth of arms and equipment promised by President Bush.

headline: A Publisher Is Named for Miami Herald
abstract: LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc. said yesterday that David Lawrence Jr., publisher of The Detroit Free Press, will become publisher of The Miami Herald, the company's flagship newspaper, on Sept. 1.

headline: Pronouncing The Names
abstract: LEAD: JACEK AMBROZIAK, legal adviser to the Polish bishops: YAHT-sek ahm-BRO-zhak.

headline: 49% Sosa Stake For D.M.B.&B.
abstract: LEAD: Sosa & Associates, a leading Hispanic advertising agency, announced yesterday that it had sold a 49 percent interest to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/U.S.A. and, not coincidentally, had been awarded the Spanish-language advertising and promotions account of Burger King, a major D.M.B.&B. client.

headline: Trotsky Works Printed In a Soviet Magazine
abstract: LEAD: An official Soviet magazine published works by Trotsky today for the first time since he was exiled and slain, presumably on Stalin's orders.

headline: C.F.T.C. Chief Before Panel
abstract: LEAD: Wendy L. Gramm, chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, told skeptical members of Congress today that the futures markets do not require major reforms now.

headline: Market Place; Electric Utilities Face Competition
abstract: LEAD: FOR years electric utilities have produced energy with little fear of much changing except how much the regulators allowed them to earn, and investors have counted mainly on a steady dividend. But the industry is rapidly changing. Analysts see investment opportunities among the bigger, more competitive utilities, but they caution that many of the smaller ones will not survive.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Prudential Account Is Placed Under Review
abstract: LEAD: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has placed its $60 million advertising account under review, but a spokesman for the company maintained yesterday that Prudential still had a strong relationship with its agency, Backer Spielvogel Bates.

headline: Catering to a New Batch of Home Buyers
abstract: LEAD: With baby boomers nesting, furniture sales - listless through the 1970's - are growing once again. Retail sales have climbed 24 percent since 1985, to $29.4 billion last year, according to the American Furniture Manufacturers Association, a trade group.

headline: Banks Seek I.R.A. Talks
abstract: LEAD: Bankers said yesterday that they expect to meet with Labor Department officials later this month to discuss a department opinion that could cause cause considerable turmoil in the $231.8 billion of I.R.A. accounts at banks and savings institutions.

headline: Dow Declines 12.91; Airline Stocks Falter
abstract: LEAD: Stocks lost ground for a second consecutive session yesterday, led by heavy declines among airline issues.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: Companies

headline: Supreme Court in Hungary Declares Nagy Was Innocent
abstract: LEAD: Hungary's Supreme Court today declared the innocence of former Prime Minister Imre Nagy, who was hanged as a traitor three decades ago.

headline: Compaq and I.B.M Sign Patent Accord
abstract: LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation signed a patent cross-license agreement under which each company granted to the other a non-exclusive license that covers patents having an effective filing date before July 1, 1993, Compaq said today.

headline: A CROP OF NEW AND EXOTIC SPECIES - FROM TALAPIA TO CRABS
abstract: LEAD: In the last few years, farmers have been growing and experimenting with a host of new and exotic aquacultural species like talapia, abalone, sturgeon, hybrid striped bass, red fish, alligator, crab, crawfish and oysters. In many cases, these growers are trying to cash in on the dwindling supplies of these fish in nature.

headline: South Africa Miners' Pact
abstract: LEAD: South Africa's biggest union, the National Union of Mineworkers, accepted a pay offer today from the leading mining houses, averting a repetition of a damaging nationwide strike in 1987.

headline: Peruvian Economy Plan
abstract: LEAD: Peru's Economy Minister has vowed to raise wages and clear the way for easier imports by the end of the year as part of a plan to revive the country's battered economy. ''Over the next six months the state will promote a revival of economic growth, we hope with the firm cooperation of the private sector,'' the Economy Minister, Cesar Vasquez Bazan, said in a television address on Monday.

headline: Investments In Taiwan Rise
abstract: LEAD: Foreign investment in Taiwan hit a record high in the first eight months of 1989, and officials today attributed the rise to political turmoil in China and labor strikes in South Korea.

headline: Dollar Jumps; Selling by Fed Is Reported
abstract: LEAD: The dollar rose sharply against major currencies yesterday after the employment report for July convinced many traders that the economy was not slowing down sharply and that there was therefore less reason to expect the Federal Reserve to move interest rates lower soon.

headline: Toyota Increases 1990 Prices by 1.8%
abstract: LEAD: The Toyota Motor Company raised its prices in the United States for the company's 1990 cars by an average of 1.8 percent, or by about $178, from the final 1989 retail price. The company said the increase was its first since the 1989 models were introduced last fall. It said the 1990 prices reflected installation of more safety equipment, new-model changes and product upgradings.

headline: Market Place; Equity Fund Sales Gain Momentum
abstract: LEAD: WITH stock prices at record levels, individual investors are growing less nervous.

headline: In Beijing, Humdrum Masks the Scars of June
abstract: LEAD: The peculiar thing about Beijing, two months after troops and tanks crushed the democracy movement, is how normal life at first seems to be.

headline: Honeywell Net Has Big Gain
abstract: LEAD: Honeywell Inc., a maker of control systems for homes, industry and the military, said today that its second-quarter earnings more than doubled from last year's results.

headline: Hasbro's Purchase Of Coleco's Assets
abstract: LEAD: Hasbro Inc. said it had completed the purchase of most of the financially troubled Coleco Industries' product lines and would immediately begin producing popular Cabbage Patch Kids dolls. Hasbro, the nation's largest toy maker, agreed last week to buy Coleco's main assets for $85 million cash and an option for Coleco to purchase one million shares of Hasbro at $28.85 each after Coleco's bankruptcy reorganization plan was confirmed, said Barry Alperin,

headline: MEXICO AND BANKS NEARING AN ACCORD ON DEBT REDUCTION
abstract: LEAD: Negotiators for Mexico and the commercial banks that lend to it have tentatively agreed on important elements of a plan to reduce the burden of Mexico's foreign debt and are close to a final accord, bankers said yesterday.

headline: British Pet Food Deal
abstract: LEAD: Harrisons & Crosfield P.L.C., a food, commodities and chemicals company, said it would buy Edward Baker Holdings Ltd., a pet food manufacturer and flour miller, for about $:44 million. Edward Baker annually manufactures about 40,000 tons of dry and moist pet food.

headline: Trains Roll Into Armenia, Ending Blockade
abstract: LEAD: Freight trains began rolling into Armenia today, ending a monthlong blockade by the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan, according to official Soviet reports.

headline: Auto Dealer Drop Expected
abstract: LEAD: The number of automobile dealers may drop by more than half in the coming decade because the market is becoming increasingly competitive, a study by an automotive marketing concern, J. D. Power & Associates, predicted today.

headline: Software Reduces Radar False Alarms
abstract: LEAD: Systems engineers at the Hughes Aircraft Company have patented software for air traffic control systems that among other features cuts down on the number of false alarms from inaccurate radar data.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Sharing a Screen - Long Distance
abstract: LEAD: Ted has been in New York on business and his colleagues in Texas want to know how things are going. They can call or write or send a facsimile or electronic mail to him. But what they really need to be able to do is hold a conference with him, because the spontaneous exchange of information among executives is often the spark that leads to important decisions.

headline: Japanese Putting Off Sale Of Stock in Nippon Phone
abstract: LEAD: Japan today delayed a planned sale of shares in the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the giant telecommunications company that was involved in a bribery scandal that rocked the Government earlier this year.

headline: Cambodian Factions Cry Sham in Hanoi's Pullout
abstract: LEAD: A new diplomatic struggle is being waged here over Vietnam's announcement of the withdrawal of its occupation forces from Cambodia, with Cambodian opposition leaders trying to convince the nations of the world that the pullout is a sham.

headline: Price Waterhouse-Andersen Merger Blues
abstract: LEAD: With less than a month before the deadline for completing their proposed merger, Arthur Andersen and Price Waterhouse are still trying to iron out wrinkles in the plan to form the world's largest accounting firm, one with more than $5 billion in annual revenues.

headline: CBS Says Its Profit Fell 7.7% in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its net income fell 7.7 percent in the second quarter, reflecting higher programming costs and reduced advertising revenues from the National Basketball Association's championship series.

headline: G.E.C. and Siemens Win Battle for Plessey
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Company of Britain and Siemens A.G. of West Germany won their 10-month battle to acquire Plessey P.L.C. today, creating Europe's largest military and electronics company.

headline: Evaluating Time Warner: Court Papers Offer Glimpse
abstract: LEAD: Estimates of what Time Inc.'s core properties are worth and how Time Warner is expected to perform after the merger is completed were spelled out in court papers filed during Paramount Communications Inc.'s suit to block the merger.

headline: Buffett to Add To Coke Stake
abstract: LEAD: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire Omaha investor, said Monday that he planned to seek permission from Federal antitrust regulators to raise his stake in the Coca-Cola Company to 15 percent from 6.75 percent.

headline: Seoul Trade Talks Stall
abstract: LEAD: The United States has given South Korea five months to loosen barriers to American telecommunications imports or risk trade sanctions, Seoul officials said today.

headline: Bush as U.N.'s Host With the Most
