headline: Talking Business with Donohue of American Trucking; An Industry Plan To Curb Pollution
abstract: LEAD: The nation's $224 billion trucking industry is emerging from a decade of rapid change that began with its deregulation in 1980. Truck companies can now change schedules and prices more easily. Although parts of the industry have consolidated under deregulation, new companies have entered other sectors, including the transport of large shipments over long distances.

headline: The Beggars of Moscow Ask Not for Money but for Justice
abstract: LEAD: Street mendicants in the Soviet Union rise up swift as the agonized beggars of Bombay to plead a far more Kafkaesque need than money.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Limited Inc., Columbus, Ohio, the largest women's apparel store chain in the nation, is offering $100 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: Amway Halts Animal Tests
abstract: LEAD: The Amway Corporation has switched from animal tests to test tubes in its studies on new products but says it may use animals if ordered to do so by the Government.

headline: POLISH CHIEF QUITS PRESIDENTIAL RACE AS OPPOSITION RISES
abstract: LEAD: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's leader as Communist Party chief and President for eight years, announced today that he would not seek election to the powerful new presidency when Parliament convenes next weeek.

headline: Factionalism Hurts Afghan Rebels as Government Army Fails to Collapse
abstract: LEAD: Paradox seems to be the guiding principle of the 10-year-old war in Afghanistan. The Soviet Army lost in Afghanistan because it never learned to fight a guerrilla war. Now the rebels who beat them do not appear able to fight a conventional one.

headline: Real Estate; Coney Island Development Deal Gaining
abstract: LEAD: NEW YORK CITY and a private developer expect to sign a long-term lease agreement by fall that would initiate a $250 million redevelopment of a part of Coney Island, the Brooklyn oceanfront playground that has long been a symbol of summertime fun the world over.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Automotive Industries Inc., Boca Raton, Fla., named Orland Wolford, president and chief operating officer, to the additional position of chief executive. He replaces Ronald G. Farrell, who resigned as chairman and chief executive but will continue on the board.

headline: Air Quality Bonds For Ohio Power
abstract: LEAD: A $50 million bond refunding by the Ohio Air Quality Development Authority was tentatively priced yesterday, through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Your Money; Unwed Couples' Planning Needs
abstract: LEAD: When New York's highest court ruled last week that a gay couple who had been living together for a decade could be considered a family under New York City's rent control regulations, it cited an economic reality that many unmarried couples overlook: financial interdependence.

headline: Bush Says Curb on P.L.O. Tie Would Be a Step Backward
abstract: LEAD: President Bush expressed strong opposition today to Congressional moves to limit United States contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization, and the White House sought a compromise on the issue.

headline: A Change: Ideas Not Made in U.S.A.
abstract: LEAD: In a novel but perhaps inevitable departure, few of the Group of Seven's prescriptions for running the world economy were made in the U.S.A. The country that had dominated the economic summit conferences since their start 14 years ago found itself accepting its neighbors' proposals as readily as it has accepted their exports.

headline: Toshiba To Buiild Big TV's in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Toshiba Display Devices yesterday became the first television manufacturers to make ''super size'' television screens in the United States. Several other companies also have plans to make the large sets in American plants.

headline: Poland's Primate Denounces Jews In Dispute on Auschwitz Convent
abstract: LEAD: Asserting bitterly that national sovereignty and the ''feelings of all Poles'' are under attack, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate has accused Jews of fomenting anti-Polish feeling by objecting to a convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

headline: Market Place; The Advantages Of the 'DIFF'
abstract: LEAD: A NEW financial product introduced by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is steadily gaining a following. While it is too early to call the new product a success, financial professionals say it could move forward the effort to create a truly global financial market.

headline: Canada's Supreme Court Rejects Ex-Lover's Effort to Halt Abortion
abstract: LEAD: Ruling in a major test case, the Canadian Supreme Court yesterday unanimously rejected a man's attempt to prevent his former lover from having an abortion. Hours before the decision was announced, the woman's lawyer said she had had the abortion anyway.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Christian Dior Fashion and Accessories, to Grey Advertising, Paris, for its international advertising, with an undisclosed budget.

headline: Hungary Plans Arms Pullback Along 2 Borders
abstract: LEAD: The Hungarian Communist Party, demonstrating anew Hungary's independent spirit, has proposed forming a 60-mile zone partly free of offensive weapons along its borders with Austria and Yugoslavia, both neutral countries.

headline: Son Is Now 'Emperor Of Concrete' in France
abstract: LEAD: Martin Bouygues, the youngest son of France's ''Emperor of Concrete,'' has been handed control of Bouygues S.A., the empire built by his father, Francis. The younger Mr. Bouygues, who is 37 years old, likes to point out that he was born in the year the company was founded. He inherits a corporation that boasts that it has changed the face of the earth.

headline: The Bailout's Ripple Effect
abstract: LEAD: Washington's savings-and- loan bailout plan is intended to restore that industry to health. But in the process, the market for securities that are backed by home mortgages may suffer some ill effects of its own. The dramatic consolidation of savings institutions is causing a wave of selling of those securities.

headline: Merrill's Real Estate Units To Be Sold to Prudential
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch & Company and Fine Homes International Limited Partnership announced yesterday that they have agreed to sell Merrill Lynch Realty, Merrill Lynch Relocation Management, and some related businesses to the Prudential Insurance Company of America for more than $300 million.

headline: P.L.O. Seeks to Sign 4 U.N. Treaties on War
abstract: LEAD: In a bid for world support for its claim to represent a Palestinian state, the Palestine Liberation Organization is seeking to sign four United Nations treaties on the laws of war, diplomats say.

headline: Lilly Unit Lawsuits Settled by Abbott
abstract: LEAD: Abbott Laboratories said it had settled all litigation involving an Eli Lilly & Company subsidiary that had accused the pharmaceutical company of patent infringement. The settlement ends four separate legal actions pending in United States District Court in Los Angeles. Terms of the settlement with the unit, Hybritech Inc., based in San

headline: In Hungary, Communists Are Cheerful
abstract: LEAD: Hungary's Communists are following with understandable concern the troubles of the Polish Communist Party, which recently lost its hold on the Government after four decades of absolute control. But the Hungarians say they are not having nightmares about meeting the same fate.

headline: Making the Town Dump Sanitary
abstract: LEAD: Giant earth-moving machines growl across a hillside, gouging a huge gash in the ground. Along the bottom of the hole, other equipment is spreading and compacting a thick layer of clay. Later, layers of plastic sheeting will be added and a network of pipes installed, all to insure that no water seeps into the local water table.

headline: Boeing's Net Climbs 21.9%
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company said today that second-quarter profit had increased 21.9 percent, primarily because of higher sales and lower research and development costs.

headline: Senate Sustains Bush Veto Of Limits on Japan Jet Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Senate failed today by one vote to override President Bush's veto of Congressional restrictions on the joint American-Japanese production of an advanced jet fighter.

headline: Market Place; Impact on Banks Of Mexican Pact
abstract: LEAD: FOR American banks, whose stock prices have long suffered because of their heavy lending to Latin American countries, the Mexican debt accord of late July was a reminder that the troubled loans can be worked out without cataclysm, but not without sacrifice.

headline: Buyback Extended By Bell Atlantic
abstract: LEAD: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said its board had extended the company's stock repurchase program through Dec. 31, 1991, from Dec. 31, 1990, and increased the authorized amount from $450 million to $1 billion.

headline: British Group Finds Slavery Is Flourishing
abstract: LEAD: In a faded brick building in south London, a little-known organization that was established 150 years ago to abolish slavery is busier than ever at its task.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Ardent Computer Link To Stellar Is Disclosed
abstract: LEAD: In the face of slow sales and a keenly competitive market for the most powerful computer work stations, Ardent Computer Inc. and Stellar Computer Inc., will announce merger plans today, company executives said.

headline: New Clashes in Cambodia
abstract: LEAD: Fighting between rival Cambodian factions flared again along the Thai-Cambodian border, aid workers and Thai officials said today. Residents reported hearing heavy exchanges in the central sector of the frontier and foreign aid workers said there had been sporadic clashes over the past five days. The final round of peace talks on Cambodia is to open next week in Paris to try to hammer out an overall settlement before Vietnam withdraws its troops from the country by Sept.

headline: Durables Orders Jump 3.8%
abstract: LEAD: Durable goods orders jumped a surprising 3.8 percent in August for the best gain in eight months, the Commerce Department said today, but fresh signs of weakness in the industrial sector crept into the monthly report.

headline: U.P.S. Plans to Widen Its Deliveries Abroad
abstract: LEAD: In a move to meet the challenge of the recently completed merger of the Federal Express Corporation and Tiger International, United Parcel Service of America Inc. said yesterday that it would expand its package delivery service to 175 countries and territories, starting Monday.

headline: Iran Presses Mitsui Claim
abstract: LEAD: Iran is demanding $1.5 billion in compensation from the Mitsui conglomerate of Japan for its abandonment of a petrochemical plant in southern Iran, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported on Friday.

headline: Layoffs at Jeep Plant
abstract: LEAD: About 300 Jeep workers will be temporarily laid off here when the Chrysler Corporation suspends production of the Grand Wagoneer's 1990 model for two weeks in September and two weeks in October because of slow sales. The sales of the 1989 Grand Wagoneer are off 15 percent from a year ago, and Jeep dealers still have a three-month supply of the vehicle in stock, said a Chrysler spokesman.

headline: U.S. Seeks Curbs on Biological Weapons
abstract: LEAD: A top State Department official said today that it would be impractical to curb biological weapons through a system of international export controls, even though their spread is a serious threat to American security.

headline: BRITISH TRADE DEFICIT GREW SHARPLY IN JULY
abstract: LEAD: Britain's balance-of-payments deficit in July deepened to $:2.06 billion, or about $3.25 billion, its second worst monthly figure ever, the Government said today.

headline: F.D.A. May Withdraw Another Drug Approval
abstract: LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration today proposed withdrawing approval of one of the best-selling generic drugs because the agency found irregularities in earlier tests of the compound.

headline: West German Economy Continues to Strengthen
abstract: LEAD: West Germany's economy turned in the strongest performance in 13 years in the first half, as the gross national product expanded by 4.6 percent from the level a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

headline: IRAN'S PRESIDENT OFFERS U.S. HELP IN HOSTAGE CRISIS
abstract: LEAD: Iran's new President, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, offered today to help end the hostage crisis in Lebanon, a move that President Bush said would be explored ''to the fullest.''

headline: New Jerrico Owners Move Fast on Deals
abstract: LEAD: There is no time to waver when it is time to make a deal, Leonard M. Harlan said. So he and his partner, John K. Castle, spent nearly 72 hours last weekend hammering out an offer for Jerrico Inc., the parent company of Long John Silver's Seafood Shoppes.

headline: Before His Abduction, Higgins Talked of Risks
abstract: LEAD: Two weeks before Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins was kidnapped, he told a Norwegian television correspondent traveling with him of the dangers that members of the United Nations observer force faced in Lebanon.

headline: LANDS' END DRIFTS INTO DOLDRUMS Special to The New York Times
abstract: LEAD: Beset by big cost increases for its cotton shirts, wool sweaters and other natural-fiber clothing, the catalogue merchant Lands' End Inc. today reported a big drop in second-quarter earnings that sent its stock price skidding.

headline: Devaluation In Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: The Government announced today that it was devaluing its currency for the 21st time this year. The cordoba's new value will be 20,600 per dollar after the 3 percent devaluation. In announcing the move, Vice

headline: Citicorp's Hong Kong Deal Called Vote of Confidence
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp, the largest banking company in the United States, yesterday gave Hong Kong one of the strongest votes of confidence it has received since the upheaval in China in June shook its markets.

headline: Soviet Business Consultants Sharpen Hammer and Sickle
abstract: LEAD: He is 31 years old, he drives a pricey imported car, his tastes in clothing run to European-cut suits and yellow ''power'' ties, and his notion of a fringe benefit is paying tennis-court fees for his staff. Aleksandr I. Rubtsov is the Soviet equivalent of a young urban professional, a private management consultant in a country where the very concept of such a job would until recently have been alien.

headline: U.S. Seeks Information On UAL Buyout Plans
abstract: LEAD: The Transportation Department, expressing concern about the role of foreign companies in the acquisitions of United States airlines, said yesterday that it had asked United Airlines for information about a proposed $6.75 billion buyout of its parent, the UAL Corporation, by management, employees and British

headline: A MONEY MANAGER IS IN THE MONEY
abstract: LEAD: In 1987, when the Aid Association for Lutherans, a 92-year-old fraternal organization, began searching for a professional money manager to invest $384 million in savings, representatives of the big names in money management rushed to its doorstep.

headline: Rival Lebanese Legislators to Meet in Saudi Arabia
abstract: LEAD: Despite a serious violation of Lebanon's four-day-old truce, Christian and Muslim members of Parliament agreed today to meet in Saudi Arabia on Saturday to discuss a charter for national reconciliation.

headline: Japan's Uno Reeling From One Crisis to Another
abstract: LEAD: After a debilitating year of scandals, Prime Minister Sousuke Uno and his associates knew that they faced an uphill struggle this summer in trying to salvage the reputation of the governing Liberal Democratic Party in the eyes of a sullen electorate.

headline: 3 Airlines Weigh Merging Ticket Systems
abstract: LEAD: Delta, Northwest and Trans World Airlines are considering merging their computer reservation systems, executives at the three airlines said yesterday.

headline: Air New Zealand Plan
abstract: LEAD: Air New Zealand plans to sell or lease its new Boeing 747-400 without ever using it after failing to reach a deal with pilots to fly the aircraft, the carrier's chairman, Bob Matthew, said today. The plane is scheduled to leave Boeing's Seattle plant in the next few weeks and Air New Zealand had planned to put it into service later this year.

headline: Debt
abstract: LEAD: * Federal-Mogul Corp., an auto parts manufacturer, announced the completion of a $150 million revolving credit facility with 10 domestic and foreign banks.

headline: F.B.I. Seizes TV Decoders
abstract: LEAD: F.B.I. agents say they raided two electronics companies and confiscated up to 18,000 illegal devices for unscrambling pay television signals.

headline: Economic Scene; The Opportunity For Lasting Peace
abstract: LEAD: ALL the items on the United States foreign policy agenda are heavily affected by economic factors.

headline: Muslims Hit Tanker Near Beirut, Killing at Least 7 Crew Members
abstract: LEAD: An oil tanker bound for a Christian port north of Beirut was set on fire today by shelling from Syrian and Lebanese Muslim positions, the Lebanese police said.

headline: Brierley Chief Plans to Retire
abstract: LEAD: Sir Ron Brierley, a New Zealand corporate raider, is to retire as chief of the investment company he founded 28 years ago.

headline: PRETORIA OFFICER TELLS OF ABUSES
abstract: LEAD: A South African police lieutenant has sacrificed a rising career by coming forward with an account of riot policemen running amok in a mixed-race township outside Cape Town on Tuesday, the day before the whites-only parliamentary elections.

headline: Liquidation Set For Financier
abstract: LEAD: The estate of the Ohio financier Marvin Warner must be liquidated to settle $4.5 billion in claims against him, a Federal bankruptcy judge ruled on Friday.

headline: Strong Gains For Retailers In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Buoyed by strong sales in the last two months, the J. C. Penney Company, the nation's fourth-largest retailer, posted an increase in net income of 21 percent in its second quarter, while the Dayton Hudson Corporation doubled its profits.

headline: A DEMOCRAT LIKELY AS ARMS DELEGATE
abstract: LEAD: A conservative Democrat who has long been a confidant of Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, has been tentatively selected as the new American negotiator in talks to reduce conventional armed forces in Europe, Administration officials said today.

abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   11.00   11.00   9.00        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   6.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   9.79   9.69   7.63        3-MO. headline: Top Officer Appointed For Call Interactive
abstract: LEAD: The American Express Information Services Company yesterday named J. Michael Parks president and chief executive of Call Interactive, a new telephone marketing concern that is a joint venture of the American Express Company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: Cashing In on Rising Health Care Costs
abstract: LEAD: Despite the best efforts of insurers and the Federal Government, health care costs continue to rise faster than the gross national product. That is bad news for the parties paying the bill, but good news for emerging growth companies in the field of medical technology that develop high-tech solutions for use in medical imaging, disease diagnosis and drug delivery.

headline: Burmese Dissident Is Reportedly on a Fast
abstract: LEAD: The Burmese opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, has been on a hunger strike, taking only water, since she was put under house arrest on July 20, residents of the capital of Myanmar, formerly Burma, said today.

headline: Dow Rises To 2,712.63, Up 26.55
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average traded above its record high yesterday afternoon before settling back to close at 2,712.63. That was its second-highest close, following the 2,722.42 it reached on Aug. 25, 1987.

headline: Despite Crackdown, Sex Still Sells the Soap in Beijing
abstract: LEAD: This is one of the Communist Party's latest weapons against counterrevolutionaries:

headline: Sale of a Del Monte Unit To Investors Agreed On
abstract: LEAD: RJR Nabisco said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the processed food unit of its Del Monte subsidiary for $1.475 billion to an investor group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

headline: Pilot Accord At Northwest
abstract: LEAD: Northwest Airlines has reached tentative agreement on a long-term contract covering its 5,000 pilots, it was announced today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: In a Day of Wild Swings, Dow Drops 19.54
abstract: LEAD: The stock market staged one of its wildest performances in weeks yesterday.

headline: Northwest Air to Buy Up to 30 Airbus Jets
abstract: LEAD: Northwest Airlines said today that it had agreed to buy up to 30 more jetliners from Airbus Industrie in a deal valued at $2.7 billion.

headline: P.L.O. Reaffirms Right To Fight Against Israel
abstract: LEAD: The main P.L.O. group, Al Fatah, issued a new statement today reaffirming the principle of armed struggle against Israel but dropping some of the anti-Israel invective criticized by Israel and the United States.

headline: El Diario Sold by Gannett To Group Led by Publisher
abstract: LEAD: A partnership led by the publisher of El Diario/La Prensa acquired the newspaper yesterday from the Gannett Company, the parties said yesterday.

headline: Black Papers Retain a Local Role
abstract: LEAD: As the editor and publisher of a newspaper that claims to be the oldest American daily aimed at a black audience, C. A. Scott has often exhibited a contrary attitude about politics.

headline: Young Pros, Aiding Those Starting Out
abstract: LEAD: WHERE does a new junior media planner, one of the multitude starting their professional lives today on Madison Avenue, turn for help if she can't tell the difference between BBDO and TBWA? The Young Professionals may be the answer.

headline: Bermuda Spared Worst of Major Hurricane
abstract: LEAD: A hurricane swept past Bermuda today with torrential rain and winds up to 100 miles per hour, knocking out power on much of the Atlantic island but sparing it from the brunt of its force.

headline: '87 NatWest Role Assailed
abstract: LEAD: A Government agency has accused a subsidiary of Britain's largest bank of misleading the London stock market during a 1987 takeover that created the world's biggest employment agency.

headline: Local Business Weeklies Seek a New Direction
abstract: LEAD: Two years ago, Michael K. Russell, then the chairman of American City Business Journals Inc., told employees of The St. Louis Business Journal that he would never sell his controlling interest in the company for less than $80 a share.

headline: Austrian Woman Sought as Witness in Spy Case
abstract: LEAD: Lacking the evidence to bring espionage charges against an American diplomat being investigated for ''illegal activities,'' the Government has asked Austria to try to locate a woman who may become a witness in the case, Administration officials said today.

headline: Kidder Fills Equity Post
abstract: LEAD: Thomas S. Shattan, who arranged private equity financings for emerging growth companies at Goldman, Sachs & Company, has been hired by Kidder, Peabody & Company to build a new department there to do the same.

headline: About Real Estate; A Luxury Condo Project Is Going Up in Flushing
abstract: LEAD: The Hillcrest section of Flushing, Queens, has experienced a rise in construction in recent years, as underused parcels as well as empty land have been developed as residential or commercial property.

headline: 15 Killed as Oil Tanker Hits Trawler in Baltic
abstract: LEAD: All 15 crew members of a Soviet fishing trawler were killed when an oil tanker trying to avoid another boat veered into the trawler, sinking it in the Baltic, officials said.

headline: The Sleeper of Securities Firms
abstract: LEAD: Not long ago, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. was ridiculed as the ''stocks and socks'' brokerage owned by Sears, Roebuck & Company. But now the tables have turned.

headline: Colombian Policemen and Soldiers Are Reportedly Tipping Off Drug Figures
abstract: LEAD: Three weeks after President Virgilio Barco Vargas declared all-out war on Colombia's narcotics traffickers, many leading drug figures are believed to have escaped to vast areas of the country under their control after being tipped off by corrupt Colombian police officers and soldiers, Colombian and United

headline: Budapest Says It Will Keep Frontier to the West Open
abstract: LEAD: Hungary will keep its border to the West open indefinitely after the migration of East Germans this week, Prime Minister Miklos Nemeth said in a commentary written for a West German newspaper and made public today.

headline: Hungarian Accuses Rumania of Military Threats
abstract: LEAD: The Hungarian Foreign Minister said today that Rumania was posing ''military threats'' to Hungary.

headline: BEHIND UNION'S REBUFF TO THE PILOTS AT EASTERN
abstract: LEAD: In refusing to allow pilots honoring a strike at Eastern Airlines to transfer their seniority to other airlines, the Air Line Pilots Association is holding fast to a rule that protects the interests of most of its members.

headline: Another Contender For Top Job at Grace
abstract: LEAD: When W. R. Grace & Company named three vice chairmen three years ago, establishing a group of candidates to succeed J. Peter Grace, no one knew how long Mr. Grace would remain chairman.

headline: China Expels Correspondent for Voice of America
abstract: LEAD: China today ordered the expulsion of a correspondent for the Voice of America radio network, asserting that his reporting had violated provisions of martial law.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 10, 1989:  MONDAY  Central Vt Pub Svc Corp  P S Group Inc  Pacific Gas & Elec Co  Phillips Pete Co  Pitney Bowes Inc  Southwestern Energy Co  Xerox Corp  TUESDAY  Cummins Engine Inc  Divers Energies Inc Minn  Hillenbrand Inds Inc  Household Intl Inc  Proctor & Gamble Co  Weis Mkts Inc  Weyerhaeuser Co

headline: Workers Who Turn In Bosses Use Law to Seek Big Rewards
abstract: LEAD: When the Justice Department last month settled charges that a military contractor had overcharged the Air Force and the Navy for ball bearings, there were two winners.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Western Corp., Sioux Falls, S.D., a maker of plastic bags, is discussing a $64.4 million leveraged buyout with a management group.

headline: Government Rests Its Case Against Princeton/Newport
abstract: LEAD: The Government rested its case yesterday in the first Federal racketeering trial to result from the investigation of crime on Wall Street.

headline: 13 at a Sri Lankan Festival Are Killed in Grenade Attack
abstract: LEAD: Attackers threw grenades into a crowd of Sinhalese and Tamil worshipers at a ceremony meant to promote peace between ethnic groups, killing 13 people and wounding 85, the authorities said.

headline: Lilco to Pay Shareholders
abstract: LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it would pay $390 million owed to its preferred shareholders and resume paying quarterly dividends on its preferred stock.

headline: 5 Arabs Die in Occupied Regions
abstract: LEAD: Five Palestinians died today after clashes in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, and the army disclosed tonight that an armed Palestinian was shot dead by troops near Hebron last week.

headline: Savimbi Is to Urge U.S. To Join Talks on Angola
abstract: LEAD: The Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi, who is to visit Washington next week, intends to ask the Bush Administration to mediate an end to Angola's 14-year civil war.

headline: Campeau Halts Dividends
abstract: LEAD: The Campeau Corporation's board said yesterday that it would not pay dividends scheduled to be paid tomorrow on the company's series B preference shares, series C preference shares, series D preference shares and convertible subordinate shares.

headline: DOW CLIMBS BY 25.42 ON RATE HOPES
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices shot up yesterday as anticipation of lower interest rates grew.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Adage Inc., Billerica, Mass., a computer graphics company, said General Business Investment Corp., had called off a merger in which General Business would have owned 58 percent of the combined company.

headline: MAI Basic Cites Gains in Prime Bid
abstract: LEAD: MAI Basic Four Inc. issued a statement today intended to show why its offer Thursday of $450 million in cash and $150 million in debentures for the minicomputer business of Prime Computer Inc. would be a better deal for Prime's shareholders than the existing offer from J.H. Whitney & Company. Whitney has begun a tender offer for up to 49.5 million shares at $21.50 in cash.

headline: Third Big Coup For an Executive
abstract: LEAD: The agreement on Thursday for an employee-led buyout of United Airlines is the third major coup in less than four years for its chairman and president, Stephen M. Wolf.

headline: Talks on Bailout Hit a Snag
abstract: LEAD: House and Senate conferees failed today in their first attempt to agree on which special-interest amendments should be eliminated from the House and Senate passed versions of the Bush Administration's bailout bill for the savings and loan industry.

headline: Rally in Treasury Issues Continues
abstract: LEAD: The credit market rally continued yesterday as dealers further bid up the prices of Treasury notes and bonds. But the gains, which amounted to as much as 7/8 point on some securities, were recorded on light volume.

headline: Uganda Opens Wildlife Parks
abstract: LEAD: Uganda has created three national parks to protect wildlife and promote the tourist industry it is reviving after 18 years of neglect. A spokesman for the Ministry of Tourism and Wildlife said today that the parks had been set up in the Ruwenzori mountains (the Mountains of the Moon) bordering Zaire, in the Bwindi forest in Kigezi district in the southwest, and in the Muhavura mountains bordering Rwanda and Zaire.

headline: Pan Am Security Found Lax
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration said Pan American World Airways violated security rules before the flight that was bombed over Scotland in December. Page A10.

headline: McDonnell in Deal
abstract: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said two Spanish airlines had converted a total of 12 options on MD-80 aircraft into firm orders. Iberia S.A., Spain's national airline, which holds 24 options on MD-80's, converted seven of them into orders for MD-87's. Aviacion y Comercio S.A., the national domestic airline, converted five MD-80 options to orders for MD-88's.

headline: Challenging Airfone's Monopoly
abstract: LEAD: Twenty years after forming a company that helped break up the Bell telephone system, once the world's largest monopoly, John D. Goeken is seeking to crack another telephone monopoly, the GTE Corporation's service that allows airline passengers to make calls during flights.

headline: Imports Lead Mileage Lists
abstract: LEAD: Imported cars again dominated the best-mileage and worst-mileage lists in an annual survey by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Marriott on G.M. Board
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had elected J. W. Marriott Jr. as its 13th outside director. Four board seats are held by corporate officers. Mr. Marriott is chairman of the board and chief executive of the Marriott Corporation, the hotel company based in Washington.

headline: Excerpts From Remarks by Iranian and Bush
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from remarks today by President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran and President Bush on the issue of hostages in Lebanon. The Iranian leader's statement, in a sermon in Teheran, was translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a Federal agency. Mr. Bush's remarks, in answer to questions from reporters at a White House photo session, were transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: Japan Group Gets 51% of Park Inns
abstract: LEAD: The EIE International Corporation, a Tokyo-based conglomerate that is financing the construction of a Regent hotel on 57th Street in Manhattan, purchased 51 percent of Park Inns International Inc., a hotel franchise and management company, for an undisclosed amount. Park Inns, which is based in Irving, Tex., owns and operates a national chain of 70 full-service, largely mid-price hotels and has 30 more under construction.

headline: KREMLIN DEPUTIES BASK IN NEW ROLE
abstract: LEAD: Tired, exhilarated and rather proud of themselves, the deputies of the Supreme Soviet checked out of their hotels and went home today, having given birth to a new branch of government.

headline: Local News Is Challenging Prime-Time Shows
abstract: LEAD: In the battle for television ratings, entertainment shows are facing a growing rival: local news.

headline: Campbell Reports Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company said today that it had lost $194.7 million in the quarter ended July 31, because of a worldwide restructuring.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: Because of a production error, a table last week accompanying an article about L.A. Gear Inc. was incorrect. The correct table appears below.  AT A GLANCE: L.A. Gear  All dollar amounts in thousands, except per share data. headline: Lebanon's Truce Holds; Ports Active
abstract: LEAD: This city's air and sea ports resumed normal activity today after agreement by Lebanon's warring factions to an Arab-negotiated peace plan.

headline: Market Place; The Dark Cloud Over Exxon
abstract: LEAD: DESPITE the fairly positive outlook that many analysts have for the oil and refining business over the next year, they continue to be nervous about the Exxon Corporation's prospects.

headline: Bloch Goes Home to Washington And Has a Chat With an Austrian
abstract: LEAD: Felix S. Bloch, the State Department diplomat under investigation for espionage, returned to his Washington home from New York today trailed by Federal agents and reporters, and chatted for 45 minutes with a correspondent for Austria's state-financed television service.

headline: As Trading and Con Games Increase, So Does 'Slabbing'
abstract: LEAD: A small California company is transforming the rare coins trade. Formed three years ago, Professional Coin Grading Service Inc. in Newport Beach has developed a system for grading high-quality coins that has since become the industry standard. While other companies offer grading services, none have matched Professional Coin's acceptance among dealers.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * C. R. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., a maker of surgical products, acquired Catheter Technology Corp., Salt Lake City, a maker of vascular access devices, and Radi Medical Systems A.B., Uppsala, Sweden, a maker of needles and other devices for taking biopsy samples. Bard said the two purchases came to about $60 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jordan Gets A Hasbro Job
abstract: LEAD: After a three-month search, Hasbro Inc. assigned the advertising for its girls' toys and Milton Bradley divisions to Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor.

headline: C.F.T.C. Official Quits To Go Into Consulting
abstract: LEAD: After five years as executive director of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Molly G. Bayley is resigning to open a consulting practice.

headline: Continental Cuts Fares
abstract: LEAD: Continental Airlines today announced $76 one-way fares on United States flights for three days after the Fourth of July holiday. United Airlines said it would match the offer.

headline: Sandinistas Suspend Army Draft Until After Election
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced today that his Government would suspend the conscription of new military recruits until national elections are held in February.

headline: A Struggling Wang Revamps Operations
abstract: LEAD: An Wang, the 69-year-old founder of Wang Laboratories Inc., at home recovering from cancer surgery two weeks ago, is already taking an active role in directing his company's business. It looks like the Lowell, Mass., computer maker will need all of its founder's many talents.

headline: WALESA CRITICIZES COMMUNIST DEMAND
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, today criticized Communist demands for more power in Poland's new coalition Government and warned that the party would have no political future if it chose a path of ''threats and blackmail.''

headline: New Staff at Stagebill
abstract: LEAD: Less than two weeks after completing its purchase of Stagebill magazine from B&B Enterprises in Chicago, Levitt Communications has begun building the staff by hiring several executives from Working Mother magazine. Carol Evans, 36, Working Mother's publisher, will assume the same title at Stagebill, and Sandra A.

headline: Bank Set To Manage Bond Sale
abstract: LEAD: Making quick use of new powers granted by the Federal Reserve Board, the Bankers Trust Company announced plans yesterday to handle the sale of a new issue of ''junk bonds,'' thus becoming the first banking company to manage a public sale of corporate bonds.

headline: Keye/Donna Creative Chief
abstract: LEAD: Keye/Donna/Pearlstein announced Friday that its chairman, Paul F. Keye, would relinquish his title of creative director on Oct. 1 to Marcus Kemp, who is joining the Los Angeles agency from Ammirati & Puris in New York.

headline: Pan Am to Add Florida Flights
abstract: LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation said it would increase its service to Florida by nearly 50 percent next month. The expansion, announced as Miami-based Eastern Airlines, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, entered the seventh month of reduced service because of a strike, will increase the average number of daily Pan Am flights to

headline: Household Finance Issue
abstract: LEAD: A $100 million issue of senior subordinated notes due in 2001 for the Household Finance Corporation was priced yesterday through competitive bidding. Underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company made the winning bid on the issue and reoffered the notes to investors with a 9 percent coupon at a price of 99.275, to yield 9.101 percent.

headline: Denmark to Salvage Plane
abstract: LEAD: Aviation authorities prepared an underwater salvage operation today to hoist a Norwegian charter plane that crashed off Denmark's west coast, killing all 55 people aboard. Experts said metal fatigue in the aircraft was a likely cause of the crash.

headline: I.C.H. Not Sure Concern Is for Sale
abstract: LEAD: The I.C.H. Corporation, the Louisville, Ky., insurance holding company that received a leveraged buyout offer Thursday from a Dallas investment firm, said today that its board had not determined whether the company was for sale.

headline: AMR Stock Up $1.50
abstract: LEAD: Shares of the AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, continued to move up amid speculation that there may be a bid for the company. AMR climbed $1.50 a share yesterday, to $93, on the New York Stock Exchange. On Tuesday, the stock jumped $10.25. But analysts said that there was no evidence that a bid was forthcoming.

headline: Madrid Journal; Church Loses Its Thunder to the Good Life's Roar
abstract: LEAD: Bishop Ramon Buxarrais of Malaga waited for the summer fever to sweep Spain's beach resorts before he issued his annual lamentation about the ostentatious, decadent and immoral behavior of the country's hard-driving jet-setters.

headline: Turkic Republics Press Soviets to Loosen Reins
abstract: LEAD: While world attention is focused on the Baltic Republics' steady independence march, a strange thing is happening along President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's southern flank.

headline: New Capital Gains Tax Plan Aimed at Assets Bought in '90
abstract: LEAD: Continuing his search for a compromise on the capital gains tax issue, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Dan Rostenkowski, today outlined to colleagues a proposal that would index for inflation assets acquired after Dec. 31.

headline: London Journal; For Asia's Children, Hard Knocks in an Alien Land
abstract: LEAD: When the schools of London opened this month amid a national teacher shortage, the worst crisis affected the poorest areas of East London, where the faces of the students are brown and Asian. Most are from families that have immigrated from Bangladesh.

headline: Cherry Output Up a Bit
abstract: LEAD: Cherry production, which was severely affected by heat and drought last year, is making a bit of a comeback this year but is still behind 1987 levels, the Agriculture Department said. Production of tart cherries is expected to rise by 10 percent, to 260.7 million pounds, from last year's levels. The 1987 harvest totaled 358.5 million pounds.

headline: Five-Year Notes From Philip Morris
abstract: LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday offered $300 million worth of five-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: LVMH Warrants
abstract: LEAD: A Paris commercial court today rejected a claim by small shareholders in LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods group, that warrants owned by the group's chairman, Bernard Arnault, were not valid. The court ruled that there was no ground to say that the warrants, crucial to Mr. Arnault's 35 percent voting power in the company, had been issued and placed illegally.

headline: Market Place; UAL Is Called Attractive Target
abstract: LEAD: SOME airline analysts think the UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Air Lines, has become a prime takeover target, for a price far higher than the current value of its stock.

headline: Students' Foreign Aid Is Criticized by Beijing
abstract: LEAD: China accused foreign countries today of giving money and passports to leaders of the student democracy movement, whom it called ''a gang of political hooligans.''

headline: New Jewish Group Formed for Interfaith Ties
abstract: LEAD: Three major American Jewish organizations have formed a new group to represent them in international discussions with the Vatican and other Christian bodies. The action reflects divergent approaches by Jewish groups to interreligious dialogue and to issues like the dispute over a Roman Catholic convent at Auschwitz.

headline: Bolivia Installs an Ex-Revolutionary as President
abstract: LEAD: Jaime Paz Zamora, who has known exile and prison, was inaugurated as Bolivia's President today with an admonition from his predecessor not to upset the country's delicate economic stability.

headline: Taiwan Weighs Labor Imports
abstract: LEAD: Taiwan may admit up to 6,000 workers from abroad next year to help build important Government projects stalled by a severe labor shortage, a senior official said on Friday.

headline: Chrysler in Europe
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation, the No. 3 United States car maker, expects to ship about 50,000 vehicles to Europe this year and could double the figure within two years, its chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, said. Chrysler sold 31,000 vehicles in Europe last year, its first full year of sales, and revenues from Europe have already passed $1 billion, he told reporters attending the Frankfurt Auto Show.

headline: Huge Azerbaijani Rally Asks Moscow to Free Prisoners
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in Azerbaijan today to demand that the Communist authorities free jailed members of an independent group and accept its political demands.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Newspaper Ad Bureau Cuts Growth Estimate
abstract: LEAD: Citing less optimistic expectations for the economy, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau on Friday reduced its already tepid projections for newspaper advertising spending in 1989. The bureau predicted spending would increase 5 percent, instead of the 6 percent it predicted in January.

headline: Plane Carrying 22 Is Missing Over the Jungles of Indonesia
abstract: LEAD: A plane carrying 22 people disappeared over the jungles of the eastern Indonesian province of Irian Jaya, the official Antara news agency reported today.

headline: Mexico and Japan Expected To Solidify Economic Ties
abstract: LEAD: Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu arrived here today on a three-day official visit that is expected to solidify a diversifying and rapidly growing economic relationship whose importance to Mexico is exceeded only by Mexico's ties to the United States.

headline: Kaprielian Acquired
abstract: LEAD: Kaprielian O'Leary Advertising, a tiny New York agency whose clients include the Cayman Islands Department of Tourism, has been acquired by the Gegenheimer Group, a New York company whose other agency holding is Hyers/Smith in South Norwalk, Conn.

headline: Two Sides in Warsaw Seem Near Cabinet Pact
abstract: LEAD: Solidarity and the Communist Party appear to be nearing agreement on a new Cabinet whose makeup would satisfy both Communist demands for additional power and Solidarity's requirement that the party come to terms with a reduced role.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Architectural Record to HDM New York, with a budget of $500,000.

headline: Treasuries Continue to Creep Up
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds crept higher again yesterday, helped by fresh signs of softness in the economy and an indication that the Federal Reserve may be in the process of easing credit conditions further.

headline: British Stocks Up; Tokyo Prices Are Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Share prices on the London Stock Exchange rose in dull trading today as the July 4 holiday in the United States cut sharply into trading.

headline: Airlines Reduce Fall Ticket Prices
abstract: LEAD: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it would offer lower prices on heavily restricted tickets bought before Sept. 1. Other airlines quickly matched the fares.

headline: Bush Plan Would Aid Computing
abstract: LEAD: President Bush's science adviser will present to Congress today a plan by which the United States would almost double over five years its spending on advanced computing research technologies to develop dramatically faster supercomputers and more powerful software. The plan also calls for the construction of a high-speed computer network that would link the nation's research centers.

headline: New Singer Chairman Is a Railroad Retiree
abstract: LEAD: Walter A. Drexel, who was named chairman of the Singer Company on Friday, is a former railroad and oil executive who is coming out of retirement to try to help calm the troubled waters at the military contractor.

headline: Real Estate; More Leasing Of Midsized Office Space
abstract: LEAD: DESPITE a stagnant office market that has kept vacancy rates in Manhattan at the 12 to 13 percent level for more than a year now, brokerage companies report an encouraging increase in the number of leases that have been signed by midsized tenants for the first half of this year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; CBS Plans Package Deal For Olympics
abstract: LEAD: HAVING purchased the broadcast rights for the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympics, CBS plans to approach prospective advertisers this fall with ideas for long-range marketing promotions and with offers of package deals to buy commercial time for both events at once.

headline: Chairman of Latchford To Lead Vitro in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Clifford L. Jones has an unusual place in a fairly unusual deal. He is the chairman and chief executive of the Latchford Glass Company, a glass container manufacturer in Huntington Park, Calif., and is also the point man in a Mexican company's attempt to build a strong presence in the American packaging and container businesses.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Akzo N.V., Sassenheim, the Netherlands, a chemical company, completed the acquisition of Reliance Universal Inc., Louisville, Ky., a coatings concern, from Tyler Corp., Dallas, for $275 million.

headline: Savings-Unit Agency Plans 5 More Sales
abstract: LEAD: The agency created to liquidate and sell off hundreds of ailing savings and loan institutions announced today that it was putting up for sale five institutions with $10.8 billion in total assets. But officials said it may be as long as two months before any final deals will be struck.

headline: Court Date Set for Lawyer
abstract: LEAD: A lawyer who admitted that she mistakenly gave confidential court documents to a reporter for The New York Times during the Time Inc. takeover fight has been ordered to appear before the Delaware Supreme Court.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Patricia Stewart and Alan Saperstein have been named executive vice presidents of Campbell-Mithun-Esty/ New York.

headline: RUMORS FLY ON BUNDESBANK RATES
abstract: LEAD: The Bundesbank's policy makers returned from a monthlong recess today to a familiar refrain in the foreign exchange market: speculation that the West German central bank will raise interest rates to bolster the value of the mark and rein in inflationary pressures.

headline: Buddhist-Muslim Feud Divides an Indian Territory
abstract: LEAD: A mass campaign of civil disobedience in the once-peaceable mountain valleys of Ladakh has brought India's traditionally nonviolent Buddhist minority to the edge of revolt.

headline: HUNGARY ALLOWS 7,000 EAST GERMANS TO EMIGRATE WEST
abstract: LEAD: Hungary announced today that it is allowing thousands of East Germans who have refused to return home to leave for West Germany. It was another chapter, and a dramatic one, in a summerlong exodus through the new Hungarian gap in the Communist frontier.

headline: Producer Prices Fell Last Month
abstract: LEAD: Prices fell at all stages of production in June, the first month this has happened in more than three years, the Labor Department reported today.

headline: Afghan Rebel Faction Issues Warning on Killings
abstract: LEAD: A leading Afghan guerrilla group warned today that the killing of 30 of its fighters by a rival faction would have ''far-reaching consequences'' in the fight against the Soviet-supported Afghan Government.

headline: Natural Gas Bill Is Passed
abstract: LEAD: The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill to end Federal price controls on natural gas by Jan. 1, 1993.

headline: Home Resale Rise Posted
abstract: LEAD: Sales of existing homes rose 1.2 percent in July, posting the first back-to-back increase after high mortgage rates produced consecutive declines in the first five months of 1989, a real estate trade group said today.

headline: '88 Farm Costs Up 7.5%
abstract: LEAD: The cost of running the nation's farms rose 7.5 percent, to $118.4 billion, in 1988, the Agriculture Department reported today. Despite the increase, the figure falls short of the record $131.8 billion that farmers spent in 1981, before the general financial crunch that stalled expansion in the agricultural sector.

headline: On China's Bustling Coast, Profit Outpaces Politics
abstract: LEAD: The young money-changer beamed at the sight of a foreigner on the street of this bustling trading center, and excitedly quoted his black-market exchange rates for United States dollars and Taiwan dollars.

headline: A SPRAY OF SPARKS ERUPTS TO MUSIC - WITH THE AID OF ELECTRONICS
abstract: LEAD: New technologies are taking some of the quesswork out of fireworks exhibition, making displays fancier and more dramatic. Rather than setting off aerial shells haphazardly during the shows, some exhibiters are now using computers to map out the programs beforehand and to set the affair to music - making sure that the chrysanthemums blossom in the sky at the crescendo.

headline: HARVARD'S SHREWD 'BLUNDER'
abstract: LEAD: This is a story about how to sell less and earn more. It is brought to you by the folks at the Harvard Business School.

headline: Wells Fargo Buys Central Pacific
abstract: LEAD: Wells Fargo & Company agreed to purchase the Central Pacific Corporation of Bakersfield, Calif., and its American National Bank subsidiary for $160 million, or $28.50 a share. Shareholders of Central Pacific will have the option of receiving either cash or Wells Fargo common stock for their shares.

headline: Fashion Industry Executives Find Situation Exasperating
abstract: LEAD: From the beginning, Robert Campeau's high-wire retailing ambitions aroused deep concern in the fashion industry. As his retail giant came crashing down to earth this week and Mr. Campeau was forced to step down as chief executive of the company, fashion industry executives found the situation exasperating but not at all surprising.

headline: Two Banks Set Merger In Japan
abstract: LEAD: Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank said today that they had agreed to merge next year, creating the second-largest bank in the world.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   10.50   10.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   6.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   9.00   9.00   8.25        3-MO. headline: Rights Groups Fault General for Haiti Abuses
abstract: LEAD: In a review of Haiti's political situation after one year of rule by Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, two United States-based human-rights groups have criticized the Haitian Government for failing to stop widespread political violence and for slow progress toward promised democratic elections.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief Named at Farah As a Retirement Is Set
abstract: LEAD: Richard C. Allender has been named the president and chief executive of Farah Inc., replacing William F. Farah, who said on Monday that he would retire from the positions.

headline: Pulitzer to Sell Station
abstract: LEAD: The Pulitzer Publishing Company said today that it had agreed to sell its television station in Fort Wayne, Ind., to the Granite Broadcasting Corporation. The station, WPTA-TV, is an ABC affiliate. The sale price is $26.5 million in cash. Granite, a private company, owns NBC-affiliated television stations in Duluth, Minn., and Peoria, Ill.

headline: Soviets to Buy Butter
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union last week agreed to buy more than 110 million pounds of surplus American butter for a subsidized price of $80.9 million. The butter was priced at slightly more than 73 cents a pound, while the United States now pays about $1.21 a pound to buy butter under domestic price support programs.

headline: New USX Chief Faces Decisions on Steel
abstract: LEAD: Charles A. Corry, the new chairman and chief executive of the USX Corporation, has never been well known outside the company. Even the president of the United Steelworkers, Lynn R. Williams, says that what little he knew of Mr. Corry came through their common dentist.

headline: China's Private Businesses Face Inspection
abstract: LEAD: China announced today that it was initiating an inspection of the nation's 14.5 million individually owned businesses, the great majority of which are accused of evading taxes, and concern is growing that the Government is adopting a more hostile attitude toward private enterprise.

headline: Dow Up 22.38 To 2,635.43; Volume High
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices continued to set records yesterday, buoyed by higher bond prices and the announcement of a new blockbuster merger.

headline: Microbilt Accord Revised by Block
abstract: LEAD: H & R Block & Company, the tax-preparation concern, said the terms of its agreement to acquire the Microbilt Corporation had been revised. The original offer was for $18 a share in Block stock.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Technology Adds Choices And Programming Needs
abstract: LEAD: ROBERT A. IGER took over ABC's entertainment division four months ago as a self-confessed novice with no previous experience in New York or Hollywood television production.

headline: Austrian Recounts Rapport With Diplomat in Spy Case
abstract: LEAD: Austria's Foreign Minister acknowledged today that Felix S. Bloch, the senior American diplomat being investigated on suspicion of espionage, had easy access to Austrian Government offices during his seven years of service in Vienna.

headline: Market Place; Hurdles Seen For Suitors Of Syntex
abstract: LEAD: EVEN though the takeover speculation about the Syntex Corporation has again reached a feverish pitch, industry analysts say the company's unusual evolution, from a Mexican research institute into a pharmaceutical manufacturer, may pose a formidable obstacle to any merger.

headline: U.N. Supports Arab League Panel In Effort to Mediate Beirut Truce
abstract: LEAD: In a new attempt to stop the bloodshed in Lebanon, the United Nations Security Council declared its full support today for the three Arab countries trying to mediate in the conflict.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: A chart last week with the Investing column erroneously included stock prices for the Network General Corporation in 1988 and January 1989. The stock did not trade publicly before February 3, 1989.

headline: Party of God Mentor Offers Help In Promoting a Trade of Captives
abstract: LEAD: The spiritual leader of pro-Iranian Shiite Muslims believed to be holding hostages in Lebanon said today that he would help free the captives if Western countries used their influence to obtain the release of Arab prisoners in Israel.

headline: U.S. Seizes 9 Savings Units
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has been named managing agent for nine savings and loan institutions, bringing the total in the Government management program to 253 in 33 states.

headline: African Talks on Angola Peace Seem to Bog Down
abstract: LEAD: As leaders of eight African nations met here today, there were increasing signs that their efforts to resolve Angola's long civil war were foundering.

headline: Patents; New Biotech Rulings Stir Confusion
abstract: LEAD: The Patent and Trademark Office has given two companies what appears to be strong patent protection for the same drug, setting the stage for another biotechnology dispute.

headline: VENEZUELA SQUINTS WARILY AT FUTURE
abstract: LEAD: Six months after the worst riots here in 30 years, President Carlos Andres Perez continues to push his free-market approach on a wary populace, pressing on largely alone.

headline: Seattle Bond Issue Totals $80 Million
abstract: LEAD: The Municipality of Seattle yesterday priced through competitive bidding $80 million of general obligation bonds that are backed by a limited sales tax.

headline: White House Acts to Ease Fed Criticism
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration sought today to minimize differences with the Federal Reserve, after the budget chief, Richard G. Darman, accused it of running unnecessarily big recession risks by keeping interest rates up.

headline: Budapest Finds Coat of Arms Suits It Better Than Red Star
abstract: LEAD: The red star, the symbol of Communist rule in the Eastern bloc for four decades, will be removed from all public buildings in Hungary to reflect the country's move toward a multiparty democracy.

headline: SELLING A 'LIFE-STYLE' AT ONE-STOP FURNITURE SHOPSZ
abstract: LEAD: The convenience demanded by young, dual-career couples is the driving force behind the boom in one-stop furniture shops, referred to as life-style stores. ''We are seemingly too lazy to do our own homework and we want to see everything at once, down to the napkin holders,'' said Mr. Brackett of the furniture manufacturers association.

headline: Florida Power's Bonds Yield 9.48%
abstract: LEAD: The Florida Power and Light Company, a unit of FPL Group Inc., yesterday priced $150 million of first-mortgage bonds, due in 2019, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: The Trouble With Mall Interviewing
abstract: LEAD: SHOPPING malls have in recent years become a preferred site for companies to acquire market research, generating a debate in the communications industry over whether the malling of research is leading to the mauling of research.

headline: Digital Offers Severance Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's second-largest computer company, has offered 40 to 104 weeks of pay to 700 employees if they voluntarily leave the company.

headline: Yields Expected to Drop Further
abstract: LEAD: Credit market analysts expect Treasury bond yields to decline further in coming weeks. The yields fell below 8 percent for the first time in two years on Friday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Sun Microsystems, to J. Walter Thompson/San Francisco, with a budget of $10 million.

headline: Envoy as Spy: Rare in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Cases in which American diplomats have been accused of espionage are extremely rare.

headline: Hunt for Golden Horse Finally Ends
abstract: LEAD: The six-year treasure hunt for a golden horse is finally over, and the only winner is a Philadelphia-based charity, the Big Brothers/ Big Sisters of America.

headline: BASS P.L.C. TO ACQUIRE HOLIDAY INN
abstract: LEAD: The Holiday Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Holiday Inn hotel chain to Bass P.L.C., a British brewer with interests in the restaurant and lodging industries. Bass will pay Holiday's shareholders $125 million in Bass stock and assume about $2.1 billion of debt.

headline: MAI Basic Gets Aid Infusion
abstract: LEAD: MAI Basic Four Inc., in need of resuscitation after spending millions in a failed effort to acquire a competitor, said today that it had agreed to receive a $55 million infusion from an investor group led by MAI's chairman, the financier Bennett S. LeBow.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL  A diplomatic cable revealed that the U.S. may soften its opposition to membership for the Soviet Union and China in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which manages the world trading system. Such a move could offer both Moscow and Beijing a framework for normalizing trade relations with other countries.

headline: A Bidding War for Professors Who Know Wall Street Ways
abstract: LEAD: A bidding war has broken out among the nation's business schools for finance professors.

headline: Saving Units' 'Junk Bonds'
abstract: LEAD: Many savings and loan associations continue to use federally insured funds to invest in securities that are below investment grade, commonly known as ''junk bonds,'' Alex Sheshunoff & Company, a financial information and consulting firm in Austin, Tex., said today.

headline: Hoechst Profits Decline
abstract: LEAD: Hoechst A.G., the large West German chemical company, said today that its pretax profits in the second quarter slipped 1.8 percent, to 1.1 billion marks, or $565 million, after a 23 percent gain in the first quarter. Hoechst said its profits were squeezed because it was unable to pass the entire rise in raw material costs on to consumers.

headline: Scripps to Buy Cable Systems
abstract: LEAD: The E. W. Scripps Company has agreed in principle to buy nine cable television systems in the Knoxville area and eastern Tennessee for $100 million, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Tax-Exempt Yields Rise
abstract: LEAD: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with increases for tax-exempt funds and declines for taxable funds.

headline: Developing Nations Benefit As Service Exports Grow
abstract: LEAD: Tens of millions of television viewers in more than 100 countries have followed the adventures of a sultry 19th-century Brazilian slave named Isaura who endures all sorts of adversity after falling in love with her master's son but eventually triumphs.

headline: Hubert Beuve-Mery, 87, Dies; Founded Le Monde
abstract: LEAD: Hubert Beuve-Mery, the stubbornly independent founder of Le Monde, France's most respected newspaper, and its editor for a quarter of a century, died Sunday in Fontainebleau, near Paris. He was 87 years old and suffered a severe fall 10 days ago, the newspaper said.

headline: Kremlin Aide Calls Disputed Estonian Law Illegal
abstract: LEAD: The Kremlin signaled its sympathy with the protesting Russian minority in Estonia today as the Soviet Justice Ministry said a new voting residency law was unconstitutional and would violate human-rights standards.

headline: Western Union
abstract: LEAD: Edward F. Heil, a business executive from Deer Park, Ill., has acquired 6.32 percent of the Western Union Corporation, the troubled telex operator based in Upper Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Heil, president of the American Environmental Construction Company, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had purchased 2.66 million Western Union shares - at prices ranging from $1.50 to $2.57 each, between May 17 and June 27 - for investment purposes only.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Fred Abatemarco has been named editor in chief of Popular Science magazine, a Times Mirror publication.

headline: Dow Jones Bids for Rest Of Telerate
abstract: LEAD: Dow Jones & Company moved unexpectedly yesterday to make complete its ownership of Telerate Inc., the rapidly expanding financial information service, with a $576 million offer for the portion of Telerate in public hands. Dow Jones already holds 67 percent of the company.

headline: Mitsubishi Bank Listing On Big Board
abstract: LEAD: Mitsubishi Bank Ltd., the world's fourth-largest bank, with some $350 billion in assets, next week will become the first Japanese financial institution to be listed for trading on the New York Stock Exchange. It will be the largest commercial bank and the largest foreign company ever listed on the Big Board.

headline: Ashton-Tate Plans Layoffs; Operating Loss May Rise
abstract: LEAD: Citing reduced revenues and increased losses, the Ashton-Tate Corporation announced today that it would lay off at least 15 percent of its 1,700 employees and take other cost-cutting measures.

headline: Growth Seen In Germany
abstract: LEAD: West Germany's economy will grow strongly this year and is likely to continue to expand for two more years, although less forcefully and with higher inflation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report released today.

headline: Belzberg Money For Armstrong Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Belzberg family of Vancouver, British Columbia, said it had raised $40 million to finance a possible takeover bid for Armstrong World Industries. The Belzbergs disclosed the financing in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: For Developing Countries, Debt Payments Outstrip Aid
abstract: LEAD: Despite record foreign aid disbursements by the World Bank and large donor countries like Japan, developing countries were so encumbered by debt obligations last year that they paid $50 billion more to creditors than they received in new aid, the World Bank reported today.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 464 money market mutual funds increased by $53.7 million, to $343.4 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 142 institutional funds decreased by $380.9 million, to $85.33 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were up by $124.3 million, to $109.91 billion.

headline: Third World Shifts Focus of Chemical-Arms Talks
abstract: LEAD: More than 60 nations will gather in Australia on Monday to discuss the problem of chemical weapons. But the conference is already headed in a different direction from that originally planned by the Bush Administration.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
abstract: LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  House Democrats proposed raising the top income tax rate. The plan, to be voted on by the House next week, is a political gamble to defeat the capital gains tax cut promoted by Bush and approved last week by the Ways and Means Committee. [ Page A1. ] The Brady plan to provide relief to the most indebted nations is forcing new losses at American banks.

headline: China's Private Business Drops
abstract: LEAD: The number of private businesses in China has fallen for the first time since 1981. The Farmers Daily reported

headline: The High-Risk World Of Colombian Politics
abstract: LEAD: He has three bullets in his body. His predecessor was assassinated. And when he goes on campaign trips, he takes along an emergency supply of his own blood. He is Senator Ernesto Samper Pizano, the governing party's leading presidential candidate, and his predicament points up the risks of political life in Colombia.

headline: For Europe, A New Look
abstract: LEAD: With the European agenda shifting rapidly away from military issues and toward economic ones, President Bush has over the last three months defined a more modest role for the United States on this side of the Atlantic: merely first among equals.

headline: Israel Tends to Quake Victims, and Soviet Ties
abstract: LEAD: On their own if they were able, in pairs if they were not, 61 Armenians stepped off an El Al jetliner onto an Aeroflot stairway this afternoon, smiling and waving at nearly 1,000 friends and family members who cheered and threw carnations from the terminal balcony a short distance away.

headline: All Yields Fall Further
abstract: LEAD: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to fall for the week ended yesterday.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ex-Officer at Chemical In United Savings Post
abstract: LEAD: Kenneth H. Thorn has been named the president and chief operating officer of the United Savings Association of Texas, a $4 billion-asset savings institution in Houston that was recapitalized with $1.37 billion in Federal assistance in December.

headline: Bell & Howell Sale Seen
abstract: LEAD: The Bell & Howell Company said today that might sell the Merrill Publishing Company, one of its core businesses. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Bell & Howell said it had told Merrill employees ''that it has initiated discussions with potential purchasers.'' Merrill, based in Columbus, Ohio, publishes textbooks for elementary schools, high schools and colleges.

headline: Shopping? Don't Forget a Warhol
abstract: LEAD: Marty Blinder is trying to do for art what Ray Kroc did for the hamburger at McDonald's: sell in volume to the masses and become wealthy in the process.

headline: Steelmakers' Inferiority Syndrome
abstract: LEAD: There is no denying that the last five years have seen great strides in the American steel industry, as companies close the competitive gap with many foreign rivals.

headline: Pollution Plan In California
abstract: LEAD: The state Air Resources Board today approved, 8 to 0, a far-reaching plan to clean up air pollution in Southern California.

headline: Market Place; Questions Raised On Bridge Loans
abstract: LEAD: WALL STREET investment banks traditionally feared committing large amounts of their own capital to finance a client's deals. But, in 1985, the firms discovered that sizable short-term loans could bring large profits, and so fear was pushed aside and they began extending bridge loans for corporate refinancings.

headline: First Pennsylvania Deal With Meridian Could End
abstract: LEAD: After two weeks of inconclusive merger negotiations, the Meridian Bankcorp announced yesterday that it had agreed that the First Pennsylvania Corporation could solicit other bids through Sept. 25.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: LEAD: * Banponce Corp., San Juan, P.R., is continuing to evaluate the unsolicited $50-a-share merger proposal made by Banco Popular de Puerto Rico. Banponce's board also authorized an increase in the quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share, from 37.5 cents, payable Sept. 29, to holders of record Sept. 14.

headline: Decision On Time by Friday Seen
abstract: LEAD: After a one-day hearing today, a Delaware court said it hoped to rule by Friday on Paramount Communications Inc.'s attempt to block Time Inc.'s takeover of Warner Communications Inc.

headline: Bonn Asked by Walesa To Invest in the Poles
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa urged West Germany today to be less cautious about investing in Poland, saying business should act quickly to back the democratization process there, which he called ''a really enormous step forward.''

headline: Fretter-Atari Unit
abstract: LEAD: Fretter Inc. said it was discussing the possible purchase of certain assets and business of Federated Group Inc., a subsidiary of the Atari Corporation. It said no definitive agreement had been reached.

headline: U.S. Charges Bank Fraud
abstract: LEAD: The former president of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association, Patrick G. King, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Dallas on 13 counts of bank conspiracy, false entry and misapplication of funds, the Justice Department said.

headline: Patents; A Sweetened Cereal With Fewer Calories
abstract: LEAD: Nabisco Brands, the baked goods unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., has teamed with a biotechnology company to develop a naturally sweetened cereal that has fewer calories than today's sugar-coated offerings.

headline: INVESTING; Hunting for Values in Canadian Stocks
abstract: LEAD: Like the United States stock markets, Canadian exchanges have been enjoying a strong year. The Toronto Stock Exchange 300 index stood above 3,700 last week, up from a 52-week low of 2,976. Analysts say the market should continue climbing if Canada manages to avoid a recession, as many economists expect it will.

headline: Ethnic Violence in Soviet Georgia Leaves 11 Dead, 127 in Hospitals
abstract: LEAD: Another spasm of ethnic violence, this time in a region of Soviet Georgia called Abkhazia, has left 11 people dead and 127 hospitalized this weekend, the official Tass news agency reported tonight.

headline: Running the Little Man's Bank
abstract: LEAD: The blazing-hot heat was already rippling up from the pavement outside, as the cars began to swing into the pawnshop's lot and pieces of households emerged from trunks and back seats.

headline: Economic Scene; Better Highways At No Cost
abstract: LEAD: REMEMBER the good old days, when the asphalt was smooth, the bridges were sturdy and America's highways could still be maintained with a few pennies' tithe at the gas pump?

headline: POLAND'S PREMIER OFFERING TO YIELD TO NON-COMMUNIST
abstract: LEAD: Under increasing Soviet pressure for an end to Poland's Government crisis, Prime Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak said today that he would resign and ask that the leader of a small party traditionally allied with the Communists be allowed to form a cabinet.

headline: Ex-Gibraltar Officer Indicted
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has arrested a former San Francisco savings and loan manager after a Federal grand jury charged him with embezzling $3.5 million. Richard A. Mariucci, 30 years old, managed a branch of Gibraltar Savings from 1985 to April 1989, when he was dismissed for reasons unrelated to the embezzlement investigation, the F.B.I.

headline: Wickes Asset Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Wickes Companies said it had agreed to sell its Elco Corporation group of companies to the Kyocera Corporation of Japan for $250 million. The move is the latest asset sale by the new owners of Wickes, Blackstone Capital Parntners L.P. and Wasserstein, Perella Partners L.P. Elco supplies electronic connectors and interconnecting systems for the electronics industry, and Kyocera manufactures ceramic products and electronic equipment.

headline: Papers' Hearing Delayed
abstract: LEAD: A hearing has been rescheduled for Tuesday on a dispute between The Dallas Times Herald and The Dallas Morning News over publishing features and comic strips that the Universal Press Syndicate intends to move from The Times Herald to The Morning News. The hearing in United States District Court had been scheduled for today.

headline: Birth Control Making Inroads in Populous Kenya
abstract: LEAD: Kenya's birth rate has dropped, the first sign that the rate of population growth, the highest in the world, may be slowing, a Government survey shows.

headline: U.S. Notes and Bonds End Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in moderately active trading yesterday.

headline: Prospects; A Brand New Deficit
abstract: LEAD: For the first time in decades, the balance of trade in the services and investment sector of the economy posted a deficit. In the second quarter, all of the components of the trade balance became negative because of that loss. The shift reflects growing foreign ownership of American assets and increased borrowing from overseas.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''Are to we to say the exchange is a church, that everything here is above-board all the time? And if so, name any business that is.''  A trading executive at a Chicago exchange, on last week's indictments.

headline: Boeing Jet Order
abstract: LEAD: Boeing Commercial Airplanes, a unit of the Boeing Company, said it had received an order from Viva Air, a Spanish charter carrier, for four of its 737-300 aircraft and options on another four. The eight-airplane commitment is valued at about $260 million, Boeing said. Deliveries are scheduled to begin in 1991.

headline: Strife Returns To a Convent At Auschwitz
abstract: LEAD: An impassioned debate has been revived here over the presence of a Roman Catholic convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

headline: Mennen and McCann
abstract: LEAD: McCann-Erickson New York increased its billings from the Mennen Company yesterday by between $7 million and $10 million a year. The company gave the agency its Home Expression Group's account, consisting of three units that make paper party goods and household fragrance products. McCann, a unit of the Interpublic Group, already handles Mennen's Speed Stick and Lady Speed Stick deodorants, which spent $26 million on advertising in 1988.

headline: Ariel Sharon: Comeback of a Catalyst
abstract: LEAD: Ariel Sharon spent the day today trying to fend off calls for his dismissal from others in the Likud Party who think he has grown too powerful.

headline: Approval Seen for Daimler On Messerschmitt Merger
abstract: LEAD: West Germany's Economics Minister, Helmut Haussmann, will approve Daimler-Benz A.G.'s controversial takeover of Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H., overriding objections from antitrust authorities to create a gigantic aerospace and armaments group, Government sources said today.
