headline: I.B.M. and Baxter in Venture To Sell Health-Care Systems
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Baxter Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that they were forming a partnership to sell computer software and services to hospitals and physicians.

headline: P.L.O. Aide Explains A Possible Arafat Visit
abstract: LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization's spokesman in Washington said today that a possible visit by Yasir Arafat to the United States was not meant as a challenge to the Bush Administration but rather to discuss Palestinian peace initiatives with the United Nations and the American people.

headline: Tanker in Big Spill Typifies Freewheeling Industry
abstract: LEAD: The tanker that spilled 420,000 gallons of oil into Narragansett Bay last month after hitting a reef off the Rhode Island coast was made in Greece, registered in Liberia, insured by a Bermuda-based group managed from London and owned by a Greek shipping magnate.

headline: 11 Armenians Leave Prison, Find Celebrity
abstract: LEAD: When the Soviet authorities jailed the leaders of the most prominent Armenian nationalist group last winter, they hoped to quell and discredit the growing movement that these men were directing.

headline: Inflation Shows Signs of Easing
abstract: LEAD: Inflation eased in June, with consumer prices rising only two-tenths of 1 percent. That is the smallest increase in 16 months and is sharply lower than the six-tenths of 1 percent rise in May. Prices of energy and clothing declined in June and food prices were up only modestly. Still, consumer prices have risen at a 5.9 percent annual rate so far in 1989, the highest six-month rate since 1982.

headline: Warsaw Assails Bonn, Citing Aid Failure and 'Revisionism'
abstract: LEAD: The Polish Communist Party assailed West Germany in unusually strong terms today over the failure to reach agreement on an aid package and over comments by a Bonn Government minister that suggested continuing German claims to territories ceded to Poland after World War II.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFSHDL
abstract: LEAD: * Aetna Life Insurance Co., Hartford, is part of a group that has reached agreement to acquire Greater San Diego Health Plan, a health maintenance organization subsidiary of Western Health Plans Inc. of San Diego, for an undisclosed amount. The venture group also includes Partners National Health Plans and seven San Diego-area hospital systems.

headline: Fiction Publishers Seek Male Readers
abstract: LEAD: For many years the book-publishing industry has regarded women as the most avid readers of hardcover fiction. Novels deemed too heavily oriented toward men were sometimes rejected outright and other times relegated to the back shelf.

headline: Business and Health; The Pressure On Generic Drugs
abstract: LEAD: MANY of the major pharmaceutical companies want it both ways. Although they have moved aggressively to produce low-priced generic versions of drugs whose patent protection has expired, some of them campaign vigorously against the generics when their own more profitable brands are threatened.

headline: ANTI-SANDINISTAS CHOOSE CANDIDATE
abstract: LEAD: The Nicaraguan opposition has chosen Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, one of its most prominent figures, to run for President in the elections scheduled for Feb. 25.

headline: Israelis Lengthen Detention For Arabs Held in Uprising
abstract: LEAD: The Defense Ministry issued an order today extending the period that Palestinians can be held in detention without formal charges or a trial from six months to a year.

headline: American Western In Carlisle Merger
abstract: LEAD: The American Western Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by Carlisle Plastics Inc. for $12.50 a share in cash, a lower price than the companies had agreed upon. Based on American Western's 5.6 million shares outstanding, the offer has a value of $69 million, but with the assumption of debt, American

headline: Excerpts From Speech By Bush on Hungary
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech today at Karl Marx University:

headline: INVESTING; Bet on the Jockey, Not the Horse
abstract: LEAD: In recent months, several popular mutual funds closed to new investors. With $1.2 billion pouring in during the first six months of this year, the Windsor Fund, one of the largest and highest-yielding funds, closed to insure that its $7.2 billion in assets could be properly managed. Mutual Series also closed its Mutual Shares and Mutual

headline: Siberia Mine Strike Affects 100,000 and Is Spreading
abstract: LEAD: The western Siberian coal mines were at a virtual standstill today with about 100,000 strikers demanding further economic and political concessions in the worst wave of labor unrest yet to confront President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: At Least 85 Are Killed in Mexican Train Crash
abstract: LEAD: A Pacific coast train plunged off a bridge into a rain-swollen river in northwestern Mexico today, killing at least 85 people and injuring 107, an official involved in the search said.

headline: Whittaker Selling Chemical Coatings
abstract: LEAD: The Whittaker Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Chemical Coatings Group for an undisclosed amount to the Sherwin-Williams Company, a Cleveland-based manufacturer of paints and building materials.

headline: Retail Sales Down by 0.4% Last Month
abstract: LEAD: Retail sales fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in June, dragged down by lagging auto and home furnishing purchases, the Commerce Department reported today, and analysts said big-ticket items would continue to bear the brunt of high interest rates.

headline: Coors to Offer Lower-Price Beers
abstract: LEAD: The Adolph Coors Company, the nation's fourth-largest brewer, said it would offer lower-priced beers starting Sept. 11. Coors plans a large advertising campaign to introduce the new beers, Keystone and Keystone Light, said Mike Willey, the brand's development manager. He said the beers would be brewed at the Coors plant in

headline: Coors Seeks Some Stroh Operations
abstract: LEAD: The Adolph Coors Company, the fourth-largest brewing company in the United States, said yesterday that it was ''exploring options to acquire certain assets'' of the Stroh Brewery Company, the third-largest beer maker.

headline: Manila Reports Arrest Of Top Rebel Leaders
abstract: LEAD: A leader of the Communist insurgency, Saturnino Ocampo, and his wife, Carolina Malay-Ocampo, were arrested in the suburbs of Manila this morning by Philippine military officers.

headline: Monsanto Wins Mobil Damages
abstract: LEAD: A Federal jury has awarded the Monsanto Company more than $21 million for a breach of contract by the Mobil Oil Corporation. Monsanto contended that Mobil had violated a five-year agreement to buy phosphorus and other products, including detergents and lubrication additives, for Mobil plants in Ohio and South

headline: Italy Has New Government With Andreotti at Head
abstract: LEAD: Two months of infighting within Italy's five-party ruling coalition ended today when Giulio Andreotti, who has already been Prime Minister five times, succeeded in forming this country's 49th postwar Government.

headline: Yugoslavs Astir Over Serbian's Rise
abstract: LEAD: The hottest political topic in Yugoslavia is Slobodan Milosevic - what he has done and, even more, what he might do next.

headline: Mellow Manley Steers Jamaica to Quiet Days
abstract: LEAD: Michael Manley promised a quiet Jamaica and, so far, that is what he has delivered.

headline: A Polish Paper Accuses Jews From Bronx in Nuns' Attack
abstract: LEAD: Poland's Government newspaper today accused New York Jews who staged a protest against a Roman Catholic convent at the former Nazi death camp at Auschwitz of making an attack on nuns.

headline: Egypt Would Be Host to Israeli-Palestinian Talks
abstract: LEAD: Egypt indicated readiness today to be host to negotiations between Palestinians and Israelis on a phased and comprehensive settlement of the political deadlock surrounding the 22-month Palestinian uprising in Israeli-occupied territories.

headline: Baker Now Confirms No Special Emissary To Be Sent to Israel
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d confirmed today that the United States might at some point send a special envoy to Israel, but not now and not a high-level mission like those headed in the past by Philip A. Habib.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Chase Manhattan lowered its prime lending rate to 10 1/2 percent from 11 percent. Other leading banks did not follow but several analysts predicted they would do so soon. [ Page D1. ] A tense debate between the Administration and the F.D.I.C. over who will set policy for the cleanup of the savings industry has taken center stage as the House and Senate take up the savings bailout bill today.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Birmingham Steel Chief Gets Credit for Success
abstract: LEAD: James A. Todd Jr., president and chief executive officer of Birmingham Steel Inc., heads one of the most competitive steel companies in the United States. The success has not gone unnoticed: Earlier this week, the company agreed to be acquired by the Harbert Corporation, a privately held Alabama company.

headline: Pittsburgh Prices Unlimited Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The City of Pittsburgh priced $60 million in improvement unlimited tax bonds yesterday through competitive bidding.

headline: Dow Drops 24.89 Points on Rate Concerns
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday amid investor fears of rising interest rates and speculation that foreign central banks might slow the dollar's rise, analysts said.

headline: Environment Magazines Spring Up
abstract: LEAD: ENVIRONMENTALISM has grown beyond the publications of groups like the Sierra Club and the Audubon Society to become one of the hottest sources of new magazines. At least three publishers are betting that there is an untapped group of readers - and advertisers - interested in an independent mass-market magazine about the environment.

headline: Aird Journal; At the Fringe of the World, a Dour Land to Farm
abstract: LEAD: Working a tiny tenant farm on the sandy soil of a remote wind-battered island scarcely seems an occupation with a future. Yet crofting, long dismissed as an economic and social anachronism, is enjoying a quiet resurgence.

headline: Coffee Impasse Imperils Colombia's Drug Fight
abstract: LEAD: Since an international coffee agreement was suspended two months ago, prices have plunged more than 40 percent on Colombia's leading legal export. Now many Colombians are saying that by allowing the collapse of the agreement, the United States has undercut its effort to encourage Colombia to fight production of its other major export, cocaine.

headline: Eastern Pilots Face the Unthinkable
abstract: LEAD: As the strike against Eastern Airlines nears its fourth month, the leaders of the pilots' union are considering what only a short time ago was unthinkable - coming to terms with Frank Lorenzo.

headline: American Dreams
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Picker International Names New President
abstract: LEAD: Picker International, which makes high-end medical diagnostic imaging machines, has named Cary Nolan as president and chief executive.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: With 2 Premiers Tarnished, Japanese Party Gets Down to Squabbling
abstract: LEAD: One week after Prime Minister Sousuke Uno announced that he would resign, Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party has dissolved into fierce factional and cross-generational battling for the choice of a new leader and perhaps even a new style of leadership.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief of Imperial Corp. Quits Amid Loan Woes
abstract: LEAD: The Imperial Corporation of America, a San Diego savings and loan holding company that made a painful foray into automobile financing, said its president and chief executive had stepped down.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization      $      Sept. 22   Sept. 15   Sept. 23        1989   1989   1988       Gasoline production, daily   7.3   7.1   7.0        Distillate production, daily   3.0   3.0   2.6        Gasoline stocks   220.0   218.6   218.5        Distillate stocks   122.0   121.4   132.2        Crude imports, daily   5.6   6.4   4.7        Product imports, daily   1.8   2.3   2.1        Crude stocks   330.9   328.9   318.8        Crude production, daily   7.5   7.5   7.9        Refinery utilization (%)   89.3   89.8   81.2

headline: Cineplex Expands
abstract: LEAD: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it has bought a 50 percent stake in four cinema complexes in Suffolk County, L.I., for undisclosed terms. Cineplex will operate and schedule movies for the complexes, which were acquired in partnership with a group of New York real estate developers. The theaters are in Mattituck, Westhampton, Islip and Sayville.

headline: Neutralizing Poison Gas
abstract: LEAD: In reaffirming American support for a chemical weapons ban from a United Nations podium yesterday, President Bush rejected recommendations by the American military and calls by conservatives that he back away from a treaty banning poison gas.

headline: Account to Foote, Cone
abstract: LEAD: G-R-I Corp., a direct marketer of cosmetics and household products, awarded its $10 million advertising and direct marketing account on Friday to a hometown agency, Foote, Cone & Belding/Direct of Chicago. Foote, Cone prevailed over three agencies, including the incumbent, Rapp Collins Marcoa. The other agencies were Wunderman Worldwide and McCaffrey & McCall.

headline: Walesa Urges Caution Amid Changes in Poland
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa, in a reflective mood in advance of a meeting with President Bush next week, said today that he thought both he and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski were having difficulties because of Solidarity's landslide election victory last month.

headline: House Committee Votes 19 to 17 To Reduce Tax on Capital Gains
abstract: LEAD: A divided House Ways and Means Committee approved legislation today to cut the tax on capital gains, handing President Bush an important political victory and setting the stage for a bruising fight on the House floor later this month.

headline: Baiting Brokers
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: S.E.C. Losing a Member
abstract: LEAD: Charles C. Cox, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission since 1983, said Tuesday that he would leave the Federal regulatory agency at the end of the month to join a consulting firm. The resignation of Mr. Cox, 44 years old, a former chief economist of the agency, had been expected because his term technically had expired.

headline: Talking Deals; An F.D.I.C. Policy Emerges in Texas
abstract: LEAD: L. WILLIAM SEIDMAN, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, surprised many bankers and securities analysts last week when he acknowledged that companies partly owned by his agency were at a disadvantage when they wanted to acquire troubled banks.

headline: Five Charged By the S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a former broker at Merrill Lynch, his mother and three other individuals with violating Federal securities laws by trading on information from advance copies of Business Week magazine over a two-year period.

headline: Doskocil Sells Wilson Holding
abstract: LEAD: The Doskocil Companies signed a definitive agreement to sell the fresh and retail meats portion of its Wilson Foods subsidiary to the WFC Acquisition Corporation for about $140 million in cash. The agreement includes all of Wilson's retail brands and trademarks, which will be transferred to WFC, which includes members of the division's management.

headline: Profiting From Puts and Calls
abstract: LEAD: FOR several weeks, the California Technology Stock Letter has been recommending an unusual way to profit on the stock of the 3Com Corporation, a computer networking company.

headline: Toyota Plans British Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would build a $220 million engine plant that will employ 300 people in north Wales.

headline: A.&S. Makes a Big Bet In Manhattan Retailing
abstract: LEAD: Across the street from Greeley Square, where men and women living out of shopping bags sometimes doze on park benches in the middle of the afternoon, a sleeping giant is awakening.

headline: Saudi Arabia Accused by Iran Of Planting Bombs in Mecca
abstract: LEAD: Iran accused Saudi Arabia today of planting the bombs that killed one person and wounded 16 near Islam's holiest shrine during the annual pilgrimage to Mecca.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: How Prodigies Perceive Business
abstract: LEAD: Thanks to the likes of Steven P. Jobs, the founder of Apple Computer Inc., and William Gates of the Microsoft Corporation, young computer prodigies are now considered potent drivers of the economy.

headline: Harken Makes Bid for Tesoro
abstract: LEAD: The Harken Energy Corporation, an energy development company, today offered to acquire the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation of San Antonio for $11.75 a share, or about $190 million, in cash.

headline: PARTIES IN POLAND WILL ASK WALESA TO FORM A CABINET
abstract: LEAD: Solidarity and two small parties that have traditionally supported the Communists agreed late Wednesday to propose that Lech Walesa, the movement's founder, be allowed to form a government.

headline: 3 Young Palestinians Killed In Unrest in Occupied Lands
abstract: LEAD: Two young Palestinians died in violence in the occupied territories today, and a third died of a gunshot wound suffered in a clash with troops last week.

headline: Moscow Sets Aside Big Obstacle to Arms Treaty
abstract: LEAD: The new strategic arms control initiative put forth by the Soviet Union here on Friday appears to remove the principal obstacle to a treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons.

headline: Soviets Stripping Brezhnev Of Top Military Decoration
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Government pushed former President Leonid I. Brezhnev further into disgrace today by stripping him of the country's highest military honor.

headline: Bolivian Patriarch Hands Reins to a Relative
abstract: LEAD: The reclusive octogenarian Victor Paz Estenssoro is to give up the presidency on Sunday after having turned Bolivia back from part of the revolutionary process he started in his middle years.

headline: Bush Is Warned on Bugged Moscow Embassy
abstract: LEAD: In unusually blunt language, the Senate Intelligence Committee has warned the Bush Administration that any decision against tearing down the new American Embassy building in Moscow invites a ''security disaster'' for which President Bush would be responsible.

headline: London and Dublin Cite Worry on Security Leak
abstract: LEAD: The Irish and British Governments today agreed that reports of collusion between British security forces and outlawed Protestant paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland ''raised issues of serious concern in relation to confidence in the security forces and respect for the rule of law.''

headline: SmithKline Gets Vaccine Approval
abstract: LEAD: The SmithKline Beecham Company said it had received Federal permission to sell a hepatitis B vaccine that it hopes will establish it in the $85 million market now dominated by Merck & Company. The company declined to disclose sales estimates for the vaccine, Engerix-B, which was approved for sale in

headline: USX Income Rises by 17.3% As Prices for Oil Increase
abstract: LEAD: The USX Corporation, the giant oil and steel company, yesterday reported a 17.3 percent increase in its earnings for the second quarter, citing greater demand for petroleum products, higher crude oil prices and asset sales.

headline: Elders Buyout Bid Nearly Completed
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of Elders IXL Ltd. and other executives said they were close to completing a buyout bid for the brewing company through their private firm, Harlin Holdings Ltd. The chairman, John D. Elliott, said Harlin was close to arranging financing for the offer, which values the company at 5.31 billion

headline: New Step for Clean Air: A Natural Gas Bus
abstract: LEAD: The value of natural gas as a clean-burning alternative to gasoline and diesel fuels has long been known, and large numbers of conventional engines have been converted to its use. Now, in anticipation of increasingly stringent Federal emissions standards for urban areas, at least one manufacturer has developed a mass- transit bus designed from the outset to be powered by natural gas.

headline: U.S. Diplomat May Have Started Spying in the 70's, Official Says
abstract: LEAD: American investigators believe that Felix S. Bloch, a veteran diplomat suspected of espionage, began spying for the Soviet Union at least a decade ago, a senior Administration official said today.

headline: Patents; Running Diesel Engine With a Coal Slurry
abstract: LEAD: An engineer at Defense Research Technologies Inc. of Rockville, Md., a research concern specializing in fluid control, has patented a device that makes it possible to power a diesel engine with a coal slurry.

headline: A New Ontario Law Matches Women's Wages With Men's
abstract: LEAD: Private employers in Canada's largest province are scrambling to comply with ground-breaking legislation requiring that the pay in jobs historically held by women match the pay for jobs of comparable skill that are usually done by men. In the public sector, the law has already produced substantial raises for women in secretarial and clerical jobs.

headline: Cheney Asks Seoul to Buy Fighter Jets Direct
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney urged South Korea today to buy jet fighter planes directly from the United States rather than to make them in Korea under license from an American producer, as proposed by Korean officials.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Top Positons Are Filled At Mercantile Stores
abstract: LEAD: The Mercantile Stores Company, an operator of department stores in mid-American smaller cities, said yesterday that it had named David R. Huhn as its chairman and chief executive and had also chosen a new president and chief operating officer.

headline: Unity Plans In Europe
abstract: LEAD: The European Commission agreed today on proposals for closer cooperation as part of an ambitious but controversial blueprint for a full economic and monetary union starting next year.

headline: Saudi Report On Economy
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia reported today that its economy overcame a fall in oil prices to achieve solid growth last year, but independent economists said the Government would keep a tight rein on spending to insure stability.

headline: Reader's Digest Names Chiefs for New Groups
abstract: LEAD: The Reader's Digest Association Inc. has hired Thomas M. Kenney, who most recently has been an investment banker specializing in buying and selling magazine publishing companies, to be president of a newly formed Magazine Publishing Group.

headline: Economic Scene; The $12 Billion Misunderstanding
abstract: LEAD: AMERICA's savings and loans lost billions of dollars investing in home mortgages, the asset they are supposed to understand best. Why take the chance they will lose billions more by investing in exotic, high-risk ''junk bonds''?

headline: 'An Inferno of Bombs': The Ordeal of Beirut
abstract: LEAD: Hardly a building remains unscathed in West Beirut as Lebanese Christian forces and their Syrian foes clash. Most residents have fled. Those who have not rush to basements at the first crash of a shell. Article, page A7.

headline: Akihito's Tone: A Bit Less Imperial
abstract: LEAD: For more than seven months, the Japanese have been watching carefully but patiently for clues to the kind of reign to be established by the unassuming 55-year-old marine-life specialist who became their Emperor after the death of his father, Hirohito.

headline: About Real Estate; New Jersey's No. 2 Convention Center Is Planned
abstract: LEAD: It took S/A Associates of Garden City, L.I., nearly three years to convince E. R. Squibb & Sons to sell its pharamaceutical distribution center in Franklin Township, in Somerset County, N.J.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman's Post Filled At Reading & Bates
abstract: LEAD: Jack W. Bates, chairman and co-founder of Reading & Bates, will retire at the end of this month at age 70, the company's mandatory retirement age. D. Keith McIntosh, a 23-year veteran of the company, will succeed Mr. Bates as chairman and retain his titles of president and chief executive.

headline: Tokyo Leaders, Stung, Try to Contain the Damage
abstract: LEAD: Stunned by its worst election defeat in a generation, the governing Liberal Democratic Party today began the difficult process of selecting new leadership and devising a strategy to prevent its control of the Government from unraveling further.

headline: Tax Deferrals Criticized
abstract: LEAD: Tax-deferred savings plans like individual retirement accounts have become a ''cruel hoax'' for many retirees who find themselves subject to higher income tax rates than when they were young, according to a private study released today.

headline: AMR Profits Increase 25.8%
abstract: LEAD: Record traffic on American Airlines in June pushed the profit of the carrier's parent, the AMR Corporation, to $177.9 million in the second quarter, a 25.8 percent increase over last year, the company said today.

headline: To Be Precise, a New Era for Instruments
abstract: LEAD: On Jan. 1, 1990, thousands of the world's most precise instruments will be recalibrated. By international agreement, the national standard laboratories of most industrial countries will on that day resolve the minute differences among them on the values of two basic yardsticks in electricity: the volt and the ohm.

headline: 14 Rockets Hit Kabul
abstract: LEAD: Fourteen rockets slammed into Kabul today, and hospital officials said at least 18 people were wounded. Kabul has been hit almost daily by rocket attacks since late June, and Islamic guerrillas have claimed responsibility for some of the attacks.

headline: Business Week Sued
abstract: LEAD: The former chief executive of Allegheny International Inc. has filed an $80 million libel suit against Business Week magazine, contending that a defamatory cover article cost him his job and reputation.

headline: For U.S., Few Options of Retaliation
abstract: LEAD: If Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins's death is confirmed, the Bush Administration will find itself confronting the same quandaries that have prevented its predecessors from retaliating for most previous terrorist attacks, former and present Government officials said today.

headline: INVESTING; Is Now the Time to Buy 'Junk Bonds'?
abstract: LEAD: Despite the rallies in high-grade bonds like Treasuries, prices of ''junk bonds'' have weakened in recent months as fears of a recession heat up. For the first six months of the year, the total return on the First Boston High Yield Index, an index of 277 junk bond issues, was 5.41 percent, compared with the 15.35 percent return on 30-year Treasury bonds.

headline: 72 Killed as Typhoon Hits Chinese Province
abstract: LEAD: A storm has killed 72 people and left hundreds missing in Zhejiang province, Chinese national televison reported today.

headline: Accounting Firms Plan to Merge
abstract: LEAD: Arthur Andersen and Price Waterhouse, two of the largest accounting firms, confirmed that they would formally explore a merger. Deloitte, Haskins & Sells and Touche Ross, the smallest of the nation's Big Eight accounting firms, also agreed in principle to combine. Joseph E. Connor, chairman of Price Waterhouse, and Lawrence A.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Amdura Corp., said John J. Cardwell, chairman of the company's new board of directors, would work with existing management, other board members and outside consultants to review the company's current strategy and operations.

headline: Stroessner's Son Is Sought
abstract: LEAD: Paraguay asked Brazil on Friday to extradite Gustavo Stroessner, son of the deposed Paraguayan dictator Alfredo Stroessner, to face charges of extortion and other crimes. An official at the Paraguayan Embassy said his country formally petitioned Brazil to turn over the 46-year-old former air force colonel, who is assumed to be living in Brasilia.

headline: Ciudad Bolivia Journal; Forsaken Land Awaits a New Breed of Farmers
abstract: LEAD: Out on the flat plains of western Venezuela, where cows outnumber people, a seed has been sown to bring Latin Americans back to the land.

headline: New Owners for 3 Savings Units
abstract: LEAD: The new Government body formed to purge the savings industry of insolvent institutions announced new owners for three of the nation's most hopelessly distressed savings and loan associations tonight.

headline: Borrowing Pace Showed Rise in May
abstract: LEAD: Americans took out $3.6 billion more in consumer debt than they retired in May, as the pace of borrowing rose again, the Government said today.

headline: Capping a Career
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  COMPANIES  The pilots' union at United Airlines plans to offer $6.5 billion for the carrier, a Wall Street executive and an investor with major holdings in the airline said. The offer, worth close to $300 a share, will be presented to UAL's board today, and approval is expected. British Airways would be a major investor.

headline: Pretoria Cracks Down on Defiance Campaign
abstract: LEAD: South African authorities stifled a plan by anti-apartheid groups to resume open political activities today in defiance of restrictions imposed on them under a continuing state of emergency.

headline: British Law Urged for Nazi War-Crime Trials
abstract: LEAD: A report on a war-crimes inquiry has recommended changes in British law to allow prosecutions for Nazi war crimes said to have been committed by immigrants who have since become British citizens. The report said there was already enough evidence to convict three such people living in Britain.

headline: Sudanese Coup Leader Offers Vote on Islamic Law
abstract: LEAD: A day after seizing power, Sudanese Army officers pledged today to end the country's six-year civil war and offered a referendum on the future of Islamic law, the central issue driving the conflict.

headline: Soviet Journals Snipe at Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is steadily losing popularity at home because he is trying to be reformer and party boss at the same time, according to an unusually frank and gloomy commentary published this week in a prestigious journal.

abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change                     Net Income   Percent       Apr.-June   Change       1989   From '89              Allegheny Ludlum Corp.   $ 36,700,000    +39.5        Amdahl Corp.   32,800,000    -37.9        American Express Co.   316,000,000    +16.8        AMP Inc.   65,800,000    -21.7        Anheuser-Busch Cos.

headline: Metropolitan Life Backs Oil Merger
abstract: LEAD: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it supports the Dallas-based Harken Energy Corporation's proposed merger with the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation. Last week, Harken offered to pay Tesoro shareholders $11.75 a share in cash, or about $190 million.

headline: Salvador Rebel's Peace Offer Brings Skepticism From U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The United States is skeptical of a Salvadoran rebel leader's offer to stop fighting if the United States halts military aid to El Salvador's Government, the State Department said today.

headline: Court Issues Order Against Vernitron
abstract: LEAD: The Kollmorgen Corporation said the Superior Court of Connecticut had issued a temporary order enjoining the Vernitron Corporation from acquiring the electric motor maker or any of its shares.

headline: 2d Rebel Group Joins Carter's Ethiopia Talks
abstract: LEAD: A second Ethiopian rebel group said today that it had accepted former President Jimmy Carter's offer to play a role in peace talks with the Marxist Government in Addis Ababa.

headline: UAL Stock Up $46.25 After Offer
abstract: LEAD: The stock of the UAL Corporation soared 28 percent, or $46.25, yesterday after the company said it had received a takeover proposal from Marvin Davis, the Beverly Hills, Calif., investor.

headline: American Express Apology Is $8 Million, Not $4 Million
abstract: LEAD: The American Express Company agreed to pay twice as much as it originally announced to settle accusations that it had conducted a campaign of disinformation against Edmund J. Safra, a banking competitor, people involved in the agreement said last night.

headline: Rig Count Rises Again
abstract: LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil throughout the country jumped by 14 last week, to a total of 950, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. It was the second straight increase. A year ago, the count stood at 938.

headline: Cambodian Premier Appeals for Truce
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Hun Sen appealed today to the opposition coalition to agree to a cease-fire in Cambodia and asked China to stop supplying arms to the guerrillas after the last Vietnamese troops leave the country Tuesday.

headline: P.L.O. SAID TO EASE TERMS FOR VOTING IN OCCUPIED AREAS
abstract: LEAD: For the first time, the Palestine Liberation Organization has offered a specific list of conditions under which it might allow Israel's plan for elections in the occupied territories to go forward, Government officials said today.

headline: Dow Gains 9.69 Points After Wide Swings
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday while trading volume increased sharply.

headline: Guilty Pleas in Futures Case
abstract: LEAD: Two more futures traders pleaded guilty today to violating Federal commodity laws while trading in the Chicago Board of Trade's soybean pit, admitting they pocketed about $250 each at the expense of customers.

headline: For the Children, Colombia, Is a Very Scary Place to Be
abstract: LEAD: Perched on a school sofa, her white socks and black shoes swinging a few inches from the floor, Catalina, who is 11 years old, remembers setting out with her mother on a recent Saturday to buy a birthday present.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Dick Levy & Partners Is Returning to the Fray
abstract: LEAD: When last heard from, Dick Levy had left Fisher Jackson Levy Flaxman for parts unknown. Turns out that for the last year and a half, he has been squirreled away at his father-in-law's ad agency carefully plotting his return.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Fern Kaplan and Kerry Graham have been promoted to senior vice presidents of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston.

headline: PRETORIA HARDENS TACTICS AT RALLIES
abstract: LEAD: The Government today intensified its crackdown on demonstrators protesting apartheid in advance of Parliamentary elections scheduled for Wednesday.

headline: Dow Rises 12.92 for Second Straight Gain
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average gained 12.92 points, to 2,687.50, yesterday, adding to the small rally of Friday.

headline: Sale of Sears Tower Stalls
abstract: LEAD: An official with Olympia & York Development Ltd., a Canadian real estate development concern, confirmed today that negotiations for the sale of the Sears Tower had broken down after Sears, Roebuck & Company and Olympia & York, the potential buyer, were unable to agree on who would pay a tax increase under a reappraisal that is expected to follow the sale of the world's tallest building.

headline: CONTINENTAL'S FUTURE NEEDS SAID TO PROMPT IDEA FOR SALE
abstract: LEAD: An adviser to Frank Lorenzo said yesterday that the Texas Air Corporation's chairman had decided to give serious consideration to the sale of Continental Airlines primarily because he thinks the parent company will find it difficult to afford the investment needed to keep the carrier competitive with the huge airlines forming under deregulation.

headline: U.S. to Sell 5 Savings Units
abstract: LEAD: Federal regulators put five more large savings institutions up for sale today and said they hoped to complete the multibillion-dollar deals by the end of the month.

headline: New Israeli Thicket; Mubarak's Plan for Palestinian Elections Propels Jerusalem Toward Coalition Crisis
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and the rest of Israel's right wing are pleading, threatening and fighting to kill a peace plan offered by Egypt that every other interested party has enthusiastically embraced.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Beijing Puts Khmer Rouge on Shorter Leash
abstract: LEAD: As a new round of civil war threatens Cambodia, diplomats here say China finds itself in the awkward position of wanting the Khmer Rouge troops it supports neither to win nor lose.

headline: Generic Drug Investigation
abstract: LEAD: The Health and Human Services Secretary, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, said today that he believes the worst is over in a generic drug investigation that has rocked the Federal Food and Drug Administration.

headline: An $81 Million Bond Issue For Shelby County, Tenn.
abstract: LEAD: Shelby County, Tenn., priced a total of $81 million in general-obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding. The bonds will be used for public improvement, schools and special purposes.

headline: Prague Tries To Cut Off All But Party Line
abstract: LEAD: The dissident Jiri Dienstbier lost his telephone number, 220-110, on Aug. 10. The Czechoslovak authorities said they needed it ''for an important public purpose.''

headline: Rig Count Rise Ends
abstract: LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil in the United States as of last Friday dropped by five, to 820, halting a seven-week climb, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.

headline: Honey, They Shrunk the Computer
abstract: LEAD: Several companies now offer or are getting ready to offer a generation of portable machines that weigh six pounds or less.

headline: Salinas and Business Leaders Hail Debt Accord
abstract: LEAD: The debt relief and interest rate reduction that Mexico was granted by its commercial bank creditors on Sunday night were hailed here today by the Government and by the business community as a historic breakthrough. But opposition parties, labor unions and independent economists expressed skepticism as to how much Mexico would actually benefit from the accord.

headline: A Fragile Air Freight Strategy
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Express Corporation is learning to greet customers in many different languages around the world, but some replies have been unfriendly.

headline: Some of Siberia's Miners Return; Gorbachev Calls Strike a Crisis
abstract: LEAD: After decades of grimy subservience, some of the striking miners of the vast Siberian coal region began pronouncing themselves victorious today in a wildcat strike that has paralyzed the mines and brought unexpected economic and industrial concessions from the Government.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Buyout Partnership Is Established in Dallas
abstract: LEAD: The breakup of Hicks & Haas, the leveraged buyout group based in Dallas, has produced a new partnership and a new player, John R. Muse.

headline: Home Resale Drop Posted
abstract: LEAD: Sales of existing homes declined in the second quarter in 41 states and the District of Columbia, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

headline: Grey Will Promote New Eisenhower Coin
abstract: LEAD: The United States Mint awarded Grey Advertising yesterday the $3 million account for a silver coin commemorating the 100th birthday of Dwight D. Eisenhower. Grey will do advertising, direct marketing, sales promotion and public relations for the coin, which goes on sale next January. Grey has handled four assignments for the Mint since 1985.

headline: U.S. Recalls Bulgaria Envoy; Plight of Turks Is Protested
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration said today that it was recalling the United States Ambassador to Bulgaria to protest rights abuses by the Bulgarian authorities against that country's ethnic Turkish minority.

headline: New Ball President Slated to Be Chief
abstract: LEAD: The Ball Corporation has named Delmont A. Davis president and chief operating officer and indicated that he will be asked to lead the maker of packaging products in two years.

headline: Ulster Officer Is Slain and Mother Wounded
abstract: LEAD: Assailants burst into a home northwest of the capital and opened fire today, killing a policeman and wounding his mother, the police said.

headline: Spelling TV Concern May Be Put Up for Sale
abstract: LEAD: Spelling Entertainment Inc., responsible for such hit television series as ''Dynasty'' and ''Love Boat,'' said today that it might put itself up for sale.

headline: Ernst's Canadian Affiliates Shun Merger and Pick Peat
abstract: LEAD: Ernst & Whinney's Canadian affiliates have opted out of Ernst's merger with Arthur Young and instead plan to join KPMG Peat Marwick, the parties involved said yesterday.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: An article on July 9 about the Games Gang Ltd. incorrectly described the genesis of the game Gender Bender. It was created by Loki Games Ltd. and developed by Chris Haney.

headline: Syrian Hopes for Oil Tempered by Setback
abstract: LEAD: Arthur and Mia from the Channel Islands, who entertain at a nightclub here, swung into a country and western tune recently, and the audience, including some Americans who work in the oil business here, joined in.

headline: Dollar Falls In Europe
abstract: LEAD: The dollar ended slightly lower today in European trading that was becalmed in the absence of American traders, who were observing the July 4 holiday. Gold prices were higher. Foreign exchange dealers said activity was generally light, and trading grew progressively quieter during the afternoon.

headline: Article 840689 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Undertaking by far the largest corporate takeover bid in European history, an investor group led by Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, made a $21 billion offer today for B.A.T. Industries. B.A.T., a London-based conglomerate with extensive operations in the United States, owns Saks Fifth Avenue and the Hardee's fast food chain and sells Kool and Lucky Strike cigarettes.

headline: Bush Credits Moscow With Change in East Bloc
abstract: LEAD: President Bush said today that the changes transforming Eastern Europe are ''absolutely amazing,'' and credited the Soviet Union with making those changes possible.

headline: Weeklies Challenging Boston Globe
abstract: LEAD: Russell Pergament has spent 10 years trying to get under the skin of The Boston Globe, using his publisher's column in The Weekly Tab newspaper as his needle.

headline: Falconbridge Holders Urged to Take FL Bid
abstract: LEAD: In the continuing battle for what mineral experts say are some of Canada's richest mining assets, the board of directors of Falconbridge Ltd. recommended today that shareholders accept last week's offer of $37 (Canadian), or $31.45 (United States), a share from the FL Acquisition Corporation. FL was formed by two mining giants, Noranda Inc.

headline: Bosch, Old Foe of U.S., Makes Comeback in Santo Domingo
abstract: LEAD: Twenty-six years ago, Juan Bosch worried a lot of powerful people here and in Washington. To them, his talk of land reform and turning over businesses to workers sounded very much like Communism. He lasted seven months as President. Two years later, in 1965, when supporters tried to return him to power, President Lyndon B.

headline: Paolo Baffi Dies at 77; Headed Italian Bank
abstract: LEAD: Paolo Baffi, the former governor of Italy's central bank, died on Friday night after a long illness, the bank announced today. He was 77 years old. The bank did not disclose the illness.  Mr. Baffi, one of the major economic figures in postwar Italy, worked for 40 years with the Bank of Italy, the country's central bank.

headline: Gorbachev Warns Separatists
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet President called for 'solving all problems by political methods,' but denounced secessionists as 'adventurists.' Page A8.

headline: U.N. and O.A.S. Form Panel To Help the Contras Disband
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations and the Organization of American States agreed today to create a joint commission to oversee the disarming and resettlement of the American-backed Nicaraguan rebels based in Honduras.

headline: But Can It Locate a Taxi in the Rain?
abstract: LEAD: A computerized vehicle-inspection system that checks everything from the level of pollution emitted by a car to the accuracy of a taxi's fare meter has been developed by the Hamilton Test Systems unit of the United Technologies Corporation.

headline: Auto Dealers' Profit Rate Dips
abstract: LEAD: Profits at United States auto dealerships have dropped from 2.4 percent of sales in 1984 to 1.7 percent last year, the National Automobile Dealers Association said.

headline: Japanese Gains Lift Vehicle Sales by 4.3%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks rose 4.3 percent in mid-July, but analysts said the industry would still need production cuts in the fourth quarter.

headline: 4,000 Gazans Shun Jobs for a Day As Israeli Permits Are Introduced
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army today officially put into effect a policy requiring Gaza Strip workers to show a new exit permit if they want to enter Israel from Gaza. But instead, many Palestinians stayed home.

headline: GENERIC-DRUG GUIDELINES SEEN LACKING AT F.D.A.
abstract: LEAD: Some makers of generic drugs received preferential treatment in the Food and Drug Administration's approval process because the agency failed to establish adequate guidelines for reviewing the drugs, a new Federal report says.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Amerihost Properties Inc., Des Plaines, Ill., said its board had approved a reverse stock split in which shareholders would receive one share for each 50 shares.

headline: Missing Tables
abstract: LEAD: Because of a malfunction in the computers that receive financial market data from The Associated Press, several tables reflecting yesterday's trading in gold; Treasury bills, bonds and notes, and Canadian stocks were not available.

headline: S.E.C. Censures Accountant
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured a partner in the accounting firm of Peat Marwick Main & Company today for improper conduct in the audit of the 1982 annual report of the Midwestern Companies.

headline: London Journal; In Umbrella Land, Sunshine Gets Mixed Reviews
abstract: LEAD: For Michael Fish, the British Broadcasting Corporation's veteran weatherman, who has a weather-obsessed nation waiting on his every word, it has been a disappointing summer.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: State Insurance Laws Could Slow B.A.T. Bid
abstract: LEAD: Sir James Goldsmith's $21 billion bid for B.A.T. Industries could be complicated by state regulations concerning any change in ownership of B.A.T.'s American insurance subsidiary, the Farmers Group Inc., analysts and regulators said today.

headline: Hospital Partners Makes Bid for HEI
abstract: LEAD: Hospital Partners, a limited partnership controlled by Dana F. McGinnis, a San Antonio broker, has offered to acquire the HEI Corporation for $4.25 a share in cash, or a total of $20.82 million. In a letter to HEI, Hospital Partners said that the offer was subject to obtaining sufficient financing, negotiating a friendly agreement and receiving the approval of the company's shareholders.

headline: Panel Action On Futures
abstract: LEAD: A House committee, voting hours after prosecutors announced a number of indictments against commodities traders, approved legislation Wednesday evening reauthorizing the Federal agency that regulates commodity futures exchanges.

headline: Syria Is Said to Join Hostage-Release Effort
abstract: LEAD: The Government of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has joined efforts to arrange the release of Western hostages in Lebanon and has invited a senior Iranian official to Damascus for talks, Arab diplomats say.

headline: Korea's Snake Imports
abstract: LEAD: A demand for health potions has encouraged frog and snake imports to South Korea, a Government report said last week. An Agriculture and Fisheries Ministry report to the National Assembly on imports of foreign food items said the value of South Korea's imports of snakes in the first half of this year climbed to $380,000, surpassing the $295,000 for all of 1988.

headline: Journal Cancels An Ad Section
abstract: LEAD: The Wall Street Journal has canceled plans to produce an advertising section that would have included a review featuring restaurants that bought space in the section, a spokesman for the newspaper, Danforth W. Austin, said yesterday.

headline: Argentina's Chief to Try Charm on U.S.
abstract: LEAD: In two and a half months in the presidency, Carlos Saul Menem has woven a kind of magic over the Argentines.

headline: Heavy Bombardments Continue in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Heavy clashes continued in Lebanon today, and Gen. Michel Aoun, who commands Christian forces battling Syrian troops and their Lebanese Muslim allies, said he would carry the fight ''until the end.''

headline: The Limits of Audits; Counting Alone Cannot Detect Fraud If Management Is Juggling Numbers
abstract: LEAD: The allegations of fraud filed yesterday against Crazy Eddie Antar show just how easy it can be to inflate profits, fooling investors and Wall Street analysts. What appears to have been an effort to make already-impressive results for 1985 a little prettier seems to have descended by 1987 into a complicated scheme to hide huge losses.

headline: Janos Kadar, Hungary's Ex-Leader, Buried
abstract: LEAD: Janos Kadar was buried today, and those who deposed him from leadership of the Communist Party last year and cast him into virtual disgrace delivered eulogies.

headline: U.S. Issues Rebound Somewhat
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday, rebounding from Monday's big selloff.

headline: U.S. Jews Organize to Urge Israel-P.L.O. Talks
abstract: LEAD: Liberal American Jews have formed a lobby to persuade Congress and the Bush Administration that Israel should negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization and agree to the formation of an independent Palestinian state.

headline: Soviet Weekly Criticizes Pravda on Yeltsin
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet weekly criticized the Communist Party newspaper, Pravda, today for publishing a denunciation of a Soviet opposition leader's conduct during his recent tour of the United States.

headline: WALESA TO BACK A COMMUNIST CHIEF
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, moved today to end the deadlock that has prevented the election of a Polish President by declaring that he would support Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski or any other candidate put forward by the Communist Party.

headline: Advertisers Rush Back to the Networks
abstract: LEAD: SPURRED by increased automobile advertising and renewed confidence in television's ability to sell, the networks have sold more commercial time in advance for the next season than ever before.

headline: Poles Are Reported Beaten By Rumanian Border Troops
abstract: LEAD: The Foreign Ministry filed a protest today after 30 Polish tourists said Rumanian border soldiers dragged them off a train and beat them with rifle butts, the state press agency reported.

headline: Congress Inspects a Soviet Pullback
abstract: LEAD: Machine guns blasted and mortars thundered in the distance as the Soviet military allowed the House Armed Services Committee a rare glimpse of its headquarters in East Germany.

headline: Outside U.S. Embassy, Soviet Extortion
abstract: LEAD: American officials trying to cope with increasing crowds of Soviet applicants for immigration say the people in long lines outside the United States Embassy are being victimized by an extortion racket involving Soviet police guards assigned to keep order.

headline: ARGENTINE LEADER NAMES ARMY CHIEF
abstract: LEAD: President Carlos Saul Menem has moved quickly to try to calm the restive Argentine Army by naming as Chief of Staff a man favored by dissident officers who led three barracks rebellions in the last two years.

headline: Xerox Sets Buyback Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back about 11 million shares of its common stock, or about 11 percent of its 103 million shares outstanding.

headline: Market Place; Is Stock Swap Good for AVX?
abstract: LEAD: THE ''go go years'' of the late 1960's may be coming back, but with an Asian flavor.

headline: Temple Plans Bid
abstract: LEAD: Temple Holdings Ltd. said it planned a proxy fight for control of the board of Sea Containers Ltd. Temple has offered to acquire Sea Containers for $63 a share in cash, or $1.03 billion, but the Bermuda-based ferry and cargo concern has rejected the offer as inadequate.

headline: Surplus Security
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Helicopters Join Search for Leland
abstract: LEAD: Four American helicopters joined the search today for Representative Mickey Leland and 15 others missing since their flight vanished in western Ethiopia on Monday. But the day ended with no sighting of the plane or its passengers.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Aventek Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., an industrial products manufacturer, said Gary G. Harmon was resigning as chief financial officer and secretary to pursue other business opportunities.

headline: Treasury Notes and Bonds Surge
abstract: LEAD: In a sharp rally, prices of Treasury notes and bonds surged in brisk trading yesterday, in response to Government economic reports. First, data showed that economic growth in the second quarter was somewhat weaker than anticipated, then the Government reported that initial unemployment claims figures suggested employment conditions may have deteriorated even more rapidly than had been thought in

headline: Dallas Papers In Dispute
abstract: LEAD: A Texas judge has ordered Universal Press Syndicate to continue supplying The Dallas Times Herald with 26 comics and other features that the syndicate wanted shifted to The Dallas Morning News.

headline: U.S. Expands Its Sanctions Against Panama
abstract: LEAD: The United States announced today that it has expanded economic sanctions against Panama in an effort to force Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to relinquish power there.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: Frank Assumma and J. Edmund Keating have been appointed executive vice presidents of Backer Spielvogel Bates.

headline: Cuban Air Crash Toll Rises to 139
abstract: LEAD: The death toll in Cuba's worst air crash rose to at least 139 today as local authorities disclosed that 14 people in a village near Havana's Jose Marti airport were killed when a Cubana Airlines jet went down in flames and demolished their homes.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Rain and Fines, but Mostly Rain, Slow Burning of Amazon Forest in Brazil
abstract: LEAD: Plumes of gray smoke are once again rising over the green sea of Amazonian rain forest surrounding this city. But preliminary survey figures from this year's dry season point to a new trend: a marked drop in burning.

headline: MAI Basic Expects a Loss
abstract: LEAD: MAI Basic Four Inc. said today that it expects to report a ''significant'' third-quarter loss because of write-offs associated with its abandoned tender offer for Prime Computer Inc. In addition, the company said it was restructuring and would cut 10 percent of its work force in the next three months.

headline: Di Giorgio Rejects Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Di Giorgio Corporation said today that its board had unanimously rejected as inadequate an unsolicited $32-a-share tender offer from an organization headed by Arthur M. Goldberg, a New Jersey businessman.

headline: Noranda Weighs Bidding for Amax
abstract: LEAD: Noranda Inc., the giant Canadian mining and forestry company, may try to buy Amax Inc. to block its proposed friendly takeover of Falconbridge Ltd., Noranda's chairman and chief executive, Alfred Powis, told The Financial Post of Toronto. Noranda has long been known to have an interest in taking over Falconbridge, a nickel mining concern that is one of

headline: Christian Chief Rejects Lebanese Peace Plan
abstract: LEAD: An Arab League envoy's efforts to arrange a cease-fire stalled today as Christian leaders insisted on assurances for an early withdrawal of Syrian forces from Lebanon.

headline: Campeau's Aim in Picking U.S. Chief
abstract: LEAD: The new chief executive of Campeau U.S., the large unit of the Campeau Corporation that operates nine American department store chains, will be chosen from the ranks of financial rather than retailing executives, Robert Campeau, chairman of the corporation, said this week in an interview.

headline: Jaruzelski Calls For a Coalition With Solidarity
abstract: LEAD: Arguing that Poland's dire economic situation demands cooperation among all major political forces, President Wojciech Jaruzelski has strongly urged Solidarity to join the Communist Party in forming a coalition Government.

headline: Updating Futures
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: GTE Wins $100 Million Libel Case
abstract: LEAD: The GTE Corporation was awarded $100 million in damages yesterday by a Florida jury that found the company had been libeled by Home Shopping Network Inc.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Commercial Costs Up 12%
abstract: LEAD: The cost of producing a nationally broadcast television commercial rose by 12 percent in 1988 over the year before, an increase that the American Association of Advertising Agencies yesterday called ''not as dramatic as those reported earlier in this decade.''

headline: Agitation by Farmers Is Challenging Gandhi
abstract: LEAD: Indian farmers across the country's rich western and northern agricultural belts are asserting themselves with demands for better prices and a bigger say in their future under the leadership of two men who are trying to weld their supporters into powerful political constituencies.

headline: Philips Selling Military Units
abstract: LEAD: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics manufacturer, said today that it hoped to transfer major parts of its military activities to the French state-owned group Thomson-CSF by the end of this year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Tambrands Goes to Ally
abstract: LEAD: Tambrands Inc. yesterday awarded a $15 million advertising account to Ally & Gargano, extending that agency's string of recent successes and deepening the troubles of the incumbent agency, Campbell-Mithun-Esty. Ally edged out Esty and

headline: Dunkin' Donuts
abstract: LEAD: The Delaware Chancery Court ruled in favor of Dunkin' Donuts Inc. in its lawsuit against the DD Acquisition Corporation, which has made a $305 million hostile bid for Dunkin. The court denied DD Acquisition's motion to block Dunkin' Donuts takeover defenses involving an employee stock ownership plan, a ''poison pill'' and the sale of preferred stock to the General Electric Capital Company.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; McCann Has 2 Big Losses And a Gain
abstract: LEAD: MCCANN-ERICKSON U.S.A. lost two of its premier accounts yesterday when RJR Nabisco Inc. moved its Winston and Camel cigarette businesses, worth $55 million in billings last year, to two agences.

headline: Patents; A Drug to Help Treat Food and Drug Craving
abstract: LEAD: Mark Hohenwarter, a pharmacologist for Seratonin Industries Inc., a small pharmaceutical company in Charleston, S.C., received patent approval this week for biamine, a chemical that he said could help treat obesity, cocaine addiction and narcolepsy.

headline: Commodity Traders and Brokers Indicted
abstract: LEAD: Following is a list of the 46 traders and brokers indicted today by the Government on a variety of charges, including violations of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The charges stemmed from a two-year investigation of trading in the Chicago commodity pits:  SOYBEAN PIT

headline: Murdoch Bidding for MGM/UA
abstract: LEAD: Just two weeks before it was to be sold to the Qintex Group of Australia for $1 billion, the MGM/UA Communications Company today received a surprise $1.35 billion counteroffer from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

headline: Yields Down On C.D.'s and Bank Funds
abstract: LEAD: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week ended yesterday.

headline: De Klerk Makes an Overture to Mandela's Group
abstract: LEAD: F. W. de Klerk, the leader of South Africa's ruling party, said today that if the outlawed African National Congress was prepared to endorse a statement by its jailed leader, Nelson R. Mandela, by ''committing itself to the pursuit of peaceful solutions,'' it could become involved in a ''process of dialogue and negotiation.

headline: Delaware Court Seen as Unlikely to Reverse Time Ruling
abstract: LEAD: Lawyers and Wall Street experts said over the weekend that they believed it was relatively unlikely that the Delaware Supreme Court would overturn the decision of the Delaware Chancery Court letting Time Inc. buy Warner Communications Inc.

headline: Charles Schwab Net Up
abstract: LEAD: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the largest discount brokerage firm, today reported second-quarter net income of $4.2 million, or 15 cents a share, double the $2.1 million, or 8 cents a share it reported in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues rose 45 percent, to $139 million, from $95.7 million in the second quarter of 1988.

headline: A Merger Clicks, Painfully
abstract: LEAD: After three years of turmoil, one of the biggest mergers in advertising is starting to pay off, thanks mostly to its architect - a Middle Western adman who stumbled badly at first in making the transition to Madison Avenue.

headline: Lawyers Expect Commodity Charges Soon
abstract: LEAD: Indictments are expected soon in the Government's continuing investigation of commodity trading here. Justice Department officials met with defense lawyers today to outline how racketeering charges might be brought.

headline: O'Connor Deplores Remarks by Poland's Primate
abstract: LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, disassociated himself yesterday from the remarks of the Catholic Primate of Poland, who was critical of Jews for objecting to a convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

headline: S.E.C. Tones Down Plan For Private Placements
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today toned down its proposal to liberalize trading in the private-placement market.

headline: Remic Securities From Fannie Mae
abstract: LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, yesterday priced its 101st real estate mortgage investment conduit securities deal since the company began issuing them in August 1987.

headline: Patents; Reducing Wood Stove Pollutants
abstract: LEAD: It may not be true that trees cause pollution, as former President Reagan once asserted. But pollution certainly results when logs are burned in traditional wood stoves, which belch an average of 22 grams - three-quarters of an ounce - of particulate matter an hour.

headline: French Economy Slows
abstract: LEAD: The French economy grew by seven-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter of 1989, about half the pace of the first three months of the year, the national statistics institute said today. The report came a day after France reported its worst month external trade performance in a year - a July deficit of almost 7.5 billion francs ($1.14 billion).

headline: CHINESE CHIEF SETS HARD POLICY LINE
abstract: LEAD: In its most sweeping declaration of policy since leadership changes in June, the Communist Party acknowledged some mistakes today but called for vigilance against what it described as efforts by the West to subvert the Chinese Government and institute capitalism.

headline: Borden Unit's Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Galloway West Company, a subsidiary of Borden Inc. and Wisconsin's largest producer of Swiss cheese, is being bought by Waterford Foods P.L.C. of Ireland. The purchase price was not disclosed. Galloway West will continue to operate under its current name, and its 300 employees should not be affected by the transaction.

headline: Noriega Critic Arrested
abstract: LEAD: More than a dozen armed plainclothes officers broke into a law office on Friday and arrested Jaime Padilla Beliz, the owner of an opposition newspaper shut down two years ago, one of his associates said. The incident occured at the office of the firm Padilla y Asociados, where Mr. Padilla is a senior partner, said Venus Cardenas, a lawyer in the firm.
