headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: UAL Jumps $6.75
abstract: LEAD: The stock of UAL Inc. jumped $6.75 a share today, to $183.50, amid talk that several large investors had built up stakes in the airline company. The Marvin Davis is the latest investor rumored to be accummulating UAL shares. Dan Dorfman reported in USA Today that Mr. Davis had acquired about 3.5 percent of the carrier.

headline: Unassuming Storefronts Believed To Launder Drug Dealers' Profits
abstract: LEAD: State banking regulators around the country have found that thousands of small inner-city businesses through which recent immigrants send money to relatives are also being used to launder drug money. The regulators say these storefront money-transmitting and check-cashing operations are sending billions of dollars to drug dealers in South America and Asia.

headline: Michaels Stores To Be Acquired
abstract: LEAD: Michaels Stores Inc., a retail chain specializing in materials for home decorating and crafts, has agreed to be acquired for about $130 million by a company formed to take it private. Under the accord, the holders of Michaels' nine million common shares will receive $9.50 a share in cash and $2.50 in liquidation value of preferred stock in the acquiring company, MSI Holdings Inc.

headline: U.S. Agency Accused Of Favoring I.B.M.
abstract: LEAD: Six computer companies accused a Federal agency yesterday of awarding more than $1 billion in data processing contracts to the International Business Machines Corporation without competition, saying that the practice may have cost the Government millions of dollars in excess procurement costs.

headline: Hooker Corp. Plan Typical Of Hong Kong Financier
abstract: LEAD: Lo Yuksui, the Hong Kong entrepreneur who has offered to make a $75 million loan to the ailing Hooker Corporation of Australia, has built a hotel and real estate empire through what his company literature describes as ''successful corporate rescues and reorganizations.''

headline: Sun Sets Up Cost Controls
abstract: LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., facing what could be its first loss, has instituted tight cost controls, a company spokeswoman, Carol Broadbent, said today.

headline: In Ulster After 20 Years, Hopes Are Nearly Gone
abstract: LEAD: Twenty years after British soldiers were deployed to restore order to the riot-torn streets of Northern Ireland, deep sectarian divisions and devastating violence appear to have a stranglehold on faint hopes of peace.

headline: Wells Fargo to Buy Valley National
abstract: LEAD: Wells Fargo & Company agreed to acquire the Valley National Bank in Glendale, Calif., for about $55 million. With assets of $255.4 million, Valley National has seven branch offices in the San Fernando Valley area north of Los Angeles and employs 180 people. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of this year or early next.

headline: Mazda in Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Mazda Motor Corporation, the Sumitomo Corporation and Indo Mobile Group of Indonesia have set up a joint venture in Jakarta to make automobile engines and body parts, a Mazda spokesman said. P.T. Mazda Indonesia Manufacturing, which is capitalized at $15.7 million, will be owned 55 percent by Mazda, 30 percent by Indo and 15 percent by Sumitomo.

headline: Hyundai to Add Quebec Plant
abstract: LEAD: Hyundai Auto Canada Inc. officially opened its huge car assembly plant here today by announcing it would build another plant nearby to make auto body parts. Quebec's Premier, Robert

headline: Latest Pentagon Report Lifts Shadow of Soviet Menace, a Bit
abstract: LEAD: It is not quite a paean to perestroika. But the Pentagon issued a new report on the Soviet military today that is a far cry from the catalogue of the Soviet empire's evils published annually by the Reagan Administration - and even a bit more muted than the public statements of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.

headline: Bankruptcy Filing For Aladdin Hotel
abstract: LEAD: Ginji Yasuda, the Japanese businessman, filed Monday to put his ailing Aladdin Hotel under Federal bankruptcy protection, citing debt that outstripped the resort's assets by more than $38 million.

headline: Aid With Leverage; Bush Borrows Wall St. Techniques To Cut Cost of Package for Poland
abstract: LEAD: In the best capitalist tradition, President Bush's economic aid plan for Poland borrows some tried and true Wall Street techniques and transfers them into the arena of East-West relations. One is the notion of

headline: Report on Peru Shows Rising Tide of Rights Abuses
abstract: LEAD: The disappearance, torture and killings of citizens by security forces and guerrillas in Peru have steadily risen the last 18 months, Amnesty International said today.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Brambles Seeks Environmental
abstract: LEAD: Brambles Industries Ltd. offered to acquire the shares of the Environmental Systems Company that it does not own for $14 each, or $137 million. Environmental's shares jumped $2.25 each today, to $13.75, with the 19.6 percent gain being the third largest on the New York Stock Exchange. The offer was made in a letter sent on Friday to Jack W.

headline: Talking Business with Hedien of Allstate Insurance; Insurers Tackle California's Law
abstract: LEAD: A representative of the Allstate Insurance Company will be the lead-off witness this week in the first public hearing by the California Department of Insurance on how large a return auto insurers should be permitted to earn under Proposition 103. That new law, enacted by voters in November, mandates an across-the-board rollback in auto-insurance premiums.

headline: France to Sell Parts to Libya In Effort to Influence Qaddafi
abstract: LEAD: Seeking to encourage Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya to steer a less radical course, France has authorized a limited sale of military spare parts to the North African nation, according to officials and diplomats.

headline: Korea Trade Surplus
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus fell dramatically in the first half of 1989, according to central bank figures released today. The surplus dwindled to $2 billion, less than half the $4.5 billion recorded in the 1988 period.

headline: K Mart Stock Up
abstract: LEAD: Shares of the K Mart Corporation rose $2.375, to $43.875, on market rumors that it might be taken over or restructured, traders said. Although analysts discounted the speculation, they acknowledged that K Mart was vulnerable to a takeover. ''Bigger companies have been taken over,'' said Monroe Greenstein, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company.

headline: Petroleum Copter Stake Purchased
abstract: LEAD: Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd., the Hong Kong investment company controlled by the New Zealand investor Ron Brieley, has acquired a 5.02 percent stake in Petroleum Helicopters Inc.'s voting common stock. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Industrial Equity said it bought the Petroleum

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 3 Magazines Wage War For Revenue
abstract: LEAD: HERE'S a tip for media trade publishing companies trying to contend with the slowdown in media trade advertising: make movies.

headline: Mcorp Claim by F.D.I.C.
abstract: LEAD: Seeking to recover part of its $2 billion rescue of Mcorp, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has filed a claim for $847 million in United States Bankruptcy Court in Houston.

headline: British Telecom Names North American Head
abstract: LEAD: British Telecom, which has been increasing its activities in the United States, yesterday named Michael L. Ford as the president of its North American unit.

headline: A.&P. Profit Rises by 20.7%
abstract: LEAD: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company posted a 20.7 percent quarterly profit gain on an 11.2 percent increase in sales, it reported today.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * AMP Inc., an electronics company, to Al Paul Lefton Co., Philadelphia, with an undisclosed budget.

headline: A Critic Gets Forceful Responses
abstract: LEAD: Many advertising and marketing executives and professors responded forcefully to an interview in this column earlier this month in which John Philip Jones, the chairman of the advertising department at Syracuse University's Newhouse School of Communications, questioned some of the foundations of the advertising industry.

headline: India Halts a Shipment Of Chemicals for Iran
abstract: LEAD: An Indian company has sent more than 150 tons of a hazardous chemical that can be used for pesticides and poison gas back to its factory from Bombay port instead of shipping it to Iran, a company executive said today.

headline: Gibraltar Journal; Let Britain Crumble! On the Rock, They're Firm
abstract: LEAD: Shortly before dawn on June 30, four customs agents wearing the uniforms of the Spanish Civil Guard fired shots at random as they landed on a beach just inside Gibraltar in hot pursuit of a boat carrying three cigarette smugglers.

headline: No Ford Unit Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said a bidder for its Rouge Steel Company subsidiary was no longer interested in acquiring the unit, but it said it would seek a partner to run the steel operation. The United Automobile Workers union has said the bidder, believed to be Worthington Industries, had approached Ford about buying the unit.

headline: U.S. Presses Japan on Trade Surplus
abstract: LEAD: The United States today pressed Japan to make immediate changes in its economy to reduce its $50 billion-a-year trade surplus with America, saying action was vital for their relationship.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; New Fertilizer Group Names Chief Executive
abstract: LEAD: Fertilizer Industries, a newly formed holding company, has named R. James Comeaux president and chief executive. Mr. Comeaux's appointment is effective immediately.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Coke Spots Highlight Latin Culture in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it was planning a campaign to recognize Hispanic contributions to American culture in anticipation of the 1992 quincentenary celebration of Columbus's Spanish-backed trip to the Americas.

headline: Citicorp Rates Dip at Auction
abstract: LEAD: For the third consecutive week, interest rates fell yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

headline: Bank Profits at Record High
abstract: LEAD: Commercial banks reported their most profitable six months ever in the first half of the year, the Government said Wednesday.

headline: The Anxiety At Time Inc. Over Bidding
abstract: LEAD: A Time magazine staff member looked at the pile of papers on her desk that explained her choices of what to do with her Time Inc. stock and said glumly, ''It's very complicated. I ought to understand it better.'' As a Time staff member, she wants the company to remain intact. As a shareholder, she wants profits on her stock.

headline: Accounting Board Delays Tax Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The Financial Accounting Standards Board postponed yesterday for the second time the deadline for adopting an unpopular ruling that changes the ways companies report their income tax expense to shareholders.

headline: Treasuries Dip in Light Trading
abstract: LEAD: As dealers struggled to absorb a new $7.75 billion issue of four-year notes, prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in light trading yesterday.

headline: Comex Officer, Citing Hardships, Quits Post
abstract: LEAD: Responding to what he said were ''great demands'' on his personal time and finances, John H. Hanemann resigned Friday as the chairman of the Commodity Exchange Inc. of New York after 16 months in the post. The move came only days after Arnold F. Staloff was appointed president and chief executive of the exchange.

headline: Scores Killed in Ethnic Violence in Northeast India
abstract: LEAD: Scores of people have been killed in a wave of ethnic fighting sweeping parts of the northeastern state of Assam, and the fighting has sent thousands of people fleeing into refugee camps and into a neighboring state, The Press Trust of India news agency reported tonight.

headline: Session on Rights in China to Be Test for U.N.
abstract: LEAD: An international campaign to have China condemned by the United Nations for human rights violations in connection with its suppression of the democracy movement is expected at a meeting opening on Monday in Geneva.

headline: Mortgage Rates Fall
abstract: LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.17 percent last week, down from a rate of 10.22 percent a week earlier, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.71 percent last week, down from 8.74 percent the previous week, Freddie Mac said.

headline: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long
abstract: LEAD: One month after the murder of a presidential candidate here unleashed Colombia's attack on cocaine cartels, President Virgilio Barco Vargas appears to be preparing for a long war against the major drug traffickers.

headline: Peres Escapes Crowd at Funeral As Rage Over Bus Attack Spreads
abstract: LEAD: Enraged mourners tried to attack Finance Minister Shimon Peres today at the funeral of a victim of a bus crash that killed 14 people, while in several other parts of the country angry Jews assaulted any Arabs they encountered.

headline: Stocks Retreat as Dow Dips 1.90, to 2,583.08
abstract: LEAD: The stock market backed away from an early surge yesterday with the Dow Jones Industrial average closing down 1.90 points, to 2,583.08.

headline: East European Pollution Pact
abstract: LEAD: Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany today signed a pact on combatting cross-border pollution, the official Polish press agency reported. It said the agreement, sought by Poland for several years, set out plans for cooperation among the three nations, particularly on air and water contamination.

headline: The Tactics Of Thatcher
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who moved or dismissed nearly half her Cabinet on Monday, signaled her determination today to continue the policies that most of her critics, inside and outside the Government, blame for the decline in the Conservative Party's fortunes over the last six months.

headline: 2 Top Contenders Seen For Chief of the S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Manuel H. Johnson, and President Bush's chief adviser on the savings and loan crisis, Richard C. Breeden, have emerged as the top contenders for the position of chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Administration officials said today.

headline: Bogota Justice Chief Is Reported to Resign Amid Death Threats
abstract: LEAD: Colombia's Justice Minister, a symbol of this nation's war against cocaine cartels, has resigned, a presidential aide confirmed today.

headline: Whirlpool Plans To Lay Off 850
abstract: LEAD: Citing declines in demand for refrigerators, the Whirlpool Corporation plans to lay off 850 employees next month. The layoffs, scheduled for Aug. 14, will leave Whirlpool's payroll at about 2,750 in Fort Smith, where the plant ranked as the largest local employer and the third-biggest manufacturer in

headline: Syntex Expects Earnings Drop
abstract: LEAD: The Syntex Corporation, a pharmaceuticals company in Palo Alto, Calif., said it expected to report a decline in earnings and revenues for the fourth quarter ending July 31. Syntex attributed the decline to slower-than-expected sales of its core product, Naprosyn, which faces new competition in the market for anti-inflammatory drugs and to increased investments in research and development.

headline: Prospects; Housing vs. the Economy
abstract: LEAD: The Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes rose by 5.5 percent in June, the third consecutive monthly increase. The increase came after a sluggish first part of the year when sales fell to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. Seasonally adjusted, annual sales of new homes rose to 670,000 units, roughly the same as 1988.

headline: AMR Revises Takeover Guards
abstract: LEAD: Directors of the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, strengthened the company's anti-takeover provisions even though the company said it was unaware of any imminent takeover attempt. Under the amended plan, if a person or group buys 10 percent or more of AMR's outstanding common shares, stockholders would be entitled to buy additional shares at half price.

headline: I.B.M. Buys Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Policy Management Systems Corporation said the International Business Machines Corporation had acquired a 19.8 percent stake in the company for $116.8 million. Policy Management said that under an agreement signed July 26, I.B.M. had bought 3.7 million newly issued shares of voting convertible preferred stock.

headline: Sun Unit and C3 Get Navy Contract
abstract: LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. said its Sun Microsystems Federal unit joined with C3 Inc., which integrates computer systems, and received a contract from the Navy with a potential value of $115 million.

headline: Jordan Helps Pick Up Pace For Rockport
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the Rockport shoe company departed from Chiat/ Day in April for Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, it left an agency in advertising's avant-garde for one versed in the old-fashioned craft of sloganeering. The new Rockport ads are making their debut this week in national magazines, and they indeed hew to

headline: Signals Heard in Search for Lost Legislator
abstract: LEAD: Searchers for the missing aircraft of Representative Mickey Leland learned tonight of a faint emergency signal picked up by an American weather satellite from an aircraft in southeastern Ethiopia.

headline: Market Place; Conrail's Success Stirring Rumors
abstract: LEAD: CONRAIL, a company born of bankruptcies, and one whose profitable operation seemed highly unlikely less than a decade ago, has done rather well since the Government sold it off less than three years ago.

headline: A Colombian Campaigns Amid Risks of Drug War
abstract: LEAD: From the front of the airplane, the candidate emerged blinking into the bright sunshine of this Andean metropolis. He greeted a crowd of local politicians and then plunged happily into a forest of microphones.

headline: Beirut's Guns Silent; Some Exiles Return
abstract: LEAD: After more than six months of fierce artillery battles, the guns of Lebanon's warring Christian and Muslim factions were silent today as their representatives agreed on measures intended to bring the country back to a semblance of normalcy.

headline: Mexico Set To Sell Its Phone Unit
abstract: LEAD: Mexican Government officials said today that the state intended to put its majority stake in Telefonos de Mexico, the country's troubled, unpopular and inefficient telecommunications monopoly, up for sale in the next few days.

headline: Striking Ukrainian Miners, Appeased, Return to Work
abstract: LEAD: Striking Ukrainian miners went back to work today as an emboldened assortment of political groups ranging from czarists to Communists quickly took President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at his word and proposed holding local elections with greater dispatch and democracy.

headline: East Germans in Budapest May Soon Get to Go West
abstract: LEAD: The future of the East Germans stranded in Hungary appeared to be nearing resolution today as Bonn and Budapest indicated that the 6,000 people would be on their way to West Germany within days.

headline: Ricoh Account Moved
abstract: LEAD: Citing dwindling financial support for the account, Chiat/Day/Mojo announced yesterday that it had parted ways with the Ricoh Corporation, a manufacturer of copiers, after handling the company's advertising for two years. The account, which includes broadcast, print and outdoor advertising, is worth $6 million.

headline: Leland's Body to Come Home
abstract: LEAD: The bodies of Representative Mickey Leland of Texas and eight other Americans killed in a plane crash in Ethiopia on Aug. 7 will arrive in the United States on Wednesday, Ethiopian and American officials said today. Mr. Leland and 15 others, including 7 Ethiopians, died when the plane taking them to a refugee camp hit a cliff in bad weather.

headline: Why World Is Revolving Around Paris
abstract: LEAD: A helium-filled air-ship hovers over the city, snapping live television images to police command centers on the ground. More than 30,000 police officers and soldiers have been mobilized; anti-aircraft batteries have been installed in the Bois de Boulogne.

headline: Argentine to Pardon Ex-Officers
abstract: LEAD: President Carlos Saul Menem says he intends to pardon about 20 retired generals and admirals facing charges of political killings and torture and nearly 100 younger officers who took part in military rebellions.

headline: Now, Chiat/Day/Mojo
abstract: LEAD: Chiat/Day officially added the name Mojo yesterday, reflecting the completion of its acquisition of Mojo MDA, the Australian ad agency. Chiat/Day Holdings said it had purchased more than the required 90 percent of Mojo's shares to combine the agencies. Chiat/Day/Mojo will have billings of more than $1 billion and 1,200 employees.

headline: Henszey & Albert Gains
abstract: LEAD: With the appointment of Henszey & Albert to handle advertising promotion for The New York Post, the 16-month-old agency has quickly rolled up more than $11 million in annual billings. The budget for The Post has not been set, but the agency estimated that it would be at least $1 million. And just yesterday, Henszey & Albert won another new piece of business: Carol Dauplaise, a costume jewelry manufacturer, worth another $500,000.

headline: Bush in a Crisis: Casting the Widest Net
abstract: LEAD: Late Monday afternoon, with one American hostage reported dead and another facing death, President Bush sat at a small wooden desk with a typewriter in the study tucked behind the Oval Office. He had rushed back from Chicago, canceling stops in Las Vegas and Oklahoma City and waving off suggestions from some advisers that the action might give the Lebanese extremists the impression that they could manipulate the United States Government.

headline: A RAFT OF CREATURE COMFORTS TO LURE CUSTOMERS AWAY FROM HOME
abstract: LEAD: A night at the opera perhaps it wasn't, but going to the movies was definitely a classy night out back when theaters were ''palaces'' and the movies were, well, operatic.

headline: U.S. AUTO SALES AT HIGHTST RATE IN 7 MONTHS
abstract: LEAD: Sales of domestic cars rose 5.4 percent in mid-August, bolstered by incentive campaigns to clear inventories before the introduction of the 1990 models.

headline: Bush Signs Bill Ending Gas Controls
abstract: LEAD: President Bush today signed a law removing the last price controls on natural gas and then pledged to develop a comprehensive strategy for enhancing the nation's energy security.

headline: Goal in Chile: Fiscal Change With Stability
abstract: LEAD: A recent newspaper cartoon here showed a group of South American presidents -from Brazil, Peru, Venezuela and Argentina - struggling not to drown in a sea of economic woes, while one man stood on the shore, undecided about jumping in.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: General Assembly  LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY AND SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 and 10:30 A.M. and 3:30 and 4 P.M.  COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Pepsico, to Aid Europe Sales, Buys 2 British Snack Units
abstract: LEAD: Seeking to strengthen its European sales of snack foods, Pepsico Inc. announced yesterday that it had paid $1.35 billion for two British companies that were owned by RJR Nabisco Inc. until last month.

headline: Venezuela Eases Stance On Its Debts
abstract: LEAD: Trying to revive negotiations with commercial banks, the Government of Venezuela is dropping its demands for 50 percent debt reduction and offering other proposals it believes will be more acceptable to the banks.

headline: Prague to Make Changes, but Not Dramatic Ones
abstract: LEAD: In a time of dramatic change in much of Eastern Europe, ''no dramatic change in the situation in Czechoslovakia can be expected,'' the Government spokesman insists.

headline: Drug Scandal
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Banc One to Buy Investment Firm
abstract: LEAD: The Banc One Corporation said it would buy the investment banking firm of Meuse, Rinker, Chapman, Endres & Brooks. Terms were not disclosed. Banc One, the nation's 26th-largest banking company, said it expected the deal to be completed this month. Both companies are based here. Banc One said its investment banking operations would be consolidated in Meuse,

headline: Cosmetics Companies Quietly Ending Animal Tests
abstract: LEAD: Several leading cosmetics companies have quietly stopped testing products on animals. The moves are in response to years of pressure by animal-rights groups and reflect growing confidence in the reliability of alternative testing methods.

headline: Looking to the Company To Provide the Necessities
abstract: LEAD: Corporate paternalism has long been in retreat in the West because it is largely viewed as an infringement on personal freedom.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1989
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: INDIA SEEN AS KEY ON CHEMICAL ARMS
abstract: LEAD: Chemical companies in India have sold hundreds of tons of chemicals needed to make poison gas to Iran, Iraq and Egypt in the last two years, Bush Administration officials say, adding that they fear the trade may expand.

headline: 5 Die in Spanish Train Crash
abstract: LEAD: A train carrying 120 passengers and traveling nearly 90 miles an hour rammed into a stationary freight train 70 miles northwest of Madrid today, and at least 5 people were killed and 54 injured, officials said. A spokesman for the Governor of Alava province said the dead were the passenger train's engineer and four women.

headline: In Sicily, Even Water Has Its Price
abstract: LEAD: ''Water in town? Sure, there's water,'' said the desk clerk at a small hotel called, for some reason, Bella Napoli, even though it lies near the center of this workaday city along the southern Sicilian coast.

headline: Japanese Business Leaders To Cite U.S. Trade Strides
abstract: LEAD: Japanese business leaders who are in New York for a round of economic talks with American counterparts say they are eager to use a trade conference this week to make the case that Japan is taking significant strides toward free trade with the United States.

headline: Japan Car Exports Fall
abstract: LEAD: Japanese vehicle exports fell 1.4 percent in June from a year earlier, to 472,293, automobile industry officials said. Exports in June totaled 345,661 cars, down 1.8 percent from a year earlier, and 126,632 commercial vehicles, down four-tenths of a percent. Japan exported 3.06 million vehicles in the first six months of the year, down 2 percent from the corresponding period of 1988, the sources said.

headline: Prime Chairman Says It's Time to Move On
abstract: LEAD: R. J. Whitney & Company, the venture capital firm that plans to buy Prime Computer Inc., is well known to David J. Dunn, Prime's chairman and a venture capitalist by trade.

headline: Bogota's Justice Aide Impresses Washington
abstract: LEAD: To enlist American help in its struggle against drug traffickers, Colombia this week dispatched a representative who is said to be at the top the list of assassination targets.

headline: Afghan Minister Faults U.S. For Car Bomb That Killed 22
abstract: LEAD: A top Afghan official today called the United States and Pakistan ''morally responsible'' for a truck bomb that killed as many as 20 people in Kabul on Saturday.

headline: President Steps Down At BBDO Worldwide
abstract: LEAD: Willi Schalk resigned on Friday as the president and chief operating officer of BBDO Worldwide. Mr. Schalk, 49 years old, said he would return to his native West Germany and pursue a career outside advertising.

headline: Waste Company Rejects Takeover
abstract: LEAD: Brambles Industries said that the board of the Environmental Systems Company had rejected its offer of $14 a share, or $137 million, to acquire the Little Rock, Ark., hazardous waste management concern.

headline: PREMIER GETS POST
abstract: LEAD: President Wojciech Jaruzelski resigned today as the leader of Poland's Communist Party and was replaced by his close associate, Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski, the Government press agency said.

headline: Dow Up 5.51, to 2,693.29, as Volume Rises
abstract: LEAD: Stocks advanced moderately again yesterday on slightly higher volume.

headline: 46 Face Charges In Chicago Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Forty-six traders were indicted on charges that they repeatedly defrauded customers at Chicago's two commodity futures exchanges. The indictments stemmed from a two-year investigation that put undercover Federal agents, posing as traders, on the floors of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

headline: New Computer Can Read Handwriting
abstract: LEAD: In a development that may make computers accessible to people not accustomed to working on keyboards, a subsidiary of the Tandy Corporation introduced a 4.5-pound portable computer today that can read printed handwriting.

headline: Economic Scene; 'Soft Landing' Hard for Some
abstract: LEAD: A ''SOFT LANDING'' appears to be at hand. Although the statistics bounce around a bit, the American economy is clearly growing more sluggishly than it was last year, much to the relief of the Federal Reserve and many economists. Now, the question is whether a slowly growing economy is really a blessing.

headline: Lima Journal; Peru Rises Up Against Red Tape's 400-Year Rule
abstract: LEAD: Clutching a thick pension file, Natividad Chirinos Contrega was happy to learn that she no longer needed a certificate proving to skeptical bureaucrats that she was alive.

headline: Rise in Farm Income Is Seen
abstract: LEAD: Cash receipts from larger crops this year are strengthening net farm income more sharply than had been expected, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.

headline: U.N. Study Says 1 Billion Suffer From Diseases
abstract: LEAD: One billion people around the world are in poor health, malnourished or suffering with diseases ranging from malaria and river blindness to AIDS, the World Health Organization said in a report released today.

headline: Excess Tenders In NWA Offer
abstract: LEAD: Wings Holdings Inc., a company led by Alfred Checchi, the Los Angeles investor, said yesterday that shareholders had tendered or promised to deliver more shares of NWA Inc. than actually existed.

headline: Steel Imports Off in July
abstract: LEAD: Steel imports fell 5.9 percent, to 1.46 million tons, in July from the previous month and represented 19.3 percent of the domestic supply, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported Friday. Steel imports for the first seven months of 1989 were 10.2 million tons, down 19.7 percent from the corresponding period last year.

headline: I.B.M. Acquires Share in Bachman
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a minority equity interest in Bachman Information Systems Inc., a developer of advanced software. Bachman is privately owned and based in Cambridge, Mass. Under the agreement, I.B.M. will invest in Bachman in exchange for newly issued Bachman voting convertible preferred stock.

headline: Mutual Fund Yields Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Yields of the money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with those of tax-exempt funds rising and those of taxable funds declining.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * AGS Information Services Inc., Mountainside, N.J., a software design company, said it had acquired Multiple Technologies Corp., Detroit.Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Sales by Imperial
abstract: LEAD: The Imperial Corporation of America, a San Diego-based savings-and-loan holding company, said it had sold more than $700 million of assets in the third quarter as part of an effort to shed $2 billion in assets by the end of the year to meet new regulatory requirements. The company said it sold $235 million in corporate bonds and $260 million in auto leases.

headline: Market Place; Wall St. Invents Painless Mergers
abstract: LEAD: WALL STREET has found a new way to merge two companies without penalizing earnings. It has yet to come up with a fancy name for the idea, now known as ''a nonmonetary exchange of assets for stock in a new company.''

headline: Campeau's Mounting Debt Burden
abstract: LEAD:  Nov. 2, 1986: The Allied Stores Corporation, operator of Jordan Marsh and other top retail chains, agrees to be acquired for $3.6 billion by the Campeau Corporation, led by Robert Campeau, who made his fortune in Canada developing shopping malls.  Jan. 24, 1988: Campeau begins a bid of $4.2 billion for Federated Department Stores, owner of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and other chains.

headline: Soviets Confirm Nazi Pacts Dividing Europe
abstract: LEAD: After decades of denial, the Kremlin conceded for the first time today that ''without a doubt'' the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany secretly and illegally divided Eastern Europe into spheres of influence before the start of World War II.

headline: Real Estate; Office Space In Orange County Rises
abstract: LEAD: THE shortage of affordable housing, the high commercial rents and traffic congestion in such suburban office strongholds as Westchester County, Fairfield County and Bergen County have prompted some users of office space to venture farther north into the Hudson Valley region. A handful of developers has kept up with the demand for space in Orange

headline: Lomas Expects Delay on Debt
abstract: LEAD: The Lomas Financial Corporation, a troubled mortgage banking concern, said today that talks with lenders on a restructuring of its senior debt were continuing, but the company added that it did not expect its restructuring to be completed by Friday, when $145 million in senior public debt matures.

headline: Further Economic Lag Seen
abstract: LEAD: The nation's economy slowed in June for the second consecutive month, according to a monthly report by the association of purchasing managers.

headline: European Plan On Air Traffic
abstract: LEAD: Twenty-one European airlines proposed an air traffic control system throughout Europe on Wednesday to replace the national systems now in place.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

headline: Prospects; When Jaguar Is the Prey
abstract: LEAD: Last week the Ford Motor Company announced plans to acquire up to 15 percent of Jaguar P.L.C., the British maker of prestige automobiles. The offer was not welcomed by Jaguar, whose stock in London rose from $6.40 on Monday to $9.18 on Friday. The company is currently valued at about $1.68 billion.

headline: Dutch, Digging Deep, Find Bush's Pilgrim Roots
abstract: LEAD: President Bush discovered his Pilgrim roots today, listened to an organ interpretation of ''Boola, Boola,'' and told the last audience of his European tour that nations around the world are joining in ''a widening circle of freedom.''

headline: China Party Chief's Son Keeps Low Profile at a U.S. School
abstract: LEAD: The son of the new Chinese Communist Party leader has spent the last three years as a graduate student in electrical engineering at Drexel University here.

headline: Coup Could Deprive Sudan of American Aid
abstract: LEAD: In the wake of the military coup here, a relatively untested law approved by the United States Congress three years ago is likely to result in the cutoff of all American economic aid to the Sudan.

headline: Dunkin' Donuts Obtains Injunction
abstract: LEAD: Dunkin' Donuts Inc., the doughnut store chain based here, said it had obtained an injunction in the Federal District Court for Massachusetts against the pending $43-a-share tender offer by Kingsbridge Capital Group, a unit of Unicorp Canada Corporation and Cara Operations Ltd.

headline: Merrill in Gilt Cutback
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch Europe Ltd. confirmed speculation today that it had stopped market-making in British Government bonds, which are known as gilts. But the company said that it would continue to serve customers on an agency basis and that efforts were being made to redeploy staff in the gilts division to other areas.

headline: Towle in Chapter 11
abstract: LEAD: Towle Manufacturing said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Towle, a maker and seller of giftware, said it had made the filing because of excessive debt. The company had a previous Chapter 11 reorganization that ended in November 1987 but it said its revenues had failed to meet the forecasts on which that reorganization was based.

headline: Iraq Requests Price Freeze
abstract: LEAD: Private businesses have been asked to freeze prices after similar measures were taken by state-run enterprises, Al Ittihad, a weekly newspaper, reported today. Al Ittihad, published by an

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: THE INVENTORY MESS; Caution: A Price Deflation Is Under Way
abstract: LEAD: Inventories are the pivot on which the business cycle swings. Economists trained to track just the gyrations of supply and demand are apt to miss the shifts from inventory accumulation to inventory liquidation, and back again. Successful business heads know better. They see inventories as completing the eternal triangle between supply and demand.

headline: Thomason Has Trouble Buying an Illinois Paper
abstract: LEAD: A dissident member of the family that owns The Register-Mail in Galesburg, Ill., has frustrated the efforts of the Thomson Newspapers Corporation to acquire the small daily in what has become a testy legal battle.

headline: F.D.I.C. Sells Some Stock In First City
abstract: LEAD: Bank regulators today sold a portion of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's stake in the First City Bancorporation of Texas for $69.1 million, giving the agency a profit of $26 million.

headline: Lukewarm in the Drug Capital
abstract: LEAD: In Medellin, home of Colombia's most brutal cocaine cartel, many people are reluctant recruits in the Government's war on drugs. Page A8.

headline: Chevrolet Rebates
abstract: LEAD: Chevrolet announced rebates on two of its 1990 cars, two weeks after formally introducing them. The auto maker, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, put a $750 cash rebate on all models of its 1990 Lumina sedan, a car introduced earlier in the year to replace the Chevrolet Celebrity. It also offered an $800 rebate to buyers of the Geo Prism and Chevrolet Nova.

headline: Ecology of Ethics
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: 4 to 6 Communist Seats Seen in New Polish Cabinet
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has completed his Cabinet selections, and they include at least four and perhaps as many as six Communists, officials said today.

headline: U.S. to Train Colombians
abstract: LEAD: The Pentagon said it would dispatch 50 to 100 military personnel to train Colombians to operate and maintain the $65 million worth of arms and equipment promised by President Bush. Page A6.

headline: Digital Plan For Cutbacks
abstract: LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation acknowledged yesterday that it had asked a number of its departments to plan for a 25 percent reduction in staff and a 10 percent cut in spending, but a company spokeswoman insisted the company was not planning layoffs.

headline: Business and the Law; New York Dispute Over Kosher Meat
abstract: LEAD: A COURTROOM dispute between New York State and Hebrew National Kosher Foods Inc. over the company's practices of keeping kosher began as a tempest in a meat pot. But the fight has recently intensified and threatens to keep the company's frankfurters out of the state.

headline: British Conglomerate to Sell Off Saks and Marshall Field Chains
abstract: LEAD: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., the British conglomerate, said today that it planned to sell its vast retailing empire, including the well-known Saks and Marshall Field stores, as part of a dramatic effort to preserve its independence.

headline: A $12 Billion Merger In Pharmaceuticals
abstract: LEAD: A new pharmaceuticals giant will be formed by a merger of Bristol-Myers and Squibb. The $12 billion deal will create the world's second-largest drug maker, with combined annual sales of more than $9 billion. Bristol-Myers makes Excedrin pain relievers and Clairol beauty aids. Squibb is known for its reasearch and some big-selling prescription drugs, like Capoten, a heart drug.

headline: Opposition Leader Is Confined by Burmese Rulers
abstract: LEAD: The military Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, put the country's most prominent opposition leader under house arrest today, diplomats said. International telephone and telex lines to the country were apparently cut.

headline: Tele-Cable Cancels Plan
abstract: LEAD: Tele-Cable Inc., a cable company based in Norfolk, Va., is no longer looking for a buyer and has taken itself off the market, its president, Richard D. Roberts, said last week. Tele-Cable has 585,000 subscribers and is closely held. Tele-Cable's systems are primarily in the South and Midwest and in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

headline: Japanese Party Looks to New Generation, Then Looks Away
abstract: LEAD: After a devastating election defeat and a year of scandals infecting most of its high command, Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party is being prodded by friends and critics alike to turn to bolder and fresher leadership to help it out of the swamp.

headline: Machinists Seen Joining UAL Talks
abstract: LEAD: Unionized machinists at United Airlines are expected to begin talks soon on joining in a newly approved buyout of the airline's parent by a group including pilots, management and British Airways P.L.C.

headline: Muppets Join Disney Menagerie
abstract: LEAD: Miss Piggy and Mickey Mouse may have more pressing concerns than mergers and high finance, but their corporate masters have other ideas.

headline: Budget Surplus in June
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Government recorded a budget surplus of $7.79 billion in June, as individual and corporate income tax payments rose sharply from May, the Treasury Department said today, The June surplus compared with a deficit of $25.47 billion in May and a surplus of $9.13 billion in June 1988.

headline: Computer Sciences Gets Subcontract
abstract: LEAD: The Computer Sciences Corporation said it had received a 13-year subcontract worth $134 million to help to modernize the nation's air traffic control system. The main contractor on the $3.6 billion Federal Aviation Administration program is the International Business Machines Corporation.

headline: Text of the 1987 Agreement On the Convent at Auschwitz
abstract: LEAD: Roman Catholic officials, including Franciszek Cardinal Macharski of Cracow and three other European cardinals, met with Jewish representatives in Geneva in February 1987 to discuss Jewish objections to the presence of a Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp in Poland. Following is the text of a declaration adopted at the meeting, as translated from the French.

headline: West Bank Firebomb Hurts 4 Tax Collectors
abstract: LEAD: Four Israeli tax collectors were wounded today when a gasoline bomb smashed through the windshield of their car as they drove through the West Bank city of Ramallah, the army said.

headline: 46 Commodities Traders Indicted After a 2-Year F.B.I. Investigation
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department today announced the indictment of 46 commodities brokers and traders, accusing them of repeatedly defrauding customers by stealing and skimming investors' profits.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Arbitron's 'Mediawatch'
abstract: LEAD: The Arbitron Company said yesterday that its commercial monitoring system will become electronic in the second quarter of next year. The current manual system measures advertising expenditures and commercial occurrences on network, spot, cable and syndicated television franchises. The change will enable Arbitron's Broadcast Advertisers Reports to measure television commercials 24 hours a day in the top 75 television markets, compared with the 17 markets it now assesses on a full-time basis.

headline: Note and Bond Prices Hold Steady
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers readied themselves for the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.

headline: Washington Warns P.L.O. To Soften Its Tone on Israel
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration criticized the largest faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization today for proposing to ''escalate armed action'' against Israel. American officials warned that such militant attitudes undermined the quest for a negotiated settlement to the Middle East conflict.

headline: Iran Broke C.I.A. Spy Ring, U.S. Says
abstract: LEAD: Early this year, Government officials say, Iran ended what was thought to be one of the Central Intelligence Agency's rare successes in that country: a network of agents who provided intimate details and documents about Iranian military planning.

headline: Spanish Banks in High Gear For Stiff Competition of 1992
abstract: LEAD: With the European Community now committed to deregulating most financial services, Spain's long-protected banking sector is feverishly preparing to survive the stiff competition that will follow creation of a single regional market after 1992.

headline: A United Pilot Sticks to His Goal
abstract: LEAD: Airline industry veterans often scoffed after Frederick C. Dubinsky made up his mind in January 1987 that the best way to insure the pilots' future at United Airlines was for them to own the carrier.

headline: How British Rules Will Affect B.A.T.
abstract: LEAD: THE war for B.A.T. Industries, the old British-American Tobacco, is expected to be fought under British takeover rules. And that could make all the difference in determining who wins.

headline: Business and Health; Medical Expenses Are Strike Issue
abstract: LEAD: MANAGEMENT proposals to shift some health-care expenses to employees have emerged as important sticking points in the stalled contract negotiations that prompted strikes at three regional telephone companies last weekend.

headline: Rebels Plan Next Hardship for Kabul: Winter Without Food Trucks
abstract: LEAD: With food supplies from Pakistan blockaded by Muslim guerrillas for three weeks, the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul is confronting a new weapon to add to the rockets that have been pummeling the capital's morale.

headline: Patents; Coca-Cola's Space-Age Dispenser
abstract: LEAD: American corporations are often criticized for thinking only about short-term profits, but in at least one way the Coca-Cola Company is planning far ahead. Technicians there have patented a drink dispensing machine for outer space, which they hope will be used aboard the planned space station.

headline: Fireman's Fund Stake in McFarland
abstract: LEAD: The Fireman's Fund Corporation said it holds a 13.2 percent stake in the McFarland Energy Corporation and has promised to keep its holdings below 15 percent unless it receives McFarland's approval to exceed that limit. Fireman's said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds the 685,200 shares of M

headline: Seoul Will Aid Shipbuilders
abstract: LEAD: South Korea approved a plan today to revitalize its ailing shipbuilding industry through loans and tax incentives to three companies, including the huge Daewoo Group's debt-ridden shipyard, trade ministry officials said today.

headline: RON HOWARD: A WALL ST. STAR, TOO
abstract: LEAD: To television fans, Ron Howard will always be the actor who played Opie on ''The Andy Griffith Show'' and Richie Cunningham on ''Happy Days.'' To film buffs he is known as the director of ''Splash,'' ''Cocoon'' and this summer's latest hit, ''Parenthood.''

headline: 'The Gulag' Goes Home
abstract: LEAD: Fifteen years after Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn was exiled, a Soviet magazine has begun publishing portions of ''The Gulag Archipelago.'' Page A7.

headline: U.S. FORESEES RUSH IN SOVIET EMIGRES
abstract: LEAD: American diplomats here are bracing for an explosive increase in Soviet emigration to the United States under a law now being drafted that would lift long-standing restrictions on who can leave the country.

headline: Greeks Vote to Begin Inquiry on Papandreou
abstract: LEAD: The Greek Parliament voted overwhelmingly tonight to begin an investigation of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and four of his senior Cabinet members on corruption charges.

headline: Mortgage Rate Rises
abstract: LEAD: The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to 10.21 percent for the week ended today, from 10.09 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said. The average adjustable-rate mortgage was 8.69 percent, unchanged from the previous week, the agency said.

headline: Where the Elk and the Diplomats Roam
abstract: LEAD: In choosing Grand Teton National Park as a setting to talk about arms control with Soviet diplomats this weekend, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will be showing off one of the most dramatic places in the American West but also an area that is in conflict with itself.

headline: Beijing Ousts Governor Tied to Zhao
abstract: LEAD: In a sign that Beijing is trying to crack down on freewheeling economic policies in the provinces, China today announced the dismissal of the Governor of the nation's most experimental economic region.

headline: Treasury Notes and Bonds Ease
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in the credit markets yesterday, as traders sold securities in advance of this morning's release of July employment data and the impending sale of more than $29 billion worth of new Treasury issues.

headline: Another Soviet Area Rejects Russian
abstract: LEAD: Soviet Moldavia established Moldavian as its official language today despite the complaints of tens of thousands of Russian speakers on strike within the republic that the law would increase tension.

headline: Language Now Roils Soviet Moldavia
abstract: LEAD: A protest strike by tens of thousands of minority residents of Soviet Moldavia was reported growing today as the republic's legislature prepared to displace Russian with Moldavian as the official language.

headline: Aoun of Lebanon: Is He a National Savior or, as Foes Say, a 'Mad General'?
abstract: LEAD: Nearly a year after Gen. Michel Aoun was selected to be what he says is Prime Minister of all Lebanon, he has cut such a controversial image that many people in his country and abroad are still trying to decide whether he is the savior he casts himself as or simply an ambitious adventurer.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: Amerifirst Bank, Miami, named Richard L. Eisenman senior vice president, real estate.

headline: I.B.M. Data Will Speed Programs
abstract: LEAD: Filling in one of the final pieces of its vision of computing in the 1990's, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a broad range of software-development tools designed to speed the process of writing and managing new programs.

headline: Institutions Balk at Bid For B.A.T.
abstract: LEAD: Anticipating a higher bid, institutional investors today described the $21 billion offer for B.A.T. Industries made by an investor group headed by Sir James Goldsmith as totally inadequate.

headline: World Bank Ecology Aid
abstract: LEAD: Long criticized for financing environmentally damaging projects, the World Bank today announced increased lending for population-control projects and forestry development, The bank's president, Barber B. Conable Jr., told a conference on the environment that the bank was committed to environmental issues and its commitment would not detract from its primary mission of global development.

headline: About Real Estate; Sales Still Weak Despite Rate Drop
abstract: LEAD: A year after beginning their search, Kevin and Carol Bohan of Elmhurst, Queens, are finally buying their first house. But unlike the Bohans many potential home buyers in the Northeast are not taking advantage of a sharp drop in mortgage rates.

headline: Mark IV Weighs Bid for Interlake
abstract: LEAD: Mark IV Industries said it would explore the possibility of buying the Interlake Corporation of Oak Brook, Ill. Mark IV, which owns 5 percent of Interlake's stock, also said it had asked the Federal Government for permission to raise its stake in Interlake to 14.9 percent. The announcement came a day after Mark IV said it planned to sell the Blackstone

headline: Nutrasweet Plans Increased Output
abstract: LEAD: The Nutrasweet Company announced plans to double the production capacity for its artificial sweetener products, which are marketed in more than 70 countries.

headline: Revised Data on Output Up a Bit in 2d Quarter
abstract: LEAD: American workers posted a modest productivity improvement in the second quarter, with significant gains by factory workers leading the way.

headline: U.S. PRESSES P.L.O. ON ISRAEL'S PLAN TO HOLD ELECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: The United States stepped up its efforts today to persuade the Palestine Liberation Organization to agree to Israel's proposal for elections in the West Bank, while also encouraging a new Egyptian initiative to bridge the gaps between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Offering 'Perestroika Perks,' Aeroflot Beckons U.S. Fliers
abstract: LEAD: Aeroflot, the Soviet national airline, will begin a most American advertising campaign today, appealing directly to business travelers from the United States.

headline: Digital Equipment Offers New Models
abstract: LEAD: As expected, the Digital Equipment Corporation introduced a variety of computers today, including a scientific work station, the Decstation 3100, with prices starting at $7,950, and a more powerful model of its VAX minicomputer line, the VAX 6000 Model 400. The company said the new minicomputer offered an 85 percent performance increase over its existing 6300 line.

headline: The Challenge of Poland; Bush Facing Problems and Opportunities In Bridging Gaps Between East and West
abstract: LEAD: The election of a non-Communist Prime Minister in Poland has confronted the Bush Administration with a conflicting set of challenges and opportunities, which, for now, have combined to produce a strikingly restrained American response to what could be a turning point in East-West relations.

headline: F.T.C. Approves Pennwalt Takeover
abstract: LEAD: An agreement to sell a New Jersey chemical plant has cleared the way for the $1.05 billion takeover of the Pennwalt Corporation by the French oil giant Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine. The Federal Trade Commission unanimously accepted an agreement that allows completion of the $132-a-share deal, the companies said.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Below are the major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.Tuesday None Wednesday New-car sales Aug. U.S. productivity 2d qtr. Thursday None Friday Consumer credit July

headline: Flow of Turks Leaving Bulgaria Swells to Hundreds of Thousands
abstract: LEAD: In endless caravans of cars, buses and trains, more than a quarter of a million Bulgarians of Turkish descent have streamed into Turkey in the last three months, forming one of Europe's largest refugee flows since World War II.

headline: Wine Makers Face Hard Truth
abstract: LEAD: With the sales decline that began in 1987 accelerating ominously, the worries of domestic wine makers are mounting, along with disagreements over how to respond.

headline: 7 Months After the Armenian Quake, 'We Exist'
abstract: LEAD: In the nearly seven months since an earthquake destroyed this city in Armenia's Bazum Mountains, thousands of tenacious people have continued to live here, trying to create normal lives among the ruins.

headline: Insider Gets a 5-Year Term
abstract: LEAD: A former partner in a large Chicago law firm has been sentenced to five years in prison in what is believed to be the longest term ever issued for insider stock trading.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Brooks Brothers Inc., the men's clothier and division of Marks & Spencer P.L.C., promoted Antoine F. Moreira to senior vice president and chief financial officer.

headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; A Fresh Look at the Forgotten I.R.A.
abstract: LEAD: BACK in the mid-80's, millions of people socked away $2,000 each year in Individual Retirement Accounts. I.R.A.'s were hot. Banks and brokerage firms scrambled for these new investors; and investors scoured the markets for the year's best investment.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Cigna Corp., Philadelphia, a provider of insurance, health care and employee benefits, completed the sale of its Horace Mann insurance companies to a new corporation formed by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, a private investment banking firm. The sale price was put at $484 million.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Mistrial Declared in Texas In Big Savings Fraud Case
abstract: LEAD: A mistrial was declared today after a Federal court jury in Lubbock, Tex., said it was unable to reach a verdict in the largest criminal case brought so far involving failed savings institutions.

headline: General Groomed to Succeed Polish Leader Would Preserve Army's Paramount Power
abstract: LEAD: By recommending Interior Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak, his close friend and disciple, for the post of President that he had himself so openly coveted, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, was preserving and affirming the paramount power of the Polish Army.

headline: U.N. Council Calls for Cease-Fire And Arab Mediation in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations Security Council called for an immediate cease-fire in Lebanon late Tuesday and urged the Arab League to resume mediation efforts it discontinued last month.

headline: In Beleaguered Sri Lanka, Fear Is Taking Hold
abstract: LEAD: A weeklong strike by medical workers has virtually emptied the main hospital here and others elsewhere in the country and led to the deaths of several people who could not get adequate medical care. It is a grim reflection of the growing power of an anti-Government force and the seeming helplessness of President Ranasinghe Premadasa's

headline: Excerpts From Bush's Speech to Polish Parliament on Refashioning Europe
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Bush's address today to the Polish Parliament:

headline: Days of Post-Crash Highs And Wide Trading Swings
abstract: LEAD: Stocks swung wildly yesterday but finished moderately higher, setting the market's third post-crash high in a row, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.50, to 2,554.82. For the week, the Dow showed a gain of 66.96 points.

headline: Executive At American Express Quits
abstract: LEAD: An executive vice president of the American Express Company announced yesterday that he would leave the company, saying that he accepted ''executive responsibility'' for an investigation that had led to a campaign to discredit Edmond J. Safra, a banking competitor.

headline: American Group Finds Obstacles To Free and Fair Vote in Namibia
abstract: LEAD: A group of prominent Americans concluding a weeklong visit to Namibia said today that they had found ''major obstacles'' to the free and fair elections scheduled in November as part of the territory's transition to self-rule.

headline: Hasbro Names Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Hasbro Inc., the toy company, said yesterday that it had named Alan G. Hassenfeld its chairman and chief executive.

headline: Savings Crisis
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Buick Introduces Reatta Convertible
abstract: LEAD: Buick has introduced its Reatta convertible after solving engineering problems. Buick's general manager, Ed Mertz, said the General Motors Corporation division might make as many Reatta convertibles as hard-top versions of the car, which has two seats.

headline: Suitor in 3 Offers For Dataproducts
abstract: LEAD: The Dataproducts Corporation, a manufacturer of computer printers in Woodland Hills, Calif., said it had received three proposals from DPC Acquisition Partners to buy Dataproducts or acquire a number of its subsidiaries. The bid from DPC for all of Dataproducts is worth $15 a share, of which at least $10 would be in cash.

headline: Market Place; Closer Scrutiny Of Bid for B.A.T.
abstract: LEAD: IN 1985, Ted Turner made an offer for CBS Inc. that seemed absurd - all paper and not a penny of cash. Eventually, Mr. Turner retired from the scene, but that offer helped set in motion the chain of events that led to control of CBS passing to Laurence A. Tisch of the Loews Corporation.

headline: Behind Film's Warning on Cigarettes
abstract: LEAD: A PROMINENT Congressional opponent of cigarette advertising said yesterday that his accusations that the placement of brand-name cigarettes in movies constituted advertising had prompted a studio to add the Surgeon General's warning on cigarette use at the end of a film.

headline: Excerpts From the Speech by Shevardnadze Before the General Assembly
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from the address yesterday by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union to the United Nations General Assembly. The speech was translated by a United Nations interpreter and recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. . . . Yesterday we listened with close attention to the speech of President George Bush of the United States, a statement which in our view contained a number of very important and interesting ideas.

headline: Market Place; Partial Stock Split Worries S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: IT was one of the more dramatic stock moves of 1989. The Lifeline Healthcare Group, a home health care company, saw its stock rise from below $4 a share to above $30, then fall back to $15.

headline: Israel to Sell Big Stake In El Al
abstract: LEAD: El Al, Israel's national airline, announced yesterday that the Israeli Government plans to sell a large stake in the company to domestic and foreign investors.

headline: Founder Relinquishes Management at Carver
abstract: LEAD: The Carver Corporation, a manufacturer of high-performance stereo components based in Lynnwood, Wash., has appointed Robert R. Dougherty president and chief executive. He succeeds Robert W. Carver, the company's founder, who will remain chairman and assume the new title of vice president for advanced research.

headline: Investing After the Crackdown
abstract: LEAD: IN an unruffled voice, Zhang Xiaobin explains that not much has changed at his venture capital firm since the dramatic crackdown in Beijing two months ago. His employees come to work, his profit targets are within grasp, he still travels.

headline: At Last, Japan Takes Center Stage
abstract: LEAD: The seven largest Western industrial nations will conclude their annual economic summit conference in Paris today. Since 1975, these yearly meetings have generated an impressive degree of consensus among world leaders on how to organize their complex trade, monetary and financial relations in an increasingly interdependent world.

headline: Spending Is Up 0.9% as Incomes Rise 0.4%
abstract: LEAD: In another sign of continued economic expansion, consumer spending increased by nine-tenths of 1 percent in August even though incomes rose just four-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: Stake Is Raised In Software Maker
abstract: LEAD: Walter H. Haefner, a Swiss industrialist, raised his stake in Computer Associates International Inc. to 21.5 percent, from 20.5 percent, and said he would buy 2.56 million more shares of the computer software concern, based in Garden City, L.I. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Haefner said he would buy the additional shares so his stake would not be diluted by Computer Associates' acquisition of Cullinet Software

headline: Lockheed Asks Cleanup
abstract: LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation said it has proposed to the Government spending $52 million over six years to help remove contaminants from groundwater in Burbank, Calif., site of the company's aeronautical systems division.

headline: PALESTINIANS GAIN RIGHT TO CONTEST HOUSE DEMOLITIONS
abstract: LEAD: Israel's Supreme Court ruled today that Palestinians accused of wrongdoing must be given time to appeal through the military and civilian courts before the army demolishes their homes.

headline: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization           July 7   June 30   July 8        1989   1989   1988       Gasoline production, daily   7.4   7.4   7.2        Distillate production, daily   2.8   2.9   2.7        Gasoline stocks   226.4   226.0   213.0        Distillate stocks   114.0   111.5   119.5        Crude imports, daily   5.8   6.6   5.7        Product imports, daily   2.1   2.0   1.7        Crude stocks   333.5   330.1   347.9        Crude production, daily   7.6   7.6   8.0        Refinery utilization (%)   87.6   91.0   87.9

headline: U.S. Envoy Is Center of New Dispute in Rome
abstract: LEAD: His nomination as United States Ambassador to Italy raised questions in Rome about his qualifications and complaints in Washington about his lapses into undiplomatic language.

headline: Ariel Sharon Planning An Official Soviet Visit
abstract: LEAD: Ariel Sharon, Israel's trade and industry minister, accepted an official invitation today to visit Soviet Georgia, the national news agency Itim and Israel radio reported.

headline: THAT 'CLEANER FUEL' MAY BE GASOLINE
abstract: LEAD: The oil business, faced with government proposals to clean the air by replacing gasoline with methanol, compressed natural gas or electricity, is suddenly espousing a previously overlooked substitute: cleaner gasoline. The reformulated fuel announced by ARCO last week for older cars that run on leaded gas is only the beginning, the industry says.

headline: GROWING TENSIONS OVER MEXICAN VOTE
abstract: LEAD: In a move that is being widely criticized here as ''selective democracy,'' the Mexican Government has overridden the left-wing opposition's claims to victory in one state while acknowledging the election triumph of a right-wing opposition party in another.

headline: Drug Executive Is Sentenced
abstract: LEAD: The former president of an Indianapolis generic drug manufacturer who paid $32,000 in bribes to three officials of the Food and Drug Administration has been fined $250,000 and ordered to serve a year working for the American Cancer Society. In addition, United States

headline: Your Money; Is Small Investor Late for the Rally?
abstract: LEAD: Many small investors are wondering, now that the broad measures of the stock market are at their all-time highs and the Dow Jones industrial average is flirting with its August 1987 peak, if they, too, could realize profits in the stock market.

headline: ESPIONAGE SUSPECT REPORTEDLY TOLD F.B.I. OF PAYMENT
abstract: LEAD: Felix S. Bloch, the State Department official under investigation for espionage, told the Federal Bureau of Investigation in his one brief interview that he had been paid ''a lot of money'' by the Soviet Union, an official involved in the case said yesterday.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Cooper Life Sciences Inc., said it had notified Cooper Development Co., Menlo Park, Calif., a developer of health-care products, that because of a delay in reaching an overall settlement with Cooper Cos. Inc., Palo Alto, Calif., a maker of surgical products, it would re-evaluate its proposed merger with Cooper Development.

headline: A Gorbachev Deadline on Armenia Issue
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned the leaders of two southern republics today that they have two days to negotiate an end to an extraordinary rail blockade that has paralyzed Armenia.

headline: L. F. Rothschild's Ex-Chief Will Head Meridian Unit
abstract: LEAD: Meridian Bancorp Inc., a regional banking company pushing into the securities industry, has created a merchant banking unit and named Gary Lieberman as its president.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Suzuki Narrows Search
abstract: LEAD: The American Suzuki Motor Company, the domestic arm of the Japanese auto manufacturer, narrowed its ad agency search to three shops with offices in Los Angeles, Asher/ Gould Advertising; Wieden & Kennedy, whose base is Portland; and Hakuhodo, the Japanese ad agency. A spokeswoman for Suzuki said the review would take six to eight weeks and would include speculative creative work.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Playtex Family Account To Margeotes, Fertitta
abstract: LEAD: Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss yesterday won the advertising account for a new line of hair care products from the Playtex Family Products Corporation.
